Buddy read with my childhood friend Pippin aka Jen, my closest companion Sam aka Bhavik, my distant pal Aragorn aka Rusty

As for me, I'm Frodo, reading a book about my own adventures.

Also shoutout to the guy who left us midway and went off on his own Merry aka Fares

Title: Ruin and Rising (The Shadow and Bone Trilogy, #3)
Author: Leigh Bardugo
Bookshelves: adventure, books-in-series, characters-that-hold-my-heart, could-have-been-better, drama-overloaded, e-n-d-i-n-g, fantasy, i-didnt-get-the-point, made-me-lol, over-hyped, romance-lovey-dovey, spiralling-downward, young-adult
Bookshelves with positions: adventure (#34), books-in-series (#79), characters-that-hold-my-heart (#22), could-have-been-better (#27), drama-overloaded (#24), e-n-d-i-n-g (#3), fantasy (#36), i-didnt-get-the-point (#40), made-me-lol (#26), over-hyped (#18), romance-lovey-dovey (#103), spiralling-downward (#9), young-adult (#149)
My Review:
“The problem with wanting is that it makes us weak”

Just how weak wanting to like this book made me, I had no idea. So many things went wrong with this book, and NO THE ROMANCE ISN’T ONE OF THEM. In fact, if you’ve read my review of Shadow and Bone, you’d know that I got exactly what I was looking for, in terms of romance. But the plot went hallelujah here and I’m not going to be weak enough to overlook that fact and give this book five stars.

I’m not going to bother you or myself with a summary, because this book depends entirely on what happened in the prequels, so bear with me while I rant xD

Obv, ****SPOILERS AHEAD****

SO MANY PLOTHOLES. Let’s see how crappy my memory is, because I didn’t note these down.

1. The Escape


• Alina isn’t able to summon sunlight while in the White Cathedral, which is basically an underground tunnel, supposedly because sunlight is out of reach.
• But while they’ve escaped and are running through an underground tunnel, she manages to summon light and keep them illuminated and warm,
• Plus she can summon at night or when they’re in The Fold.
• If she can summon light when the sun is all the way across the other side of the planet, then surely being underground shouldn’t matter? Hmm?


2. The History


• Why did Baghra suddenly decide to indulge Alina with the story of her past?
• And besides, how exactly did Morozova bring back his dead child? It’s mentioned that he used merzost, but it’s not acknowledged just why other Grishas can’t do the same.
• WHO IS ALINA STARKOV? Where does her last name come from, if they’ve no idea of her past?
• Also, how did she get her power, if The Darkling got his from his mother? So there must have been other sun summoners before her, which apparently isn’t the case.


3. FLYING

• I still don’t get how their ship flies.
• To even create that ship, a lot of effort and time are required, but Nikolai has flying ships hanging on his backyard like he bought it on a sale. And Nikolai isn’t even a Grisha!
• While hunting for the firebird, Zoya is flying the ship for like 16 hours, which would be enough work to make her drop dead.
• Like, do you realize just how difficult it would be to manipulate air to make a ship fly? That thing might be weighing tons + there are passengers aboard.
• And, doesn’t there need to be a steering or something? What if a mountain comes in between? A tree? A firebird? A volcra?

4. THE BOND

• So Alina got bit by a nichevo’ya some time ago which drops a hint of darkness into her being – through a dark scar on her shoulder - enabling her to have this connection of sorts with The Darkling.
• In the second book, The Darkling is able to spy on Alina and freak her out all the time because of it. They can talk, touch and kiss like it was real, even when they were miles away from each other.
• This time, somehow, only Alina can visit the Darkling and find out what he’s up to, which is how The Darkling lies to her about trapping innocent kids to lure her for a confrontation.
• And all the while, The Darkling is oblivious of Alina’s location; a party is out to search for her. Couldn’t he simply have visited her in her head and found out?
• Or does it somehow work only one-sided this time around?

5. THE PLAN


• So basically, David has this little idea that Alina might be able to bend light around objects to make them invisible.
• Obviously it works, and Bardugo even connects it to science (‘Google Invisibility Cloak Technology’, she says)
• And their ridiculous, idiotic plan? To barge in to the Fold invisible and startle The Darkling.
• Like heck! There are about a dozen of them, how does Alina think she can bend light around ALL OF THEM AT THE SAME TIME?? It would mean they’d all need to remain in the same position without moving, which basically ruins the purpose of their little excursion.
• And our stupid, reckless Alina Starkov goes on to the basement of the ship to free some kids who aren’t even there (it was always obvious!), all the while trying to keep her crew invisible at the same time.
• TELL ME YOU HAVE READ OF SOMETHING MORE RIDICULOUS AND STUPID AND I’LL GIFT YOU A CANDY

6. THE DARKNESS


• Like Alina summons light, the Darkling can summon darkness. Apparently it’s genetic.
• I think we all know that darkness is the absolute absence of light. But with the Darkling, he can summon darkness and everybody will still see through it.
• And he can also summon darkness to make people invisible.
• I mean how many types of darkness do you know? A see-through darkness, a see-nothing-but-darkness darkness? -_-
• ALSO, The Darkling does something to Nikolai where he unleashes a nichevo’ya onto his body which makes him basically the same like those monsters.
• But, the Nichevo’yas can only be around The Darkling within a short circle radius of him; but Nikolai is flying and following Alina miles away from The Darkling???

7. THE AMPLIFIERS

• Near to the end of the book, we’re told that the whole purpose of Malyen Oretsev was to be an amplifier for Alina.
• If her powers died when she killed him, then how exactly was she to combine the power of the amplifiers and supposedly destroy the Darkling?
• AND BLOODY HELL HE SURVIVED THE KILL, WHICH WAS A KNIFE TO HIS HEART.
• Now if that resurrection wasn’t merzost, tell me what is.

8. THE ENDING

• When Alina kills Mal, she loses her power and the power wields itself onto every other Grisha near her.
• Wtf, HOW DANGEROUS AND WORLD-THREATENING IS THAT????? Now all of them can summon light, and use THE CUT and threaten or rule the world as they like, because sun summoners were SAINTS, apparently.
• Also, can we all please share a laugh at how funny that ending was, especially the Darkling’s???
• I mean, a stab with a knife!!!! Lol. Remember Baghra said it took too much to kill the Darkling or the sun summoner? Of course, no one could have picked up a knife and stabbed the Darkling in his sleep. How difficult!
• AND DON’T FORGET HOW CONVENIENT IT WAS FOR ALINA TO LOSE HER POWER SO SHE COULD HAVE A HAPPILY-EVER-AFTER WITH HER DARLING MAL, WITHOUT ANY EGOISTICAL PROBLEMS TO AFFECT THEIR RELATIONSHIP. Phew!


Besides all the crappy plot, here are some random thoughts that passed through my head while reading this book -
• Nikolai’s entry when Alina and party were captured by the militia was priceless.
• That hole-in-a-mountain-residence-thingy was,… ridiculous?
• So was, performing The Cut to slice off a mountain.
• Mal and The Darkling are cousins.
• Those little snippets from Mal and Alina’s past were too adorable.
• Zoya’s sarcastic comments and wit were my only boosters to keep reading.
• Book ends. Me - *cringe*

Now don’t you dare tell me that this book was actually good and that I should know to read better?
But I’d really appreciate it if you point out anything that I’ve missed.

So basically, this is not the first time a trilogy ending has disappointed me. You all should be wary of the danger ahead if you decide to go through with this book. Fair warning xD


----------------------------

Initial review -

If you are looking for a stupid, ridiculous, makes-no-sense book; this is what you're looking for.

Title: Come Back to Leave Me... Again
Author: Sohil Ashvin Shah
My Review:
If you’re interested in reading the book looking at its cover, title, or blurb - DON’T BE. This story is nothing like it promises to be.

Sohil Ashvin Shah meets Prerna Sharma in a café, and introduces himself as an author. Prerna luckily gets a copy of his book and promises to reach out after reading it.

The story is narrated by Siddhant Shah, who’s working in Dubai. He meets Hritisha Jain, assistant manager at a company where he goes for evening classes. For Siddhant, it was love at first sight. Slowly they get closer and become best friends. Hritisha returns to India. And Siddhant’s parents start a bride-search for him. After a failed arranged-marriage-setup, Siddhant realizes he loves Hritisha, and they become a couple once she accepts his love-confession. From then on, it is a matter of surprises, family-meetups and convincing Hritisha’s family to accept Siddhant as their son-in-law.

The story is nothing new, and is partly based on the author’s life which is what makes it authentic. Sohil doesn’t hold back anything – the online chats, sexting, meetups and romance are all honestly depicted. But there were a few problems that made this book less enjoyable for me.

• The Concept of Beauty

I’m still bugged at how old-fashioned the concept of beauty is in this book. Just about any girl who’s fair skinned is called ‘beautiful’ and ‘girlfriend-material’. Like, this is how Siddhant reacts the moment he first sees Hritisha –

“Gosh! She was beautiful! My eyes started fixating on every inch of her flawless fair skin. There was not a single mark or zit on her face.”

And this is what Siddhant has to say about a waitress in a club he only just met -

“She was quite tall, slim and fair; anyone would fall in love with her at the very first sight.”

I mean, seriously? A zit on your face is natural; it’s a part of your teenage process. There’s nothing wrong with that. Flawless fair skin should not be the default standard for beauty. When will this trend stop?

• Fat-shaming

There is so much fat-shaming in this book. Siddhant is a bit overweight and Hritisha constantly ridicules him over it, asking him to diet, reduce his weight, and not be a fat-bimbo. And Siddhant is actually ashamed of his weight too, going along with whatever she says. It is depicted as if being fat is a wrong way to be. That’s ridiculous and I’m done with reading such shit, especially since half of the Indian population is overweight :/

• Insta-Love

The insta-love in this book is at its peak. You know how? Siddhant falls in love with Hritisha from the very first moment he hears her voice through the phone. He’s restless after that, he can’t sit still and is on constant lookout for the girl with the silvery voice. I mean, like wtf? That’s the most ridiculous way I’ve seen someone falling in love.

• The local slang and shayari

The author used a lot of Gujarati words and local slang in this book. In fact an entire chapter was dedicated to the Gujarati poet Mareez Sahab. His shayar made frequent and well-timed appearance it his book. While I appreciate the author’s attempt to introduce his readers to local poetry, it was difficult to understand at times even though the translations come right afterward. There were too many of them, some of which I might have shamelessly skimmed through. It isn’t a pleasant experience to read in a language you don’t understand. We aren’t trying to get a language lesson; we’re more interested in the story. The whole deal makes me feel like the targeted audience was rather too small. The author was trying to tell his story, but he didn’t try to make it interesting enough for a wide range of audiences. I felt that the author confined the intended audience to a small group of people and anyone outside this circle won’t find the book interesting. If I ever write a story, I’d try to include my culture, but in an appealing kind of way. We need the readers to understand the perspective, not be repelled by it.

As for the book in whole, I wouldn’t exactly recommend it – the writing is sloppy and the narrative is a bit disoriented. But the dialogues felt natural, and not considering the insta-lovey beginning, there was real development between the main couple. And I loved how the author tried to answer our questions with his epilogue – Prerna meets Sohil to talk about his book, and she asks him questions about his book the readers would also have in mind. Even if they don’t answer the questions in the blurb, it helps us distinguish fiction from real life.

In short, there have been better debuts, but you cannot deny that the author is talented.


------- * ------- * ------- * -------

Probably one of the reasons why no one reads Indian contemporary anymore. This was a poorly written version of [b:I Too Had a Love Story|7977973|I Too Had a Love Story|Ravinder Singh|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1270373915s/7977973.jpg|7364012] but I could see the author has some potential.

Title: Holding Up the Universe
Author: Jennifer Niven
Publisher: Alfred A. Knopf Books for Young Readers
Bookshelves: contemporary, family, made-me-cry, made-me-lol, really-liked-it, romance-lovey-dovey, why-no-hype, young-adult, 50-states-challenge
Bookshelves with positions: contemporary (#72), family (#14), made-me-cry (#41), made-me-lol (#32), really-liked-it (#95), romance-lovey-dovey (#114), why-no-hype (#19), young-adult (#162), 50-states-challenge (#20)
My Review:
For everyone who felt that this book is offensive and fat-shaming and trying to garner attention by portraying cognitive disorder - PLEASE KNOW THAT, THIS IS AN #OWNVOICES STORY. JENNIFER NIVEN HERSELF HAD OBESITY ISSUES AND THE PROSOPAGNOSIA PLOT-POINT WAS INSPIRED BY SOMEONE SHE PERSONALLY KNEW. You’d know this if you read the Author’s note. And let’s all give the author space to write about what she wants. Thanks.


image source: Patty's review

Holding Up The Universe is narrated in the point of view of two teens - Jack Masselin, who has a brain disorder called prosopagnosia which makes him unable to recognize faces, even the faces of his family and loved ones; and Libby Strout, who was once entitled ‘America’s Fattest Teen’. Libby’s lost her mother in an accident and has lost quite some weight since then. But she’s still the fat girl at Martin Van Buren High School. The two become acquainted in detention classes and realize they’re two outcasts with similar problems. Doing full justice to the themes it addresses, THIS IS A BOOK YOU NEED TO READ. Not for the romance, but for the message, for the underlying subject of dealing with obesity and questioning the general norms of beauty in our society.

THE WRITING

I loved Niven’s writing in [b:All the Bright Places|18460392|All the Bright Places|Jennifer Niven|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1404331702s/18460392.jpg|26113532] and I adored it here. Her immaculate consistent flow is very easy to read. BUT. Niven uses these silly similes and metaphors that probably was meant for emphasis, but felt nothing short of ridiculous.
Like, see this –

“I feel my stomach drop and land somewhere around the gas pedal.”

Umm, whutt?? Girl, you’re dead then.

Or this –

“My heart goes hopscotching out of the room and down the hall and out the door and into the street”

Like, WTF?? Just picture that and tell me if you survive.

And this comes right after –

“And now my heart is nowhere on earth to be found. I can see it as it bypasses the moon and the stars and goes blasting into another galaxy”

Me: *dead*

MY THOUGHTS

• Fat Girl Rogue is the stupidest game I’ve ever heard of.
• Like, ‘hug-a-fat-girl-and-squeeze-the-hell-out-of-her’?? Seriously, WhO cOmES uP WiTh SuCH sHIt??
• Jack’s brother Dusty is a lil’ munchkin I’d like to cuddle.
• Also, DIVERSITY. Jack’s half-black.
• Idk how any kid can live up to 16 years without their parents not recognizing they have prosopagnosia.
• Jack’s parents are either very ignorant or Jack is very potent at hiding his condition from them. UNREALISTIC
• But why would anyone want to hide their prosopagnosia from their parents?
• Wait, Brad Pitt has prosopagnosia?? O.o
• THANK GOD, no insta-love
• And YET
• The Libby-Jack romance was forced. Unrealistic. Unsatisfying. Every other un-insert_suitable_word_here
• If you ask me, the prosopagnosia rep was rather dull.
• I still can’t picture how a prosopagnosiac person sees faces. It’s confusing, and may I say, NOT DESCRIBED WELL
• Also did you know, [b:We Have Always Lived in the Castle|89724|We Have Always Lived in the Castle|Shirley Jackson|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1415357189s/89724.jpg|847007] is the newest addition to my tbr.
• It makes me effing happy to see characters talking about books and referencing books
• LIKE HECK YEAH, WE’RE BOOK LOVERS WE NEED PEOPLE WHO LOVE BOOKS IN OUR BOOKS
• Libby Strout gives me self-esteem goals.
• And Libby’s dad is THE BEST

“You realize you’ve just asked me if you can skip school and borrow money in the same conversation? You realize I’m the world’s best dad?”

• AND LIBBY STROUT IN GENERAL IS JUST THE TAKE-NO-SHIT FAT GIRL WITH ANXIETY PROBLEMS YOU NEED IN YOUR LIFE,,,

• Look at this –

“I look at Elise’s perfect hair and face and figure. Of course people love to watch her dance. Of course she marries the prince. I wonder what would have happened if Elise had looked like me”.

• ^^This book dwells on everything that’s wrong with the world. Like, look at fairy tales for instance. Every other girl is skinny and fair with perfect blond or black hair and blue/green eyes. No fat princesses, no zits ever on any of those flawless faces. No people of color. Same falls for the Princes too. Except for The Beast who also turns out to be a handsome young prince. I mean, more than half of the population is overweight and non-white but we’ve been raised on these stupid stories filled with stereotypes since the beginning of the world. That you need to look good and ooze beauty for you to have a fairy-tale-happy-ending. hOW THE FRIGGING FRIG DOES THAT WORK??
• If you think Libby talks of being fat all the time, think again. That’s what they’re being told Every. Single. Time. They can’t just forget the fact that whenever people look at them they’re being judged for their weight. That’s an accurate rep imo. NOTHING WRONG WITH A FAT GIRL THINKING SHE’S FAT BECAUSE WHAT ELSE IS SHE SUPPOSED TO THINK OF WHEN WE THE PEOPLE DON’T BOTHER TO TELL HER ANYTHING ELSE??
• The ending? Nah. I don’t buy that. I wasn’t really invested in the romance, and frankly this book is more than just the romance. It doesn’t dominate the book. It doesn’t dwindle the actual message.


Even with the problematic writing at some places and the unromantic romance, I’d say this book is still a must read. The way it addresses the issue of obesity is what won me over. Of course, it’s nowhere near good as [b:All the Bright Places|18460392|All the Bright Places|Jennifer Niven|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1404331702s/18460392.jpg|26113532] and don’t expect it to be heartbreaking either. Just read it!

Also, remember, DOESN’T MATTER WHETHER YOU’RE FAIR OR DARK, SHORT OR TALL, SKINNY OR FAT, FLAWLESS OR ZITTY, OR JUST ANYWHERE IN BETWEEN - YOU ARE WANTED - DON’T EVER LET ANYONE CONVINCE YOU OTHERWISE. IT’S NOT THEIR PLACE TO JUDGE YOU, NOT YOURS TO JUDGE THEM EITHER.



* * * * * * * * * * * *

Initial review -

Forget Leah Burke and every other fat girl, LIBBY STROUT IS WHOM YOU SHOULD BE READING ABOUT

Title: Piano Lessons Can Be Murder (Goosebumps, #13)
Author: R.L. Stine
My Review:
This book wasn't anything memorable. It's basically a rip-off from every other goosebumps books.
The plot was cliche and totally predictable. Here,

- The MC and his family moves to an creepy and old house.
- He finds a piano in the attic, and obviously brings it down.
- He hears the piano playing by itself at night. (Every. Piano. Cliche. Ever)
- His parents insists he should learn to play, so they put him under the tutor of a creepy old guy.
- The neighborhood girl and a ghost warns him away from his new teacher and his school.
- The stories turn out to be true.

And the ending? Uh, no one saw that coming! *eye rolls* Like, it was basically any child's guess.
The school is haunted and he was bought there because his hands were 'excellent' duh! And that creepy machine genius? Of course, he turns out to be the mastermind! And the ghost and her friends destroy him... forever? DUH

All in all, I wasn't very impressed with this book, even if it was my second time reading it.

Title: The Notebook
Author: Nicholas Sparks
Bookshelves: books-i-own, made-me-cry, really-liked-it, romance-lovey-dovey, mature-stuff, books-in-series, 50-states-challenge
Bookshelves with positions: books-i-own (#4), made-me-cry (#9), really-liked-it (#23), romance-lovey-dovey (#20), mature-stuff (#6), books-in-series (#14), 50-states-challenge (#21)
My Review:
The Notebook is the sappiest, cheesiest, most….er, romantic book I might’ve ever read. Nicholas Sparks weaves romantic lines from the simplest of words and they turn out cringey and good at the same time.

So, why the four stars? This book was given to me by my uncle when I was barely fourteen. I remember reading it then and wondering if he had actually read it, and then thinking that if he had, then he must consider me mature enough to read this book, and feeling quite proud of the fact. Back then, I swooned over the romance, though neither the characters nor the romance itself is swoon worthy. I remember really loving the miracle aspect of the novel, of how Sparks thought that miracles really do happen, of hoping I’d encounter a miracle myself and be forced to believe the same. Rereading it now, expecting what is to come, I knew there wasn’t going to be any mind-blowing moments or anything remotely close. This is merely the way it is for me, and not a book I’d recommend to others. Looking at all the one-star reviews, I understand why this novel failed to please so many readers, but nevertheless, it remains one of the very few books I own, and so, it’s too important for me to not love it. I realize I sound as cheesy and corny as Sparks does in this book, so I’d get on with the review.

Noah Taylor Calhoun has loved only once. The summer he turned seventeen, he met Allie Nelson at a festival in his home town of New Bern in North Carolina. Allie was there for nearly two months, but those two months lasted a lifetime for the two of them. They met each day and made memories and slowly fell irrevocably in love. Fast forward, Noah is thirty-one and alone, renovating an old house he had always loved - losing himself in work - trying to stay away from the memories of the hazel-eyed girl he’d once fallen in love with. Allie is twenty-nine, engaged, and lives a routine life she’d always thought she’d lead. But an encounter with each other was all they needed. The old memories rush in. Bonding over candle-light dinner and kayak rides, the two once again discover why they’d fallen for each other, and even more, that they’d never stopped.

Noah and Allie’s relationship while at first might seem like insta-love, there are a thousand memories that make up their chemistry, but unfortunately the author doesn’t deem them necessary enough to share with his readers. The summer they initially met is mentioned many times, but only in conversation. We don’t get to see what or why they fell in love, nor do we get to see the development that is so obviously there. Sparks makes it work though; he makes us believe that Noah and Allie truly share a wonderful past, that there were some wonderful moments that keep them bonded. I only wish we could’ve experienced it with them.

What I loved the most was the family dynamic in this book. Noah’s father has no role here, but he’s so often present in Noah’s thoughts. I love how he made his father sound like this wise old man, who’d loved his son and raised him to be the tough, nature-loving gentleman that he is. And then there is this one instance, where Noah talks about losing a child and how it feels, of growing up together with your family, bringing up kids – they all hit right on the spot. I also loved Allie’s mother, who despite everything, loved her daughter and wanted her to be happy no matter what.
The vivid, clear description of New Bern and the natural aura, the kayaking, canoeing, rain, art and paintings; everything felt heartrendingly nice to me. Even though this book is supposed to be set around the time of Second World War, we don’t get to see the bad side – the depression, the deaths, the bloodshed and poverty. I can’t decide if that is a good thing or bad.

The Romance? If you have the patience for long-drawn, meant-to-be-poetic-but-are-actually-sap kinda romantic letters and descriptions of sex, then maybe you’ll love this book. There’s no way in hell that actual people speak the way Noah does, there’s no way people actually write such cringe-worthy letters. It is unrealistic, yes, for the most part. But what do you expect from a romance? The chemistry between Noah and Allie felt real to me, but sometimes hasty. I’d say the character of Lon Hammond had no real significance in this book, and the male characters all act a little too gentlemanly (there are only two of them actually). But I loved reading the very realistic concerns of an old man groping over his upcoming death, reminiscing his long life and feeling ancient – they felt real and believable, as if the author himself had such thoughts bothering him.

The Ending ? was far too stretched and the author dwelt on the same thing again and again, as if he didn’t know how to end it all and was waiting for inspiration to strike. There were some fillers, some boring parts – unnecessary additions that could’ve been avoided. Otherwise, there wasn’t a real ending at all.

Title: An American Marriage
Author: Tayari Jones
Bookshelves: 2018, 50-states-challenge, contemporary, family, favorite-dads, favorite-moms, really-liked-it, romance-lovey-dovey, verging-on-five-stars, young-adult, why-no-hype
Bookshelves with positions: 2018 (#8), 50-states-challenge (#13), contemporary (#69), family (#12), favorite-dads (#4), favorite-moms (#6), really-liked-it (#94), romance-lovey-dovey (#112), verging-on-five-stars (#11), young-adult (#159), why-no-hype (#18)
My Review:
I would’ve loved to give this book five stars, but something is stopping me. Four seems like an injustice to this book, considering that I’ve been four-starring books that are nowhere near as good as this. I’ll settle for a 4.5/5 stars.

The Plot

An American Marriage is a quick read. It is about being black in America, being married, being in love, and being away from your loved ones for too long. Roy Othaniel Hamilton and Celestial Davenport are in their earliest stage of marriage – the settling down stage. They have it all – money, home, car, jobs and a promising future. But when life decides to throw them lemons, they forget to make lemonades. Andre and Celestial have always been best friends since childhood. When things with her husband gets bad, Celestial turns to Andre for comfort.
Would being together by obligation beat being together by love? And what does it mean, to be a black man in America?


The Writing

It is written in three-person point-of-view. Unlike many other books attempting multiple point-of-views, this book actually manages to let you know where you are, who’s talking. It works, this three pov thing, and it is actually what makes us readers get hooked.
It was amazing, the pacing and plotting of this book. There wasn’t a single moment to be bored. Even though the book is about 400+ pages, you just fly by. The writing was really familiar to me, it felt really smooth, and didn’t take time to get used to. The story was completely satisfactory. No loose, dangling threads, no issues unaddressed. The ending could have been a total let-down, if it wasn’t handled right, which was fortunately not the case.


The Characters

A cast of well-developed characters and the complex relationships between them is what makes this book a winner. BUT, if there was anything lacking for me in this book, it was emotional attachment. I couldn’t really feel for the characters, and I suspect Tayari Jones deliberately made it that way. You see, you can’t take sides in this book. There comes a time when you’re forced to, when people make bad decisions, when you consider one person well over the other. But really, Jones leaves no space for siding up. All three characters are on their own, and all you feel for them is empathy. Believe me, you just can’t take sides. I’ve tried. Even with the depth and closeness to reality these characters exhibit, there was something lacking too. The intensity. Somehow it works too.


The relationships

The complexity of the relationships in this book is mind-blowing. And the intricately delicate way Jones handled it, was brilliant it say the least. Roy and Celestial’s relationship was fragile from the start. They’ve been married for only about one-and-a-half year before tragedy strikes. On the other hand Andre and Celestial have known each other for a long time. This complexity shows throughout the story. But I have to say, the connection, the chemistry between the leads was missing. Again, I don’t know if it was deliberate, because it would only have complicated things more. All throughout the book, I felt like Jones never intended for her readers to connect to the story, for her characters to be intense, just so we could focus on the big picture. It must have worked, because all I cared for was how it all ended. And it ended well. Though, I was a bit disappointed a bit with the turn of events in Roy’s life. He ends up with the woman with whom he spends the first two nights after his release. There wasn’t much visible growth in the character’s lives.

What I loved the most about this book, were THE PARENTS. Roy’s mama Olive and daddy Big Roy were one of the best parents I’ve read of. That was family goals. I loved Big Roy so much. I wished we had more of Olive though. Celestial’s parents were really well developed and impactful too. I especially loved Mr. Davenport and his devoted loyalty to Roy and the Black community. Also, I’ve got to say this - having read so much on family and relationships, I feel like the Black community has the most intense relationship and the deepest connection to each other. They care so much for their brothers and sisters, their family, their fellow countrymen. It’s unnerving, their emotional attachment. It’s relationship goals. They’d die defending their friends and family. And I think the rest of the world has a lot to learn from the way the black people treat each other.


To sum up, this book is one of the best book of 2018 I’ve read so far, and I believe it would be throughout the year. There are some amazing life lessons to be gained from this book. You’d definitely not regret reading this.
“Time can’t always be measured with a watch, or a calendar or even grains of sand.”




*******************************

Initial Review -

WONDERFULLY CRAFTED, a must read.

Title: The Girl Who Cried Monster (Goosebumps, #8)
Author: R.L. Stine
Bookshelves: young-adult, suspense-thriller-mystery, horror-paranormal, fantasy, books-for-children, old-school-library-reads, goosebumps-frenzy, 50-states-challenge
Bookshelves with positions: young-adult (#53), suspense-thriller-mystery (#6), horror-paranormal (#10), fantasy (#16), books-for-children (#27), old-school-library-reads (#2), goosebumps-frenzy (#5), 50-states-challenge (#12)
My Review:
This was the first Goosebumps book I ever read. It was well over six years ago, but I still remember how I finished reading it in one-sitting, one hefty afternoon when my cousin had come over. He was talking to my sister, and by the time I’d finished, they were still talking! Anyway, this book is nowhere as good as how it appeared to me back then. But still, you have to give Stine some credit. That guy has some serious creepy-book-writing talent.

Lucy is twelve always cooks up monster stories to scare her 6-yo brother. She’s usually obsessed over monsters, and it’s easy to scare her brother Randy and even her best friend Aaron. But one day, she happens to witness their town librarian Mr. Mortman turning into an actual monster and eating yucky moths and flies. Turns out, nobody believes her. Her mother thinks it’s just another monster story she made up to keep away from the library. But Lucy is determined to have them believe her, she’s going to show them proof. And meanwhile, she needs to make sure the monster doesn’t realize she knows his secret, or she’d be his next meal instead of the flies!

It’s amazing how easily Stine comes up with such believable characters and cooks up such ridiculously creepy stories. But they’re entertaining and easy to read. I didn’t particularly like Lucy because she was stupid, and never treated her best friend Aaron, right. Neither did he, for that matter. Though that’s understandable because they’re kids. The ending was a big twist I didn’t see coming. Lucy’s whole family actually feed on monsters and have fangs!

For a goosebumps book, it was pretty good thrill. But it’s still childish and sometimes even a bit predictable. Otherwise though, a quick easy scare!

Title: Flipped
Author: Wendelin Van Draanen
Bookshelves: 50-states-challenge, adapted-to-tv-movie, books-for-children, contemporary, family, hopefully-more-to-come, i-need-the-book, liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure
Bookshelves with positions: 50-states-challenge (#11), adapted-to-tv-movie (#17), books-for-children (#56), contemporary (#68), family (#11), hopefully-more-to-come (#7), i-need-the-book (#15), liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure (#46)
My Review:
First things first – that cover is so good! And now that I’ve read the book, I’m even more in love with it, knowing its significance. I mean, look at it? It’s just a chick, there’s nothing else. But I love its simplicity and the idea in general (I know you're gonna judge my poor choices or something, but I love what I love, get over it ;)

Flipped is not a romance, despite what the book might want you to believe. It’s more of a coming-of-age story about two different kids, with problems and personality of their own. Bryce Loski is a shy teenager, and has hated Juli Baker ever since the first day he saw her when they moved to her neighborhood and she fell for him, or more like his blue eyes. The outgoing, enthusiastic girl that she is, Juli still fails to impress Bryce. But then, Juli starts to realize that Bryce is more than his blue eyes, and Bryce starts to realize that what matters are the matters of the heart.

• Bryce’s pov was really impressive to read. He talks to us like it matters to him how we see things, and it felt refreshing to be included and considered.

• Juli seemed a little too over-enthusiastic and idk, over-the-top in almost everything she does, in her crush on Bryce, her love for the sycamore, her daily actions in general.

• Both of the characters aren’t particularly likeable. But I did like reading Juli’s view on everything. She looks ‘at the big picture’.

• Idk, but Juli’s and Bryce’s family were weird. Like very very weird and unrealistic.

• Like, take Juli’s brother for an instance – owning a boa constrictor? Isn’t that illegal or something? Also, Bryce’s dad was a dick and Bryce himself was a coward. But I loved Juli’s dad and Bryce’s mom – they were the only sensible people in the book.

• The whole ‘Basket Boy’ thing was really weird and funny and idk, unbelievable. Selling boys and their handsome face for money? It was kinda cruel if you ask me. I mean, if it were ‘Basket Girls’ the whole world would have been chasing the school authorities with pitchforks. But alas, those poor unfortunate boys have nobody to speak up for them.

• The Ending in my opinion was unsatisfactory. True, the author succeeded on giving us a mental picture of how things might go on. But it felt abrupt and scraped off a bark. There wasn’t much of a conclusion, any confrontation of sorts or anything pleasing in general. I wasn’t ready to buy it.

This book is just another coming-of-age book. The characters are unique in the sense that, they’re weird and don’t try hard to be relatable or anything. But the message as a whole was promising and hopeful. I wish I could’ve read this as a child. Definitely something I’d buy my kids though. It’s got a lot to teach young kids. Recommended.

Title: I'll Give You the Sun
Author: Jandy Nelson
Bookshelves: 50-states-challenge, contemporary, family, liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure, made-me-cry, really-liked-it, romance-lovey-dovey, lgbt, writing-to-die-for, young-adult
Bookshelves with positions: 50-states-challenge (#10), contemporary (#67), family (#10), liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure (#45), made-me-cry (#39), really-liked-it (#93), romance-lovey-dovey (#111), lgbt (#10), writing-to-die-for (#12), young-adult (#158)
My Review:
It so rarely happens that you stick to a book you are sure you’ll end up hating anyway, only to discover that it has been one of the best you’ve read in a while. Most of my favorite books started out as almost-DNFed ones. While this book won’t be categorized as a favorite, it was profound, evocative and moving in a way I’ve never imagined possible. If I happen to reread this book, and I will, I’m sure I will soak up the words and let it flow through me because I’d be aware that this book is an artful masterpiece.

The Plot

Noah and Jude.

Jude and Noah.

They were born together, bound together with more than blood. They are the Sweetwine twins.

But they couldn’t have been less similar.

Noah is an artist, gay, and shy. Fearing the homophobic world, he’s struggling to find his place in the world, to express his over-imaginative mind, and he does it in the only way he knows – through his art. Having had his dreams shattered, and bearing the terrible secret of his family’s destruction, Noah gives up art, and pretends to be everything he is not.

Jude on the other hand, overwhelmed by guilt and shame, shrinks into herself, loses her former outgoing nature and tries to do what she has always tried to do – impress their mother and convince her that she’s as good an artist as Noah.

The lies were convincing.

But can they be true to themselves?


The plot was non-existent for the first half, but the second half was worth it. Everything comes together, and while things were predictable, it still amazed me. It’s brilliantly crafted and the execution is spot on. The story makes sense, the writing makes sense, everything makes sense by the end.

Now, here’s an overview of what will happen when you read this book –

- You’ll start reading and immediately start procrastinating because it’s boring.
- You start to realize that you’ve no idea what you’re reading.
- You have to look up metaphor in the dictionary.
- You’ll be aware that the characters are all too over-dramatic and too teenager-ey for your taste.
- You’ll forget that ‘twin-thing’ ever existed.
- You’ll realize that your fights with your siblings are mere pinpricks compared to what you’re reading.
- Halfway through the book, you realize that there actually is a plot!!
- And then you realize you can’t stop reading.
- You get a newfound love for art.
- You get wide-eyed at places and see stars and colors and glitter.
- And you cry and you cry and you cry.
- You marvel at how the story is an intricate pattern of woven words and how brilliantly the story is crafted.
- You realize you need to reread this book asap to soak in its beauty.


I’m telling you, getting through this book is no small job. Jandy Nelson’s writing is an artwork. Sometimes you’ll stare at it for a long time without comprehending anything at all. Sometimes you stare at it and feel like you’re floating through the universe, passing through the Milky Way, with comets and meteors and glittering stars scattered in the sky like a cake frosted with confetti and sprinkles, just like artworks that speak to you. It’s difficult to read and know what’s happening sometimes due to the metaphorical talks, and sometimes you just wonder how she managed to weave sentences where the words are delicate pieces of puzzle falling rightly into place. The writing was quite annoying in the beginning, and only later did I realize its whole purpose and how it actually compliments the character’s behavior.

As for the characters, let me tell you – the twins you’re going to encounter is no ordinary twins. They are basically personified metaphors. They’re too pretentious and over-dramatic, make all the wrong choices, regret all the said choices, and still live like there’s no tomorrow. Noah’s pov was annoying to read. He was obsessed over Brian; he exaggerates and overly analyses everything he sees. And according to him, everything that happens in the world has something to do with him. I felt he was selfish at times. Frankly though, I loved Noah better when I was reading Jude’s point of view. In fact, I liked everything better while reading Jude’s pov. But Noah’s pov, even though annoying and confusing at times, was actually an accurate portrayal of an artistic mind. I loved Jude for all the mistakes and guilt and shame she carried on her back. I loved reading her thoughts. It was relatable and funny at times. And needless to say, Guillermo Garcia is probably my favorite person right now. Also, there is so much focus on art in this book and IT IS DONE SO SOO WELL. Seriously, Noah’s pov tells you a lot about an artist’s mind and the paintings and sculptures and everything else are described so artistically, it’s imaginative and inspiring. Clearly, Jandy Nelson knows her art. Oscar Ralph, on the other hand, was an unflattering character. There’s basically zero characteristic traits to him, except that he’s a womanizer who had a bad past and has suffered quite a lot. I didn’t enjoy his presence, and I sure af didn’t swoon over the romance. And also, Brian. He was basically a manic-pixie-dream boy and I had no sympathy for him So simply put, the characters are all merely plot devices.

As for the relationships, it was so freaking fantastic to see Noah and Jude’s relationship develop from hatred, to sympathy, to love and something much more. They make me believe in second chances and rainbows and unicorns and the magic power of forgiveness and love. They have such an awesome chemistry, you guys!! Even if they spoke barely a word to each other. I hated their parents though, both of them were stinking and reeking of stereotypes and they treated their children like they bought them off the market on sale. It was frustrating.

One of the best relationships that developed here was the one between Jude and Garcia. They’re adorable together, and they share a lovely bond, I can only understand but not explain. It’s LOVELY. Other than that, the romance help zero appeal to me, because – lack of development. It was like, you meet this guy, you see his eyes, fall in love, and decide you’re soul mates. Crap. I don’t buy it. And it’s impossible to believe that Brian comes back after two years, and gets back with Noah just like that. Nope.

Overall, as difficult as it was, to really get into this book, IT WAS ABSOUTELY WORTH IT IN THE END. I can really see the reason for hype and it was justified in every ways. Even though the characters and story were a bit unrealistic, it was enjoyable and thought-provoking and brilliantly crafted. I’d definitely recommend it if you’re interested in contemporary stories with a bit of a magical-touch.

Title: See If I Care
Author: Judi Curtin
Bookshelves: 50-states-challenge, books-for-children, contemporary, family, i-need-the-book, loved-the-protagonist, made-me-lol, really-liked-it, school-boarding-genres, why-no-hype
Bookshelves with positions: 50-states-challenge (#4), books-for-children (#55), contemporary (#66), family (#9), i-need-the-book (#14), loved-the-protagonist (#33), made-me-lol (#31), really-liked-it (#92), school-boarding-genres (#42), why-no-hype (#17)
My Review:
I don’t understand why children’s books like this one are not more widely read or don’t receive the attention they deserve. That being said, this book reminded me of You’ve Got Mail.

Two teachers from two different countries, who happen to be friends, decide to start a pen-pal trend among their students to make them realize the worth of letters. That’s how eleven-year-olds Luke Mitchell and Elma Davey start writing letters to each other all the way from Ireland to England. At first, it was all lies and made-up stuff. Stories they told each other of how their lives were perfect, stories they said to themselves to make them feel better about their own harsh realities. Until they realize that their lives are pretty similar - that they have no one else to confide to - other than each other.

I really loved the concept of the book and adored how the authors brought the book to life. Luke and Elma seem like real persons with real problems. They are eleven year olds, true. But they feel like real living persons trying to pretend their life is better than what it actually is.

It was refreshing to see them bond through the letters, even if they were lies. The way they made a little ritual of sticking their stamps upside-down just to see if the other would notice, how they sent Christmas cards they didn’t actually mean to send, and how they help each other and bring about big changes in their lives. Elma’s Dad gets better with Luke’s suggestion to sign him up for a quiz . It was adorable and heart-warming – made me smile all along.

I really loved Luke’s character; he seemed way too old for someone his age. That guy works each day and weekends, earns 50 euros every week, and buys his mom a washing machine for Christmas! Way to go boy! Elma had her share of problems too, but I wasn’t very impressed with her way of dealing with them. And in the end, she felt a bit arrogant, walking away with her problems solved when Luke really could have used some help.

Unlike You’ve Got Mail, this book isn’t about unions and happy endings. In the end, Luke and Elma are just pen pals, both from different countries, both with their share of problems, both trying to get through with life. And that’s what makes it even more realistic and good. I was satisfied, to say the least.

This book isn’t another romance where penpals meet in real life and stick together life-long. This is simply a story of two kids striving with their lives. You just need something like this when you think your life is hard. It reminds you that no matter how bad your problems are, there are people who are having it worse. It’s simple, humble and yet hopeful.

Title: The Avery Shaw Experiment (Science Squad, #1)
Author: Kelly Oram
Bookshelves: books-in-series, chick-lit, contemporary, drama-overloaded, liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure, romance-lovey-dovey, school-boarding-genres, young-adult, 50-states-challenge
Bookshelves with positions: books-in-series (#80), chick-lit (#56), contemporary (#61), drama-overloaded (#25), liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure (#41), romance-lovey-dovey (#105), school-boarding-genres (#38), young-adult (#150), 50-states-challenge (#9)
My Review:
Okay, so this wasn’t exactly bad or cheesy as I’d expected. Some things rather bugged me incessantly, but in the end, I knew I’d kinda enjoyed it.

Avery Shaw is heartbroken. Her best friend since childhood – Aiden Kennedy – turned down her feelings. Sweet, naïve, plain little Avery Shaw couldn’t handle it well. To get over herself, she accepts the help of Grayson Kennedy, Aiden’s big brother, who suddenly can’t seem to take his eyes off Avery. Bonding through a science experiment meant to mend Avery’s broken heart, the two realize how they’d fallen for each other, which in turn, makes for a successful science project.


• For the record, I don’t even understand why Avery was heartbroken in the first place.
• Because SHE WASN’T EVEN IN LOVE WITH AIDEN.
• They weren’t even together.
• Avery should take up crying and blushing as her occupation.
• That’s all she ever does.
• But I thought she was cute.
• And I hated her love life. HATED.
• She had to kiss two brothers to realize one was a better kisser than the other.
• So she went after him.
• You can guess what happens; the other brother is left hopelessly dangling after her.
• Idk, I just hate the idea of siblings dating the same person, or someone dating a person they know their sibling is pining for.
• That’s an unhealthy family right there.
• Umm, can we also say that the whole science element was unbelievable?
• Because who knew, heartbreaks made for an award-winning science project?
• Also, Grayson and Libby made me want to punch them in the face a few times with their sexist comments.
• I mean, Grayson looks at Avery like she’s something to eat.
• Also Aiden was a dick most of the time, but at least he got around well in the last instead of moping.
• EVERYTHING IN THIS BOOK WAS WAY TOO PREDICTABLE.
• Also, I loved that this book showed us how important it is to bring up our kids in the right way, how harmful it can be to force kids into each other’s company.

In the end, it was a cute contemporary and for once I did enjoy the romantic element in it. Go for it without a critical mind and I’m pretty sure you’ll end up liking it well enough.

Title: Fire with Fire (Burn for Burn, #2)
Author: Jenny Han
Publisher: Simon & Schuster Books for Young Readers
Bookshelves: books-in-series, characters-that-hold-my-heart, contemporary, e-n-d-i-n-g, i-need-a-movie, horror-paranormal, made-me-cry, made-me-lol, really-liked-it, romance-lovey-dovey, school-boarding-genres, suspense-thriller-mystery, young-adult, why-no-hype, 50-states-challenge
Bookshelves with positions: books-in-series (#82), characters-that-hold-my-heart (#23), contemporary (#63), e-n-d-i-n-g (#7), i-need-a-movie (#20), horror-paranormal (#68), made-me-cry (#37), made-me-lol (#28), really-liked-it (#90), romance-lovey-dovey (#106), school-boarding-genres (#40), suspense-thriller-mystery (#37), young-adult (#153), why-no-hype (#16), 50-states-challenge (#8)
My Review:
This was freaking AMAZEBALLS. Like, heck, I found a new favorite character – that itself is surprising. I’m not much of a character driven reader as a plot-driven one, but WOW THIS BOOK HAD THEM BOTH.

Picking up a week later after the events in Burn for Burn, we see the trio – Kat, Lillia, Mary – are still hanging out with each other (which gives me all the feels!), unbeknownst to Lillia’s popular gang of friends. To rid Mary off her grief and heartbreak, they decide that Reeve needs to get avenged with heartbreak similar to hers, and Lillia is up for the job. The series of events that occur is something they could’ve never imagined.

❇ THE PLOT

I was worried that there wasn’t going to be anything to keep the plot going after everything that went down in the last book, but no! This is just as interesting, and emotional, and dwells so much on character development. And the plot twist was mind-blowing, even if most things were predictable up to that point. And even though, not everything was resolved in the end of this book, it was a huge cliffhanger which builds up so much potential for the next book to dwell on.


❇ THE CHARACTERS and WRITING

The book is narrated through three povs – Kat, Lillia and Mary’s. I have to say this, even though the book is written by two people, it doesn’t feel like it at all. You can try all you want, but you can’t distinguish the lines between Han and Vivian, and it truly makes it all the more amazing. Also, the authors have succeeded in giving the three protagonists distinct voices that you have no difficulty in placing them whatsoever, its exceptional. Like, my edition of this book had the chapter titles missing, and still, I could easily identify who was narrating, just by the first sentence. Now, let me put it there fair and square –

KAT DeBRASSIO IS MY NEW FAVORITE CHARACTER. Totally. I love her bratty nature, her loyalty, her tendency to hide her grief, just about everything about that girl.
Also, Lillia Cho annoyed me a bit with her arrogant nature here. I mean she’s super rich, but in the first book, she’s sorta generous about it, but here she’s all showing off and spoilt.
As for Mary Zane, I didn’t like her enough in the first book either. I knew she was gonna get creepy by the end. And her non-stop pining over Reeve was absolutely unbelievable, I wanted to slap her. The side characters, Rennie, Reeve, Alex, Nadia – everyone’s so developed and have so much though put on them, it’s astonishing.

So, the point is, these characters feel so real and believable. I don’t know how they come up with such detailed characters.


❇ THE ENDING

It was abrupt and jaw-dropping and nerve-wracking and everything that stands for thrilling and exciting. It was a freaking roller coaster. Even though not everything is resolved in this book, the way the girls bond gives us friendship goals and the ending hints that it might all fall apart. I don’t know what to think about it, but I sure as hell jumped right into the next book after that. And the hint of paranormal and supernatural elements was creepy, and I don’t really want them there, but the authors make it sound so realistic, I think they can pull it off.


So, just what are you waiting for? Grab your copy of [b:Burn for Burn|13406425|Burn for Burn (Burn for Burn, #1)|Jenny Han|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1332791803s/13406425.jpg|15571673] next weekend and start the trilogy. It sure as hell is not going to disappoint and I wish with all my might that the next book would be even better :)


---------------------

I swear, Jenny Han is a witch, controlling my emotions. I've yet to read a book by her that didn't make me bawl like a streetdog.

Title: The Libby Garrett Intervention (Science Squad, #2)
Author: Kelly Oram
Bookshelves: books-in-series, chick-lit, contemporary, could-have-been-better, family, i-didnt-get-the-point, liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure, made-me-lol, romance-lovey-dovey, school-boarding-genres, young-adult, 50-states-challenge
Bookshelves with positions: books-in-series (#83), chick-lit (#57), contemporary (#64), could-have-been-better (#29), family (#6), i-didnt-get-the-point (#42), liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure (#43), made-me-lol (#29), romance-lovey-dovey (#107), school-boarding-genres (#41), young-adult (#154), 50-states-challenge (#6)
My Review:
It was good to see the Science Squad back, but there was no real plot. While [b:The Avery Shaw Experiment|17660979|The Avery Shaw Experiment (Science Squad, #1)|Kelly Oram|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1363678578s/17660979.jpg|24651100] was well-planned and executed, this one felt like an unnecessary addition. There was absolutely zero science involved, except for some unpronounceable scientific terms used as curses whose meaning no one knows and no one might even bother to find out. The only thing I loved was how real Adam’s character felt, and the skateboarding thing was also a very nice addition. Libby’s parents are unbelievable with their openness, Libby herself felt more like a slut, and the way this book addressed issue of body-weight and addiction was commendable. But the intervention thing? Don’t even bother. That was a ruse for the romantic development between Adam and Libby. I rather did not like how the book addressed science nerds and geeks to be socially inept and their tastes to bizarre and unlikeable, but I did appreciate Libby’s eclectic tastes.

THE BEST PART OF THIS BOOK? The sibling relationship between Adam and Kate. That has to be one of the best siblings I’ve come across in fiction. It felt so real and it was so heart-touching. Absolutely loved how they treated each other, teased and loved and cared and annoyed the hell outta each other.

All in all, this was a more adult version of TASE, with more focus on the sex. There isn’t much to write, really, because the plot was utterly predictable and substance-less.

Title: Ashes to Ashes (Burn for Burn, #3)
Author: Jenny Han
Publisher: Simon & Schuster Books for Young Readers
Bookshelves: 50-states-challenge, books-in-series, characters-that-hold-my-heart, contemporary, could-have-been-better, drama-overloaded, family, i-didnt-get-the-point, liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure, loved-the-protagonist, made-me-lol, romance-lovey-dovey, spiralling-downward, young-adult
Bookshelves with positions: 50-states-challenge (#2), books-in-series (#84), characters-that-hold-my-heart (#24), contemporary (#65), could-have-been-better (#30), drama-overloaded (#26), family (#7), i-didnt-get-the-point (#43), liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure (#44), loved-the-protagonist (#32), made-me-lol (#30), romance-lovey-dovey (#108), spiralling-downward (#10), young-adult (#155)
My Review:
Well, that was a freaking Indian soap opera. You know it’s crazy and unrealistic as hell, and yet, you find it hard to take your eyes off the screen – in this case, page. I expected a lot better ending from the authors who write some of the best realistic fiction I’ve known, but looks like they went a bit overboard with the supernatural plot.

Taking off after that unexpected twist in Fire with fire, the book moves right into action – the sizzling Tabatsky-Cho romance, Kat’s awesomeness and along with that, Mary turns maliciously crazy with her plan to avenge Reeve. This time, she’s against two of her best friends. And they’d have to do anything it takes to stop her.

• THE PLOT

Romancing your best friend’s crush, a dead spirit seeking revenge – only seen by two people, them trying to ward off the spirit. Like I said, THE PLOT WAS EVERTYTHING LIKE AN INDIAN SOAP OPERA. It was cringe-worthy, but at the same time, the writing was super good and thrilling and you just cannot take your eyes off the page. Only these two authors could’ve executed such a crappy plot so freaking well.


• THE CHARACTERS

✴ Lillia Cho - Her transformation from the loving, generous Asian girl to an arrogant, selfish girl was noteworthy. I still liked her, because her heart was in the right place, and she just couldn’t have NOT done what she did. But really, the authors didn’t have to make her a rich arrogant, spoilt brat. She was really fine in the first book.

✴ Kat DeBrassio - Still my favorite. I love her intelligent nature, brassy attitude, her loyalty, her love for her family, everything about her.

✴ Mary Zane - She is barely recognizable from how she was in the first two books. Typical cliché character degradation – from loving, sweet and innocent girl to evil, malicious girl. But there was some kind of hilarity and immaturity to her behavior that I felt was very Mary-like.

✴ Reeve Tabatsky - As evil and bad he might have been, my heart went out for this guy. He had to suffer a lot more than he deserved. From losing his future and his best friend – to being driven crazy by supernatural forces and having his heart broken – I’d say he didn’t deserve any of it. True, his attitude towards Elizabeth had been bratty, but he couldn’t have known that she’d kill herself. And he regretted it his whole life. And besides, he was the only guy who didn’t get a good ending.

✴ Alex - He felt like a plot-fueler, a sidekick only meant to fuel up the plot. I didn’t like his character much, there wasn’t much development, and he was annoying sometimes with his obsession towards Lillia Cho.


• THE RELATIONSHIPS

✴ Needless to say, I was totally aboard the Tabatsky-Cho ship. It was so very well developed; there was some real chemistry between them, even if I did feel that they were totally not matched as couples.

✴ The friendship between Kat and Lillia was really lovable and felt very real. I loved how they were there for each other throughout, and how understanding and supportive Kat was with Lillia’s decision to date Reeve. A solid friendship, even without Mary.

✴ The family of DeBrassios felt very real. Even though Kat’s brother Pat, was a dick when it came to being a big brother, their family and the bond they shared melted my heart, and seeing Kat torn between her family and her dream of Oberlin was EVERYTHING.


• THE ENDING

✴ The Climax. Whoa, really? Such stupid crap? It was rushed and there was no much talking and understanding, it was just wrapped up in a thrilling, nice, very convenient way. DISAPPOINTED IS AN UNDERSTATEMENT.

✴ But I loved how the themes of suicide and self-harm were addressed, . though really, it could have been given more importance than just being a plot-twist.

✴ The epilogue was AWFUL. How could Lillia be with someone whom she never ever had feelings for? And how could she even leave Reeve when they loved each other like crazy? I didn’t see WHY they had to be separated. It’s not like Rennie or Mary was alive or anything. There was no reason, it was like they were together and so in love one day and not together anymore the next. But the most awful of all was Lillia going with Alex. As much as that guy loved Lillia his whole life, THERE WAS ZERO CEMISTRY, ABSOLUTELY NO DEVELOPMENT, MUCH LESS ANY REAL FEELINGS BETWEEN THEM. Also, I could see how Reeve and Kat could’ve been a thing, their attitudes totally match. But the authors just had to break our hearts and leave poor Reeve alone and heartbroken -_-


As much as I hated how the whole trilogy wrapped up I did have a really good time reading it, I actually enjoyed the excited chill in my spine throughout the book. I have always loved and adored [a:Jenny Han|151371|Jenny Han|https://images.gr-assets.com/authors/1492645464p2/151371.jpg] and her books, and I’m willing to try more of [a:Siobhan Vivian|800187|Siobhan Vivian|https://images.gr-assets.com/authors/1447441386p2/800187.jpg] now – these authors have some serious writing skill. This book and the ending does no justice to the previous two books, and I really wish it had ended some other way. But what’s done is done and was done very well.
2.5/5 stars
