Title: The Elite (The Selection, #2)
Author: Kiera Cass
Bookshelves: chick-lit, liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure, loved-the-protagonist, read-always-one-author-challenge, romance-lovey-dovey, young-adult, books-in-series
Bookshelves with positions: chick-lit (#39), liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure (#17), loved-the-protagonist (#19), read-always-one-author-challenge (#1), romance-lovey-dovey (#55), young-adult (#94), books-in-series (#51)
My Review:
"LOVE IS A BEAUTIFUL FEAR"


A fine sequel to a not-so-fine start of a series that was [b:The Selection|10507293|The Selection (The Selection, #1)|Kiera Cass|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1322103400s/10507293.jpg|15413183]. I liked this one better and I’m more curious to read the next book than I had been when I finished the first one. Though that might be because I ventured into this with no expectations at all. And that technique worked. *applaudes self*

PLOT

America Singer, one of the six girls left in The Selection, and the only one of caste five, is not sure if she is ready to pursue the crown. She has to decide between her long-time sweetheart Aspen, and Prince Maxon, who has made it clear that she is his only choice. But obliging to America’s request of needing time, Maxon decides to extend the selection and give other girls a chance.

On the day of her presentation of philanthropy project report, America speaks against the need to abandon the caste system. The report is cut short, the king is furious and rebels break out. America must finally choose – going home to the life she has always known, or stay at the palace and try to reform the country.

MY THOUGHTS

□ It was good to see some action finally, but still I hated the fact that we didn’t get to witness it. Everything that goes on with the rebels is narrated third-person, and that strips us of the satisfaction of actually being there while it happens.

□ I had many issues with America Singer. The author’s desperate attempts at making us love her is one of the main reasons I don’t feel like it. Otherwise, she is fairly lovable. But her modesty and cluelessness regarding herself, is frustrating. The love triangle is interesting, but there needs to be boundaries. In one chapter she’s all sure about Maxon, and in the very next, Aspen’s words melts her to puddle.

It was also annoying to wait her out, while she makes up her mind on whether she’s suitable for the crown or not.

□ I feel the whole story, THE WHOLE OF IT, from book 1 to book 5, could have been a single book. It is just a simple story, which is dragged out so much; it makes me want to scream. How long do I have to wait till she just takes up the crown and becomes the princess? (Because obviously, she is going to be the One duh) It’s pure torture -_-

□ Maxon. He’s the best thing to happen to this book. I really feel America doesn’t deserve such a gentleman. No, he’s not willing to throw his position as a prince and rebel against the republic, but he is still willing to bring a change once he is beyond his father’s grasp. And I totally agree with him being with the other girls, because AMERICA is one selfish girl. She wants Maxon all for herself, but she also wants Aspen and his familiar warmth. But when Maxon goes out with another girl, she becomes green with envy. FOR GOD’S SAKE, MAXON IS WAITING FOR HER!! IT’S NOT LIKE SHE HAS NO CHOICE. HE IS JUST WAITING, TO MAKE SURE SHE TOTALLY AGREES. BUT SHE BEING THE DAMNED GIRL SHE IS, IS NOT READY TO TAKE THE CROWN! I mean what the hell?? If you think you can’t be the princess, just get the hell out of the palace without sulking around wasting other people’s precious time. THIS GIRL IS SO ANNOYING AND SO NOT-ANNOYING AT THE SAME TIME. DAMN -_-

All said, I would definitely like to read the next book, just because it is comforting and frustrating to read about America’s turmoil. And be as it may, I think we’re both similar in some ways which is probably why I have such contrasting feeling towards her. AND I LOVE TO WORK UP MY EMOTIONS TIME AND AGAIN SO THERE.

Title: The Anxiety Code: Deciphering the Purposes of Neurotic Anxiety
Author: Roger Di Pietro

Title: The Crown (The Selection, #5)
Author: Kiera Cass
Bookshelves: chick-lit, i-didnt-get-the-point, romance-lovey-dovey, young-adult, read-always-one-author-challenge, books-in-series
Bookshelves with positions: chick-lit (#44), i-didnt-get-the-point (#21), romance-lovey-dovey (#61), young-adult (#102), read-always-one-author-challenge (#8), books-in-series (#59)
My Review:
It has happened people. For once, Kiera Cass has her MC end up with a character I (and most probably everyone else) didn’t root for. For once, her happily-ever-after is disappointing. For once, she thought she could write a book without much thought and that her readers would buy it – no offense there Kiera Cass, I’m still your fan. But this book? It was a clear NO for me .

PLOT
Eadlyn Schreave has made up her mind to have a husband by the end of her selection – only she isn’t sure which guy would be her happily-ever-after.
There is Henri, the Swendish cook, who worships the ground she walks in, and then there is Kile, whom she has known since childhood. Hale never did fail his promise to surprise her every day, and Ean is ready to be a gentleman. But the thing with the heart is that, it never does go in the right direction.
Eadlyn must make sure she can secure her crown, the people’s love and a husband whom she can love and for that, she has to make an impossible choice. Who is going to be The One?

MY THOUGHTS
I never did expect much to happen in this book, and I never expected such disappointment either. The story was way too predictable. I saw the end coming miles away. The writing wasn’t all that good either.

As for Eadlyn Schreave, I have no idea how she became an overnight saint. The character development which was supposed to be gradual seemed to have caught an airbus. Her sudden compassion and change of heart toward the suitors were just too fast. And please, I know Maxon and America are in love - I HAVE READ THREE WHOLE BOOKS ABOUT IT - I DON’T WANT TO BE REMINDED THEY STILL ARE IN LOVE EVERY OTHER CHAPTER!

Also, may I ask where was Ahren, Kaden and Osten or even Aunt May all the time? Because the first person I know would respond to America’s heart attack (besides Maxon) would surely be May. But no, these people, who are important family members, are seen in what, like, one chapter? Or make that one page -.-

So let’s talk about The Selection now. For half the book, I wasn’t even aware it was taking place. The characters felt bland, and undeveloped. And the winner! That is the part which was most disappointing. Even though I wasn’t really rooting for any of the boys, Eadlyn’s choice Erik? was totally predictable and very unwise. And the way Henri reacted to it was, like, WHAT? DID YOU EVEN LOVE HER BOY?? Things were very unrealistic. The so-called romance was non-existent. One thing I liked though, was the thing about Hale and Ean. They’re gay and in love

Let me tell you, I actually wanted a nice, cute memorable ending as in The One, but the ending felt as if the author was rushed to meet a deadline. It was too much, and too soon – the after-effects we don’t even get to see. I don’t know, I just thought it would be better.

VERDICT
I really wished I had stopped at The One, because it was a perfect ending to America’s story. Eadlyn’s story was short of depth and emotion, and in the end, it didn’t work for me.

Title: Fried Green Tomatoes at the Whistle Stop Cafe
Author: Fannie Flagg

Title: Salt to the Sea
Author: Ruta Sepetys
Bookshelves: characters-that-hold-my-heart, favorite-moms, i-need-a-movie, made-me-cry, new-places, historical-fiction, really-liked-it
Bookshelves with positions: characters-that-hold-my-heart (#19), favorite-moms (#2), i-need-a-movie (#18), made-me-cry (#35), new-places (#11), historical-fiction (#18), really-liked-it (#82)
My Review:
I have put this review on and off for some days now, and finally have decided that this book needs reviewing. It’s one of those books which carries a powerful message, wows you with the amount of work put on it by the author, introduces some memorable characters, and yet you find a missing piece in the puzzle.

Salt to The Sea is set in Nazi Germany. Many books have been written during the time, including one of my absolute favorites. But it also brings to light, the sinking of The Wilhem Gustloff which is one of the biggest maritime tragedy in history, and yet I only knew about it through this book. Ruta Sepetys gives us a wider perspective, narrating through four people’s point of view.

Florian is a young guy, who’s exceptional at forgery, carrying with him the weight of a secret. Joana is a nurse, striving to help others recover while struggling to survive herself. Emilia has lost it all, her Dad, Mom, homeland. And now she has only one little hand to hold onto, which she clutches to her heart with all her remaining strength. Alfred, an aspiring German soldier, gaining strength from the mental letters he writes to his beloved back at home, wants to prove himself by working for a cause he feels is RIGHT.
This book is the journey of these four people, how they come together and fall apart, in a world that is crumbling, straying to stay right.

The Writing - though not exceptional by any means, fits the story just right. The narrative was a really clever move by the author in my opinion. Ruta Sepetys succeeds in showing us completely different perspectives of people in war. The innocence, the cruelty, the unfairness of it all, and most of all THE HUMANITY still left in this world.

The CHARACTERS - The character buildup is brilliant. Such complexity, such background. How all of them came together in this story is what I loved the most. But even though, I love them so much, the characters were still one-dimensional. It was like watching them through a looking glass. We don’t really form an emotional bond with them. It’s not about the relatability. It’s more like the distance, between us and them. You get me? Sepetys’s characters are intense and complex, but not deep. The emotional development was missing; rather, it was a matter of mind.

A cleverly weaved out story of fictional characters. It’s like Sepetys rehearsed her characters so much and put them out to act on the play, but the characters forgot to be themselves. I hope that makes sense?
Lets explore the characters –

• Florian
“Fear is a hunter.”

My favorite. This reserved, introverted, artistic character had an important role in the book. From his shy, private demeanor to his carefully constructed lies, and caring nature, Florian is the best example of how war ages people prematurely.
At just seventeen, Florian has the heavy weight of a top national secret on his baggage, and has already been on the ‘wanted” board. Plus, the insta-love, which just fell right. The only character I could actually feel for. I wished his story was a little more elaborated though.


• Joana
“Guilt is a hunter.”

Persistence and humanity is displayed simultaneously through this character. Joana grew up with rich parents - practicing medicine - in the land of Lithuania. When war erupts, she is forced to flee to Germany. Overcome by guilt and regret, Joana becomes compelled to save whoever comes her way, treating them, saving lives, as much as she can, in hopes that redemption can wash away the guilt written in her forehead.


• Emilia
Oh yes, quite possibly the best character in this book. Being sent away by parents who were concerned for her safety was one thing, but being sent away again from fake parents was a heartbreak. Enduring too much shame and sadness in her 16 years of life, than we would ever experience in a lifetime, Emilia is the epitome of goodness, sacrifice and strength in a weak body. Yes, her story was heartbreaking.


• Alfred
Every tale needs an antihero. But Alfred is not quite that. Through Alfred’s story, Sepetys shows us a complete different side of the war. Supporting Hitler and his ideologies with his own twisted righteousness, Alfred is going to make you think. Not all villains tried to be villainy. Some just became that way on the journey to become a hero.


The supporting characters were also very well developed and significant to the story. And it is also one of those rare books where you don’t get overwhelmed by the number of characters and their stories, because each of them is unique.


This book is definitely one of the best works of fiction dealing with Nazi Germany and the effects of War. The research work by the author is praiseworthy. The characters may as well have been real. If not for the feeling that the author forgot to let her characters live their own life, it would have been a five-star read.

Title: How I Live Now
Author: Meg Rosoff
Bookshelves: could-have-been-better, historical-fiction, i-didnt-get-the-point, not-really-my-thing, audiobooks, adapted-to-tv-movie, young-adult, over-hyped
Bookshelves with positions: could-have-been-better (#21), historical-fiction (#17), i-didnt-get-the-point (#35), not-really-my-thing (#5), audiobooks (#3), adapted-to-tv-movie (#14), young-adult (#135), over-hyped (#15)
My Review:
This book is supposedly about war and survival, but throughout the book, I wasn’t sure I found what I was looking for. With an utterly boring plot and undeveloped characters, How I Live Now makes you wonder bleakly about how you actually are living while reading the book – lifelessly. I sure as hell didn’t expect much from the book, and even without the added burden, this book somehow managed to disappoint the hell outta me.

Well, for starters, Elizabeth – Daisy – who is the narrator, goes to live with her aunt and cousins whom she had never ever seen before, all the way across to England. Life with them was going really well for her, with the added drama of romance with Edmund, one of her dreamy-eyed cousins. The act of incest is well received by her other cousins. Unfortunately, a war erupts in London, which in turn affects their whole life.

• The characters had zero potential, no personality.
• The narrative was too dragged and there were literally no conversations, dialogues.
• THAT, I realize, is something I can’t live without in books.
• It was indicated many times that Daisy’s cousins had some sort of mental power, but no explanations or descriptions were made.
• Again, Daisy has to be the most boring character I’ve ever had the unfortunate fate to meet in fiction.
• This book was written with war in mind.
• Because nothing else happens, other than the constant mention of war in the background.
• The gruesome detailing of broken limbs and detached arms were added for pity’s sake I guess.
• The narrator of the audiobook expressed exactly ZERO emotions.

• It goes without saying that I felt exactly the same way throughout the book. -_-

I can’t go on in my life speaking of this nonsense book. One of those literal ‘masterpieces’ I am not going to lay my eyes on, ever again.

P.S I hear it has won a Michael Printz Honor.

God bless me and my reading tastes.

Title: True Letters from a Fictional Life
Author: Kenneth Logan

Title: Simon vs. the Homo Sapiens Agenda (Simonverse, #1)
Author: Becky Albertalli
Bookshelves: characters-that-hold-my-heart, contemporary, adapted-to-tv-movie, young-adult, romance-lovey-dovey, really-liked-it, over-hyped, made-me-lol, lgbt
Bookshelves with positions: characters-that-hold-my-heart (#18), contemporary (#49), adapted-to-tv-movie (#13), young-adult (#134), romance-lovey-dovey (#94), really-liked-it (#81), over-hyped (#14), made-me-lol (#21), lgbt (#6)
My Review:
Everything to be said about this book has been said, everyone to read this book has enough reasons not to read it OR pick it up next. If you ask me, this book was very similar to [b:Will Grayson, Will Grayson|6567017|Will Grayson, Will Grayson (Will Grayson, Will Grayson, #1)|John Green|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1368393890s/6567017.jpg|6759965] in terms of plot, but the characters here were much better and developed, and less self-centered, so yeah that earns it an extra star.

PLOT

It is no secret to us that Simon Spier is gay, but to Simon, coming out is the most difficult thing to do. The only one who knows that about him has no idea who he is. Blue is a guy Simon is in constant emailing terms with, a boy who is gay himself, and goes to the same school, lives in the same town as him. Only, both of their identities are anonymous by virtue of fake names and internet.



UNTIL, another guy discovers it. Simon’s secret is out when Martin chances upon his open inbox, and Martin takes the chance to blackmail him into getting him a chance with Abby, one of Simon’s best friends. Torn between setting up a stupid guy for his popular friend, and the horror of his sexuality coming out, Simon has a lot of things weighing him down. Add to it, the pressure of his parents’ ‘big deals’, his friends being upset with him, and Blue seeming suddenly uninterested, Simon has one hella life.

THOUGHTS

• The prospect of having an anonymous listener to all the rambling of your stupid brain is like, delightful. freaking delightful.
• Blue is awesome.
• Those emails were so damn good and relatable.
• All the references to Harry freaking Potter.

“It’s a dementor robe over my clothes. I think you’ll survive.”
“What’s a dementor?”
I mean, I can’t even. “Nora, you are no longer my sister.”
“So it’s some Harry Potter thing,” she says.

• That has to be the best Harry Potter reference I’ve read in my entire life. Ah. Such satisfaction.
• Also Oreos. Can’t forget the Oreos. I’m dead.
• Is it possible to smile to death?
• The insides of these kids’ brain are literally an expansion of my own.
• And the family, the relationships.
• A FURRY, WOOLY ADORABLY GOOD BALL OF WARMTH AND CUTENESS.
• I know that was cheesy. Just saying.
• ‘who-is-Blue’ guessing never got me anywhere.
• I stopped guessing a long time back.
• Because, Blue was freaking amazing in those emails, I didn’t want to ruin him for me by him showing up in person.
• But damn, he was even more cute, adorable and shy and lovely in person.
• Wait, I can’t seem to get over the fact that this school has like, zero bad kids??
• I mean an effed up tumblr post for three days, and no one gives a damn??!
• That’s so freaking unrealistic.
• Never mind.
• Leah is the fictional version of my bff.
• I’ll have to gift this book to her.
• I can’t really believe how easily and conveniently everything happens to Simon.
• Like, this book is the definition of happiness and goodies don’t get me wrong.
• But I expected a bit more drama, stuff to happen.
• And Abby, Nick and everyone else who makes an appearance in this book, stole my freaking heart.
• The highly appropriate usage timing of FREAKING in this book is impossible.
• It’ll take me some time to get over it.
• That ending was sunshine on my dark eyes.
• Love, Simon.
• Can we please applaud???

Anyway, this was too cute to be true, with little story, highly entertaining characters and a smooth, fun writing style. Almost all the characters felt girlish. The hype is true in sense of characters, but this book, imo, neither does it have much appeal in terms of realism, nor in the terms of mind-blowing-sensations.
Pick it up when you need to feel good. Or gay. Either way, it works.

Title: Life As We Knew It (Last Survivors, #1)
Author: Susan Beth Pfeffer

Title: Women in the Qur'an: An Emancipatory Reading
Author: Asma Lamrabet

Title: Moxie
Author: Jennifer Mathieu
Bookshelves: all-time-favourites, characters-that-hold-my-heart, contemporary, i-need-the-book, loved-the-protagonist, really-liked-it, young-adult, why-no-hype, favorite-moms
Bookshelves with positions: all-time-favourites (#21), characters-that-hold-my-heart (#17), contemporary (#47), i-need-the-book (#10), loved-the-protagonist (#27), really-liked-it (#80), young-adult (#132), why-no-hype (#11), favorite-moms (#1)
My Review:
Before you read on, I confess, I am not much of a feminist. Because, mostly what I hear of feminists’ activities were about woman claiming to be stronger, better than men. This, in my opinion, is not true. And I’m not talking about physical strength. Just that nature has made one gender more powerful than the other. And clearly, in the case of human beings, it’s the male gender. But with power come arrogance and an impulse to dominate over the others. We aren’t weak actually, we the women population. We are strong in our own way. But men always have had the upper hand. And that has led to unequal consideration towards women. This, imo, is WRONG. Just because one nut is harder to crack, doesn’t mean the other nuts are worthless.

Feminism should be about equality,
having a chance to voice your opinions,
and an opportunity to work on them.
Not undermining the opposite sex.

Now, let’s come to this book.

MOXIE SIMPLY MEANS COURAGE.

The story takes place in East Rockport, a small town in Texas, America. The girls at East Rockport High have always been accustomed to the variety of sexist jokes and games the boys come up with. Like, the bump-n-grab game scheduled for Valentine’s Day, the March Madness, which is basically an online poll for boys where they select the most-fuckable-girl of the year. The administration doesn’t find these acts punishable but they always have these dress-code-checks few times a year that applies only for girls.
Having enough of this sexism, and inspired by The Riot Grrrl Movement her mother was actively part of, Vivian decides to start Moxie, a feministic zine, anonymously. At first the response is barely there. But then more and more girls come up, eager to fight for rights they deserve. Fighting with the rock-headed principal and staff is hard, but MOXIE GIRLS MUST FIGHT BACK.

THOUGHTS

This was literally the first page of the book –
For all the teenage women fighting the good fight.
And for my twelfth-grade Current Topics teacher for calling me a feminazi in front of the entire class. You insulted me, but you also sparked my interest in feminism, so really, the joke is on you.
Revenge is best served cold, you jerk.

- I’m in love already.
- The sexism described in this book is awful.
- THAT SORTA STUFF HAPPEN IN AMERICAN SCHOOLS??!
- That’s like, horrifying for non-American girls,
- Because for us, America is this big developed country where women have all the rights.
- Clearly, prejudices are distributed all around the world.
- Girls need to fight back. With Moxie.
- And boi! Did they fight back!
- And the version of feminism in this book is AMAZING.
- I stand by it.
- I pledge myself a FEMINIST.
- This book has got me converted.
- Ooh and the realistic feel of it all.
- Omigod I MIGHT EXPLODE.
- The relationships are sooo well done.
- Not the romance, obviously, it was awkward.
- I loved how awkward it was. It was basically lust, but realistic.
- Like really realistic.
- The characters are super lovable. Very well developed.
- The unease Viv felt over her Mom dating someone.
- Very very well done.
- And the female friendships, the gatherings.
- Uh-uh, I need some Moxie in my life.
- Like some real moxie.
- I have some people to see me all Moxie-like.
- The girls are literally Wonder-woman.
- It couldn’t have ended any better.
- Wait, 400 pages?? WHAT? I read it in a night, it can’t be.
- Well, I need some more.

In the end, I still asked for more. The writing was brilliant and flew by so fast. Most of all, THIS BOOK HAS A STORY TO SHARE THAT SHOULD BE HEARD ALL AROUND THE WORLD.
Please please please read this book. Gift it to your friends, family, mom, dad, sister, stranger, me (okay maybe not, but I wouldn’t mind ;) )

Title: The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn
Author: Mark Twain
Additional Authors: Guy Cardwell, John Seelye, Walter Trier

Title: The Sun and Her Flowers
Author: Rupi Kaur
My Review:
If this was poetry, I am honestly Edgar Allen Poe.

Having read Milk and Honey, I expected Kaur to have improved a bit, to bring up some new stuff into her poems, to be more intense with her emotions. But this book felt like a sad attempt to imitate her previous book. The topics explored weren’t well executed; it felt flat and bland to me.

- The part about immigration felt real. And good.
- The poem about mother’s sacrifice was heartfelt and true.
- Rupi Kaur seems to know what it is to face oppression.
- But feels like she has a hard time explaining it.
- Not. Much. Emotion.
- Or Thoughts.
- Boring.
- Art wasn’t as good as in Milk and Honey.

So, overall, this book just felt like scattered tumblr posts. It has no right to be called poetry. They’re more like verses. And bad ones too. Dive in if you’re still interested.

Title: Love Her Wild
Author: Atticus Poetry
My Review:
Well, combining some cheesy phrases with some form of art (photography, in this case) seems to be the latest trend in poetry. Love Her Wild, is a compilation of short poems, divided into three parts -
Love.
Her.
Wild.

“Love is diving headfirst into someone else’s confusion and finding that it all makes sense.”


And to think this crappy piece was nominated for Goodreads Choice Awards pretty much extinguishes my faith in the so-called people’s choice award for books. Or is it that no one actually writes quality poems anymore? Not that I’m a poetry expert, but still, I believe I have the literal sense to distinguish good from the bad ones.

Following the trend of Rupi Kaur’s infamous poetry style, this book has poems that barely lasts 4 lines, or comprise short paragraphs at times, with no repeated pattern whatsoever. The topic is pretty much the same old Love.

“Love could be labeled poison and we’d drink it anyways.”


~This girl who is the most beautiful one.

~This girl who has no idea she’s the best thing ever.

“The world is made up of too many girls
wondering if they are pretty
and too many boys
too shy to tell them”


~This girl who breaks hearts.

~This girl who has no idea she breaks hearts.

“It’s not the fear of losing them that scares us,
It’s that we have given them many of our pieces
That we fear fear losing ourselves when they are gone."


~This girl who dreams unattainable things.

~This girl who is the centre of the universe.

"She was too busy
wishing on the shooting stars
to see the dreams come true around her"


Blah. Blah. Blah.

I’m not sure if the pieces were original at all. All of the lines felt too familiar to be original. And the accompanying pictures didn’t seem to play any significant role. What the author meant to convey through this book is still alien to me.

Despite everything, it was quick, short read. Yeah it wasn’t mind blowing, and I didn’t expect it to be. Yeah there were some lines I found to be good. But no, if you are a poetry lover, you may want to avoid reading this book. If you are a newbie, well then, no one’s stopping you.

2.5/5 stars

Title: I Kissed A Girl In My Class: 2 Valentine's Day Specials For Boys
Author: A. Gaur
Bookshelves: books-for-children, contemporary, indian-author-books, really-liked-it, romance-lovey-dovey, school-boarding-genres, why-no-hype
Bookshelves with positions: books-for-children (#51), contemporary (#44), indian-author-books (#51), really-liked-it (#79), romance-lovey-dovey (#92), school-boarding-genres (#30), why-no-hype (#10)
My Review:
Have plans for the evening? No? Pick up this book and lie down on the hammock, or your comfort coach, preferably with a mug of hot cocoa. Yeah, that’s an evening well spent.

This book was surprisingly good. Considering the 0 ratings for this book – I must say, it was nostalgic and upfront. It took me back to the thrill of those old school days. I am glad I gave it a try. 3.5 stars

There are two stories in this book. I Kissed A Girl In My Class and Going On 13. Both of the stories are set in middle school and deals with the rather petty issues of middle-schoolers. The innocent worry of a boy on getting his girlfriend pregnant, just because he kissed her; those first crushes and heartbreaks; the tight competition between the toppers; the rather sweet tension between opposite sexes in early high-school; the disappointment when classes are rearranged at the beginning of the year, and such stuffs.

[a:Abhilash Gaur|8984511|Abhilash Gaur|https://s.gr-assets.com/assets/nophoto/user/u_50x66-632230dc9882b4352d753eedf9396530.png] makes sure to let us know that we are meant to become nostalgic, that this book should remind us of our own school days, and all the while he manages to get back into the head of an innocent child himself. He captures all the essence of first love and the bashful, bragging nature of a seemingly intelligent protagonist, the highs and lows of school days, and delivers them with ease.

In short, this book is not going to blow your mind, rather it will let you relive your past childhood and make sure you finish up with a smile on your face. Highly relatable. Especially if you’re an Indian.

Title: As a Man Thinketh
Author: James Allen
My Review:
"As a man thinketh in his heart so is he"

^ That one sentence sums up the whole idea of this book, or rather, an essay.

In As a Man Thinketh, James Allen strongly professes the concept that a man is only as good as his thoughts. While in a sense, it may be true, you could also argue against it. It has a lot of possibilities for an amusing, thought-provoking debate.
Look at this –

●
“A man does not come to the almshouse or the jail by the tyranny of fate or circumstance, but by the pathway of groveling thoughts and base desires. Nor does a pure-minded man fall suddenly into crime by stress of any mere external force; the criminal thought had long been secretly fostered in the heart, and the hour of opportunity revealed its gathered power.”


Unsurprisingly, I was reminded of Jean Val Jean while reading this sentence. Not surprised if you did too. We all have loved that character, who, out of sheer desperation to feed his family, stole a piece of bread and ended up in prison. Theft is a crime, no matter what they say, but feeding your family is not. Bringing up this fictional scenario to point out that Allen is wrong, is not my intention though. I’d rather you think of all the poor people there, who were tried and tested in court, many sentenced to death, because they did something similar, or worse. Does that justification make them any less guilty? No. But does that knowledge lessen your hatred for the said accused? Admit it, it did.

●
"Circumstance does not make the man; it reveals him to himself”


So what does that say about the person’s thoughts? Had he always harbored ill thoughts, thought of stealing, killing, murdering? He might have. Could he have avoided those thoughts if he willed himself hard enough? The answer is NO. Point blank.

However hard we try, a controlled mind always slips, always blends in with its surroundings, because just like a coin with two sides, a mind is composed of bad thoughts as much as the good ones. We may think bad stuff, and will ourselves not to do it. But when we actually do something bad, it is NOT BECAUSE WE HAD THOUGHT OF IT ONCE BEFORE. Of course, it is just what I feel to be true, you may have arguments that I may counter-argue. Still, I STRONGLY BELIEVE THAT THE COMPLETE CONTROL OF ONES’ MIND BY ONES’ SELF, IS NOT POSSIBLE.

●
"A man cannot directly choose his circumstances, but he can choose his thoughts, and so indirectly, yet surely, shape his circumstances”


That, my friends, I whole-heartedly disagree with. You can choose to be good or bad, but you definitely cannot choose to think good thoughts or bad thoughts. Duh. Try it for yourself if you don’t believe me.

●
“Change of diet will not help a man who will not change his thoughts. When a man makes his thoughts pure, he no longer desires impure food.”

I mean, seriously? What someone eats is his own business, you idiot. Even if you eat a snake, or a man for that matter, your body will adjust unless there are other ways for survival. Alright?

●
"The will to do springs from the knowledge that we can do. Doubt and fear are the great enemies of knowledge, and he who encourages them, who does not slay them, thwarts himself at every step."


However impressive the above sentence might be, I can’t think of confining the whole of human behavioral pattern and thoughts to such a simple conclusion. One does not simply NOT DO things because he thinks he can’t. An ordinary human being, being a social creature, considers a lot many more factors rather than the simple ignorant fact that he can’t do what he wants to. I couldn’t vouch enough for how wrong that statement is. Yeah, I have come across such phrases before - “Nothing is impossible”, “You can’t do it if you think you can’t”. And no, I haven’t questioned them before, because they were meant in a motivational context. But reading Allen’s work, where he analyses human mind, and spreads out reasons why we’re all doing it all wrong ‘mentally’, I had to say it.
And I don’t mean to be demotivating. If you are inspired by this work, that’s a good thing, go on with your life. But if you are anything like me, you might be criticizing the book too, and I’m merely contributing my opinions.

●
“ALL that a man achieves and all that he fails to achieve is the direct result of his own thoughts”


Please don’t get me started on this one again. A man simply doesn’t fail because he thought them all wrong. And a man wouldn’t conquer the world with his stupid domineering thoughts.

●
“To desire is to obtain; to aspire is to, achieve.”

You get that? It’s the same thing over and over again. I’m amazed he managed to stretch it out for a full 65 pages. That’s impressive vocabulary skills. Blah.

This one might be the truest thing he said, but it is not a fact at all. It doesn’t work in all situations. Like those physics theories we were forced to learn in high school? Applies to some places but doesn’t run true for the rest.
The strength of the effort is the measure of the result.


All in all, I get that while James Allen tried some old-school motivational lines, (okay, maybe he is the master of those ‘old-school’ motivational lines. This was published in what? 1902?), it didn’t work with me. That might be because I’m unmoved by non-fiction and motivational pieces in general, so you may still want to read this book. And yet, I say, “A man is literally what he thinks, his character being the complete sum of all his thoughts.” - NOT.

Title: Mahashweta
Author: Sudha Murty
My Review:
Sudha Murty knows her audience, and she doesn’t care about them. She bluntly yet bravely shows them what is wrong with their mindsets and in turn makes us question our morals, our innermost trepidations; all the while making the process as simple as possible.

In Mahashweta, we follow Anupama, described to be one of the most beautiful woman one has laid eyes on, fall in love, get married. and her world falling at her feet when she contracts a skin disease Leukoderma, otherwise known as Vitiligo.

Anupama is the daughter of a poor schoolmaster. Anand is a rich doctor. Their match was made in the heavens. But heaven rots to hell for both of them when Anupama discovers her disease. Her rich mother-in-law sends her away to save face, and so does her stepmother. Lost, Anupama heads to Bombay, where she makes a living for herself.

Coming to term with the climax of life, and accepting oneself form a major part of the story, along with moving on from a treacherous past.

THOUGHTS
I have no idea what to think of this book. The message is important and the story is one to behold. Sudha Murty impeccably manages to question yourself and the way of life. The way she has managed to capture the shallow mindset of Indian villagers is new to me. Not many Indian writers try to write out so honestly about their culture and way of life. That is another reason, why this book might appeal more, only to Indian readers. The characters of Anupama and Anand teach us a lesson or two. The character development that takes place within these 150 pages is amazing. And the topic of Vitiligo was handled well, but I do feel, the ‘untold’ story of the rest of the characters should also have been assessed. In the midst of it all, Sudha Murty herself profusely displays her ‘standard’ Indian nature, with the descriptions of beauty and wealth as a domineering aspect of one’s life. Quite hypocritical actually.

Either way, this wasn’t a remarkable book, neither am I going to remember the characters for much long. But this was an important read. I would definitely want to try more of Sudha Murty’s works.

Title: Friends Forever
Author: Danielle Steel
My Review:
This book was not what I expected it to be. It was so much worse. It had a right beginning, a good theme, a meaningful, makes-you-want-to-dig-in-right-away kind of powerful title, but it just doesn't do justice to all of the plus points. I've been thinking of reading Danielle Steele books just to see what all the hype was about. Now I'm not sure I would want to read any of her books ever again.

Don't get me wrong, the book wasn't thaaat bad, but it was just not good. It was in no way realistic, or original. The story lacked the relatability we so badly look for when we read non-fantasy-type stories. Yeah, it's fiction, but I don't think anything as dumb as what happens in the book would happen even in the fictional world.

For starters, five kids Izzie, Gabby, Billy, Sean and Andy meet on the first day of kindergarten, and they grow up together up until they graduate - together? Really, don't kids grow up to have different tastes and personalities? And even weirder, these kids go on to become what they dream of becoming in childhood. Yea, it does happen, but all of them? Everything just happens to this group of friends. Seriously, I have never heard of dumber coincidences. And then, the friendship starts hindering when each of them are killed, one-by-one in different ways - accident, drug dealing, suicide. And what happens to the two who are left together? They make out. Hah! What happened to the years of friendship then?

In the beginning, Izzie was my favorite character, but at the end, the author screwed her up so badly, I wasn't even sure why I liked her in the first place. She sleeps with two of her best friends, Andy and Sean, just because. Thank heavens, the third boy Billy, was committed, or else I guarantee he would also have been laid out.

And they say, Izzie is the most reasonable of the five. Really.? I'd think Gabby was better. She at least had the right mind to stick with one person throughout. That sounds more reasonable that going for a one-night stand with two best friends.

The book did have plus points, it shows accurately how death of someone affects the people close to them. But it's also exaggerated, and unrealistic, predictable halfway through, and does no justice to the title.

I'm so not going to read this ever again. Thank you very much! Ms. Steele, I know you have made enough money, so please start writing realistic books even if it doesn't sell well. We'd appreciate it.

Title: A Quiet Kind of Thunder
Author: Sara  Barnard
My Review:
Earnest in its attempt to capture the mind of a girl with Selective Mutism, and a deaf boy, this book delivers on that aspect but failed with the romance. Though why this is under YA when it clearly categorizes as New Adult is beyond me. It depicts sex and hand-jobs smh

In A Quiet Kind of Thunder, readers get to discover a protagonist and her relatively new disability – which is that she can’t speak at all times. Selective Mutism is what they call it. And there is also Chronic Anxiety.

When Steffi meets Rhys, a deaf boy who is new to her school, she finds it interesting. Her knowledge of BSL, ie, sign language which has long been gathering dust and threatening to fade from memory, comes in handy when communicating with the new boy. Her determination to go to university despite her parents’ protest and the brewing romance between Steffi and Rhys, as well as her relationship with her best friend Tem, are all examined in a realistic and honest way.

My thoughts -

● Many instances prove that Sara Bernard wasn’t really trying to gather attention with her new line of thought for this book. And the fact that she learnt basic sign language proves her dedication to the work which made the book more appealing imo.

● While the book started on a strong note of Selective Mutism and its effects, it was later overridden by excessive romance.

● Tbh, the romance was too fast and too forced and highly uninteresting.

● Neither of the protagonists was appealing enough. Steffi was short-tempered and ill-mannered sometimes. I found myself thinking that even if Steffi could speak, she wouldn’t have made much friends, because she was just plain boring

● That is because; all the time she opens her mouth, it is to speak about her disability and anxiety.

● Trying hard to explain a matter rather than giving us reasons to believe her words would do no good.

● I liked the way Steffi’s Mom wasn’t supportive of her choices. Most of the books always speak of highly supportive, caring moms. Sara Bernard tried to show that Dads could be lovely too, along with the reality of unsupportive not-always-loving Mom.

● The pace of the romance from insta-love to oh-my-he-is-damn-hot to first-kiss and sex was way too fast. There was no communication, no heart-to-heart conversations, nothing. From what I could see, the only driving force in the relationship was lust.

● Though, I am grateful the author decided to bring up the communication matter in the end.

● Tem is the best friend everyone needs.

● And Steffi might be the worst.

In the end, the book might have tackled an uncommon subject without tampering its cores, but the book was just too boring, dull and unexciting that I couldn’t care less for the characters or plot or the supposedly-swoon worthy romance.

2.5/5 stars

Title: Undelivered Letters
Author: J. Alchem
My Review:
A Postman.


Undelivered Letters.


From 20 years ago.

Aron has retired from service for years. But while packing up for their relocation, Sarah and Aron find a bag of his from 20 years ago which contained letters Aron had accidentally forgotten to deliver. The story each of the letters unfurl is revealed with a touch of love and warmth in this novella by J. Alchem.

To be fair, the idea was intriguing. Undelivered letters from years ago, and a man on a journey to deliver them all. How can you miss the possibilities? But alas, the execution didn't match up to the plotline and its brilliance.
The writing felt wrong - it would've suited short stories better. Not that this was a big story; infact, it was barely 100 pages. But it took me so long to get through with it, mostly because the prose was utterly uncompelling and unappealing to me. The narrative and Aron's voice seemed make-believe and forced. Too much sweetness, sugar-coated, to make the readers smile. I am not a big fan of books that try too hard to make you feel and are obvious about it. So, no, I wasn't impressed.

And the stories themselves were meagre at best, nothing imaginative there. I expected something new and creative. Maybe it was my fault for expecting too much (the reviews were such). Anyways, it doesn't matter. J. Alchem is undoubtedly talented and I am willing to read more of his works, but Undelivered Letters, despite it's promise, failed to deliver.

2.5/5 stars

Many Thanks to Priyanka for providing me with a free copy for review.

Title: The Nest
Author: Kenneth Oppel
My Review:
My first audiobook, and this was…. WEIRD

First things first, This book should not be categorized as middle-grade

I don’t see why this book falls under that category. Just because the protagonist is some 10 years old? Huh, How about marking The Book Thief as middle-grade then? The Nest is more of a magical realism story, and I wouldn’t recommend it for kids.

Despite what the cover and title makes you believe, The Nest is not some spooky mystery.

It is told through the pov of Steven. Steven has a sister Nicole and both of them are excited when Mom and Dad brings home a little baby brother, Theo. But Theo is not completely fine, it seems. He has to undergo surgeries for heart problems which make Steve’s parents busy, going in and out of the hospital. One day Steve is stung by a wasp from the nest in their courtyard. That night, Steven dreams of an angelic wasp who promises to replace their ‘faulty’ brother Theo with a new perfect baby boy they’re ‘constructing’ in their nest. Steve dismisses the dream at first, but later on the Queen Wasp’s predictions come true, making him realize it was for real. Realizing he has made faulty promises, Steve is determined to save their baby brother from the wasps.


My first and foremost problem with the book is the plot itself. The author might have had good intentions of showcasing a big brother fighting alone to save his little brother. But the premise and the plotline don’t do much justice. Steven and Nicole lack a child’s innocence and curiosity. The insecurities of children with busy parents are also unreasonably portrayed. The whole climax scene was lengthy and the action felt forced. There were some incidents though like with the knifeman’s phone call which were quite interesting. But the overall story was boring to me. For whatever reasons, this book would not appeal to older audiences. At the same time, the subject is kind of inappropriate for younger audiences too.

Like I said, in one word, weird. Nothing like I have read before, definitely not what I expected. What makes it a 3-star read was the narration of the audiobook by Gibson Frasier. Otherwise, it is safe to skip this book.

Title: To Be Soul, Do Soul: Adventures In Creative Consciousness
Author: Hiro Boga

Title: The Unbecoming of Mara Dyer (Mara Dyer, #1)
Author: Michelle Hodkin
Publisher: Simon  Schuster Books for Young Readers
Bookshelves: young-adult, verging-on-five-stars, suspense-thriller-mystery, romance-lovey-dovey, really-liked-it, magical-realism, loved-the-protagonist, i-need-a-movie, horror-paranormal, contemporary, characters-that-hold-my-heart, books-in-series
Bookshelves with positions: young-adult (#127), verging-on-five-stars (#7), suspense-thriller-mystery (#33), romance-lovey-dovey (#88), really-liked-it (#76), magical-realism (#6), loved-the-protagonist (#26), i-need-a-movie (#16), horror-paranormal (#62), contemporary (#41), characters-that-hold-my-heart (#15), books-in-series (#74)
My Review:
Abandon all hope, ye who enter here.

An unexpected guilty pleasure - a very good one at that. This book was all kinds of goodies – adrenaline and raging hormones, but includes very little kiss or sex, perfect for Twilight fans. But I am NOT a Twilight fan. What intrigued me though, were the creative prose, and the compelling plotline.

THE THING ABOUT MARA DYER is that she survived a fatal accident that killed both of her best friends AND her boyfriend. The only ones she ever had. Unsurprisingly, Mara is diagnosed with Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder, remembering nothing about the incident that traumatized her, all the while seeing weird hallucinations of her dead friends.

Moving to Florida and joining the Croyden Academy was supposed to heal her mind. But there she meets Noah Shaw, and unknowingly make enemies with some students and a teacher. Pieces of the events that led to her friends’ death start occupying her nightmares. Seeing things in mind and seeing them actually happen IS unnerving. Mara has a hard time coping with the revelations of her hallucinations and what it makes her.


This book, while unique on its own, seems to have borrowed bits and pieces from some other books. For instance, the lead couple’s relationship reminded me of Twilight. The plotline itself felt vaguely similar to [b:Belzhar|20821376|Belzhar|Meg Wolitzer|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1395326170s/20821376.jpg|40167214] and [b:Lucid Dream 1|10257738|Lucid Dream 1|Swati Singla|https://s.gr-assets.com/assets/nophoto/book/50x75-a91bf249278a81aabab721ef782c4a74.png|15158023]. What absolutely gripped me was the writing though. At a single glance, it seems simple, but the words are woven to make our read more intense and thrilling. The book is fast-paced; you couldn’t put it down even if you wanted to. Just the suspense makes you want to flip over to the last page and see the ending for yourself.

Pros

✴ Mara Dyer
That’s our protagonist btw. The book is narrated in first person, through Mara’s eyes. The thing is, you don’t really feel like Mara’s telling the story, YOU FEEL LIKE YOU ARE EXPERIENCING THE STORY BY YOURSELF. It was like virtual-reality came true and became real for once. The way Michelle made it happen is a mystery to me, but she somehow does make it work. Being in the character’s head is kinda thrilling and scary too, yeah.

✴ Noah Shaw
Noah is your typical-paranormal-YA boyfriend. I have only so much book-boyfriends but Noah made that list. It’s crazy, I know, because this guy is a sure douchebag. The bad-boy-turns-good-for-love boy. But you know what? Rhett Butler was a douchebag too. But I loved him. I have a long-list of why Noah isn’t the perfect gentleman, it goes like this –

**He is BEAUTIFUL – You may already know why that is bad. Remember Edward Cullen?< *wink*
**He is a too rich – Rich boys in YA are bad, you get me?
**He is a womanizer – Oh, but so was Rhett *wink x 3*
**Because Mara is his – He owns her; he declares so many times.
**He is a control freak – He not just says, he acts his part. He acts like he owns Mara.
**He is never sorry – He used a girl to get back at her brother. He doesn’t bat an eye when she commits suicide. Yeah, yeah I know!


What do I do after learning all of this? Fall for him anyway. (Don’t judge me, I haven’t had a boyfriend ever in my life. Period)

Cons

✴ Jamie whats-his-last-name ?

I don’t get the point of this character. Why was he even there? To act the part of a tragic hero? As if we haven’t had enough of it already. And all he ever did was accuse Noah of being a womanizer. And teach. Well, he was such a good teacher that Mara mastered Spanish in two weeks with his tutoring. And well, what happens? I’m not going to spoil much for you, but it’s irrelevant. He drops dead for the rest of the story.

✴ The Ending

After everything Michelle had put us through, that one was the worst. A big cliffhanger. If I hadn’t already had a copy of the sequel I might have choked on my own tongue then and there iykwim *ahem ahem*


Overall, this book wasn’t what I expected from the title and the cover, there wasn’t as much substance. But the intense pace and writing makes up for it. Give it a try, if you love realistic YA paranormal with swoon-worthy romance interests.

Title: The Evolution of Mara Dyer (Mara Dyer, #2)
Author: Michelle Hodkin
Publisher: Simon  Schuster Books for Young Readers
Bookshelves: books-in-series, characters-that-hold-my-heart, could-have-been-better, drama-overloaded, i-need-a-movie, horror-paranormal, liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure, made-me-lol, made-me-cry, really-liked-it, romance-lovey-dovey, young-adult, suspense-thriller-mystery, e-n-d-i-n-g
Bookshelves with positions: books-in-series (#75), characters-that-hold-my-heart (#16), could-have-been-better (#14), drama-overloaded (#21), i-need-a-movie (#17), horror-paranormal (#63), liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure (#33), made-me-lol (#18), made-me-cry (#33), really-liked-it (#77), romance-lovey-dovey (#89), young-adult (#128), suspense-thriller-mystery (#34), e-n-d-i-n-g (#1)
My Review:
SORRY FOR THE INCOMPREHENSIBLE MESS THAT IS THIS REVIEW. Now read on.

I wonder if it’s possible to know someone through the words they loved.


This book is on the spotlight for all the right reasons. Takes off slow, builds up a steady pace. By the end, it’s un-put-down-able (grammar what?) and takes you on a full-fledged roller coaster of a ride. Spare me some grammar and reviewing tips while I go –
aswdfklj cbdhvcerqub nqwoi kjbfsdak!!!!!



What did Hodkins mean to do with that ending???? Gawd, it was so palpable, it was luminescing off the pages. I don’t want to wait a moment to launch on to the next book. You know that’s the best part of reading a series late, right? Ahh the feelssss…. Lord don’t let my English teacher see this.. ever.

"I wasn’t sure how I would manage staying sane while I was constantly being told that I was crazy."


So, uh, I’ll try to be back on track once more, let’s make this work together.


Mara Dyer is back – to Horizons – a facility for the mentally unstable. Jude, her ex-boyfriend, whom she had killed was alive, or at least Mara thinks so. The only person who believes her is Noah Shaw, her gorgeous boyfriend. They understand each other in a way no one understands them because they share this special kind of ability. It is what labeled Mara as ‘mad’ in front of her parents but it might also be what saves her in the end.

The rights and the wrongs -


- Mara Dyer is so so realistic and believable and perceivable and what not. I would have hated her if she didn’t feel too much like me. Like I WAS HER.

- The Dyer family? Daniel? Too good to be true. Nah. I would crave for a brother like that in vain. NO ONE has a brother like that.

- Noah Shaw? PERFECT. Actually, beyond perfect. He’s IMPOSSIBLE. Unreal.

-Seriously, I can’t fathom up a reason why he is with Mara. There is no reason for him to be. I just don’t get their relationship. She never said or did a thing to please him, never-ever.

- ALWAYS Noah is the listener while Mara narrates. She didn’t give a damn what goes on in his mind. And he never cares enough to elaborate. Uh. That relationship would never work out in real-life.

-But Hodkins writes so well, so I guess that counts for something. The romance isn’t that great though. The couple are.

- Or rather, the people forming the couple.

- Or maybe it’s just the writing.

- She makes you feel insane sometimes, because Mara feels insane too. Hodkin’s brilliant that way.

- She makes you think there is nothing much to happen here.

- And then she stops your heart with THAT ENDING. Abrupt as it was.

- No-ah , I can’t get over that.




Please. I’m starting the next book already.

Title: Girl in the Blue Coat
Author: Monica Hesse
Publisher: Little, Brown Books for Young Readers

Title: Eternal Promise (Between Worlds #3)
Author: Talia Jager
Bookshelves: books-in-series, contemporary, fantasy, hopefully-more-to-come, i-need-a-movie, romance-lovey-dovey, young-adult
Bookshelves with positions: books-in-series (#73), contemporary (#39), fantasy (#30), hopefully-more-to-come (#6), i-need-a-movie (#15), romance-lovey-dovey (#87), young-adult (#125)
My Review:
3.5/5 faery colored stars.

This book wandered way above my expectations. From the first two books, I had expected it to be a quick book with no much development going on, but I was totally wrong. The story took on an exciting turn and the ending makes me want to pick up the sequel right now.

PLOT

We are once again back into the faery realm with Rylie, an Aurorian faery, or speaking in clichés – The Chosen One. Rylie learns more about her world, what it means to be an Aurorian fae, how important she is to their world, and more about the creatures that reside only here. With Kallan by her side, she goes on her quest to defeat the evil Satine and unite the light and dark faery world.


To say the world-building was good would be an understatement. About seventy-five percent of the total world-building and character development in the whole series takes place in this book which is what made it exciting. The romance was not much drawn-out and was perfectly handled. My only misgivings are the kisses. The lead couple kisses so damn many times! It’s embarrassing, gross even. I’m sure Rylie’s lips might look like this for real –


The climax was a bit abrupt though. After all it took to get there, it was disappointing. I got the vibe that the authors aren’t much into writing good action scenes or violence in general. It kind of felt childish to me. In fact the whole story, when you think clearly about it, is pointless and childish, full of loopholes. Otherwise, I thoroughly enjoyed the book. The scenic descriptions were amazing and so were the beautiful fae world. Just the freaking turn the whole story took was impressive, since I never really expected much.

In short, if you’ve come as far as the second book in this series, please do pick this up soon. It is way much better than the other two. I can’t wait to see what happens next. Sayonara!

Title: How to Be a Bawse: A Guide to Conquering Life
Author: Lilly Singh

Title: The Hate U Give (The Hate U Give, #1)
Author: Angie Thomas
Bookshelves: contemporary, could-have-been-better, liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure, mature-stuff, over-hyped, really-liked-it, young-adult
Bookshelves with positions: contemporary (#40), could-have-been-better (#13), liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure (#32), mature-stuff (#21), over-hyped (#12), really-liked-it (#75), young-adult (#126)
My Review:
My first book of the year has left me disappointed

People, drop off on your asses and pick up this book. Run through it already (you wouldnt need help) and tell me what you think about it. Because honestly, every 5-star I see makes me think how and where I read this book wrong. Not that it was bad. If anything, you would emerge out wondering about a whole new dimension of life. BUT. There are some issues this book couldn't get right. Hopefully I can shed some light on them with this review.

THE PLOT (spoiler free)

Starr lives with her family in Garden Heights, a neighborhood of Black people. But she and her brothers go to Williamson, a school predominantly attended by White people. Blending in meant putting on a mask of Williamson-Starr whenever she was at school.

One night, a commotion at a party results in Starr hurrying off with Khalil, a childhood friend of hers, whom she was no longer in touch with. That night, Khalil gets shot by a White Policeman. Reports of Khalil being a gang-member and drug-dealer dominate the news rather than the fact that he was mercilessly killed for no reason. Realizing that she is the only person who can raise her voice, Starr struggles to take out her weapon and use it against the cop, in the fight for justice for Khalil.

I wasn't familiar with the plotline in anyway but the story unfolded in a rather predictive manner. The starting was difficult to get into, but slowly, once we get a grip of the culture, the diversity is refreshing. Still, there were some issues of racism that bothered me throughout the book –

● Black Jesus vs. “Jesus”

I know I have read of Black Jesus a few times before, but only in the context of this book did the significance hit me bad. Jesus is supposed to be the son of God, and for God's sake, they couldn't avoid categorizing him as Black? Seriously? What difference does it make if Jesus was Black or White or Yellow? Would they abandon their faith if Jesus was white for real? What does that show of themselves and their belief? That they believe in God because he belongs to their race? How faithful!

What pissed me off even more is the fact that others never really did consider Jesus as ‘white’. One would argue that, it's because White is the default. But what I can't understand is why they have to color their faith in black and whites just because it's in their skin? Just like beauty lies in the heart, belief comes from heart too. No matter the skin color of Jesus, Christians are supposed to believe in him. They're not free to put him out as Black just for the heck of ‘equality’ or whatever.


● Damn, The. H . Y . P . O . C . R. I . S . Y.

This book is so much about racism, but I still don't get Angie Thomas's idea of it. The Black people think they're ridiculed for their skin color, but they give no thoughts on calling out the white people and ridiculing them for their skin color. And when, Chris, a white boy comes out in support of them and joins the riots, they actually ask him if he is black! What, because he's got a good heart and wanted to stand up for justice?

I could see several such instances where Black people easily accused people of racism, but went on saying shit about the White people because they're WHITE.AND THAT ISN'T BEING A RACIST?! If people want others to treat themselves in a particular way, they should know better than to treat the same others in a way that is any different. While rich White kids are spoilt brats, rich Black kids WORKED HARD TO GET THERE. Cool? NOT COOL.


● The Relationships

To say the good things, the portrayal of a family life was highly relatable, heartwarming and realistic. I love Starr’s family - the realistic sibling relationships, the jealousy, the love, the unity, the little fights and reunions were all showcased VERY WELL.

What I didn't like though, was Starr's relationships outside of family. Especially, the ones at school. I saw no reason one would want to be friends with her. She didn't seem to give a damn about her friends or White boyfriend Chris while they, in fact, treated her better than she deserved. In short, Starr was a bad friend, unlikeable in general. Chris somehow managed to shine in the spotlight, though, and so did Seven, Starr's brother. When I think about it, everyone else in her family was likeable except for Starr. That simple point lessened my sympathy and feelings for this book.


● The Themes

No matter how disappointed I am, I do think that this book is an important piece of literature. Black community is so under-represented in YA literature. I loved that Angie Thomas decided to bring it out with this book. Justice for Black people or minority communities anywhere in the world is a big issue. You don’t get to see YA books that deals with this sort of subjects on a major league. And displaying it so realistically, not going with the usual happily-ever-after was a bold and much-needed move from the author.

For me, that ending said much much more than the whole book ever did.



I would say, despite my 3-star rating, that this book is something everyone must read. THE MESSAGE IT CONVEYS IS TOO POWERFUL TO BE MISSED (Even if it does nothing much to improve our view of Black people).

Title: Meet Cute: Some People Are Destined to Meet
Author: Jennifer L. Armentrout
Additional Authors: Dhonielle Clayton, Katie Cotugno, Jocelyn Davies, Nina LaCour, Emery Lord, Katharine McGee, Kass Morgan, Meredith Russo, Sara Shepard, Nicola Yoon, Ibi Zoboi, Julie   Murphy

Title: The Final Year Project
Author: Mehana Usha Rani
Bookshelves: contemporary, i-need-a-movie, indian-author-books, really-liked-it, review-copies, romance-lovey-dovey, school-boarding-genres, young-adult, why-no-hype
Bookshelves with positions: contemporary (#38), i-need-a-movie (#14), indian-author-books (#49), really-liked-it (#74), review-copies (#6), romance-lovey-dovey (#86), school-boarding-genres (#29), young-adult (#124), why-no-hype (#8)
My Review:
It's been a long time since I wrote my last review. Hopefully, I haven't forgotten the art of reviewing!


*deep breath*


PLOT

TRIGGER WARNING : Rape, Sexual Abuse

The Final Year Project follows Om, a nerdy Tech student at Amra, throughout his final year, along with his spoilt, ready-for-trouble friends.

Om is a photographer of their college boxing club. His friends, the flirty tech-savy Sid, omniscient Dev and childhood buddy and best friend Vik have a knack of paving the way for trouble while dragging him along. When Om declares his crush on Sarah Morgan, a fresher and the topper of the batch, his friends are determined to set them up by the end of the year.

But when Sarah becomes the manager of their boxing club and turns out to be a tough nut, giving them all a tough time, his friends are not impressed. Om, however sees through her facade while she confides in him the truth about her family, her sister's abuse, her dad's ignorance and her unhappy childhood, he cannot help falling for her.

X ------- X ------- X ------- X

Reading the title and the synopsis, I was promised of an indulgent campus-novel, but this book turned out to be much more than that. Although, while I was skeptical of starting this book, what with it being my first ARC, Mehana managed to hook me with her slightly thrilling and easy to read flow of writing.


THOUGHTS

◇• The story started on a strong note of feminism. The author is undoubtedly a feminist as potrayed through her character of Sarah Morgan. She goes to great lengths to potray gender equality and feminism, to the point that it became quite disturbing and unrealistic.

For example, there is a boxing game between girls and boys where the girls unanimously win BECAUSE THE BOYS COULDN'T HIT THE GIRLS ANYWHERE. Not in the guts because "hitting a girl in the guts? unmanly!", not the face because "Why ruin a pretty face?, or chest because its-oh-so-obvious-why. That is not a good way to showcase feministic strength. It infact, highlights weaknesses, that the girls win out of sympathy, which should not be the case. Girls should not have been fighting boys in the first place, because, let's face in, on an average, BOYS ARE PHYSICALLY STRONGER THAN GIRLS.

Also, the things both the sides do inorder to avenge the other gender is plainly cruel. The prevalent theme of feminism isn't as prevalent in the second half of the book.

◇▪ The beginning of the book was incredibly slow and hard to get into. There were too many descriptions which was difficult to keep track of, but it WAS INTERESTING all the same. The story itself captured my curiousity. It took me forever to complete the first half, but ONLY A NIGHT to finish the second half. Yeah, engaging it seems.

◇▪ I was completely amazed by how Mehana managed to pull off a male pov so smoothly and realistically. You can't even tell it is by a female author. Seriously, most of the male characters written by female authors are usually unconvincing. But this one was not.

◇▪ There was a part of the book where the author gives us a brief introduction to some concepts of mathematics, which was, obviously very boring and which I PROMPTLY SKIPPED. Seriously, I really felt it was completely unnecessary. An whole page on sequences and series! My! My! I have had enough of them in my higher secondary classes, thank you very much!

◇▪ The characters and their development were forecasted brillianlty. They are morally gray characters who show a hint of redemption and righteousness. The message given through them touches deep and true.

◇▪ The suspense was very entertaining. It was mysterious, engrossing and surprising in the end. The author also tries to deal with many themes and subjects without being too obvious about it. The way the issues of rape and abuse were handled, the accute potrayal of the situation of girls in India are noteworthy.

◇▪ Overall, the nostalgic representation of a student's college life and the world Mehana built in the campus of Amra, was really good to read. A small fault was that the location was not very descriptive. I had no idea where the story actually took place or how it looked like, excpet that there are vague references to Coimbatore, Tamil Nadu. Other than that, we see no real demonstration of the varied culture of the Tamilians.


I would recommend this book to anyone looking for a good campus story, with romance, fun, mischief and mystery. A really good book that deals with many issues that needed to be dealt with. Good debut.

I received an e-ARC of this book in exchange for an honest review. Many thanks to [a:Mehana Usha Rani|16974978|Mehana Usha Rani|https://images.gr-assets.com/authors/1506756813p2/16974978.jpg] for sending me this book. I am glad to have had this opportunity :)

Title: Broken Promise (Between Worlds #2)
Author: Julia Crane
Bookshelves: books-in-series, could-have-been-better, horror-paranormal, i-didnt-get-the-point, liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure, romance-lovey-dovey, spiralling-downward, young-adult
Bookshelves with positions: books-in-series (#72), could-have-been-better (#12), horror-paranormal (#61), i-didnt-get-the-point (#31), liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure (#31), romance-lovey-dovey (#85), spiralling-downward (#6), young-adult (#123)
My Review:
Well, this book was just,.. Neutral.

At first, I had thought that the writing had improved than the first book and that it was going to be real good, but then turns out it wasn’t really anything special.

This book continues Rylie’s struggle in balancing her identities and relationships in the human world as well as the newly-discovered faery world.
Someone who hasn’t read the prequel would never get the hang of what is happening in this book. In short, this would be a really bad standalone even if there isn’t much story it is carrying forward from the prequel.

There were a lot of revelations in this book. The authors tried to add more and more details to this faery world they had created, but to me it felt dumb, as if not much consideration was given to the world-building or characterization as much as the romance.

Another thing that bugged me was the protagonist. Not that she was unlikable; in fact her narrative was very soothing and comfortable. But the way she treated people around her was very unfair. Her cousins especially, threatening them to get her way, and Adam too. The way she ended things with him without as much as an explanation, was cruel of her. Not that I like Adam. Ugh no, Rylie and Adam’s relationship was basically just kissing-mates, nothing else. Still, no one deserves to be treated the way Rylie treated Adam.

The characters themselves were a bit unrealistic and two-dimensional. They did not show any reactions a normal human (or faery) would have under their circumstances AND their straightforward behavior was too good to be believable. The happily-ever-after ending didn’t do much to warm me up either.

In short, this book had no impact on me whatsoever. No sort of emotional response from my side. Since I wasn’t actually expecting anything, I am not that disappointed either. Like I said, neutral. Recommended to fans of Twilight, or ‘normal’ paranormal beings. Others- you have better books to read.

Title: The Giving Tree
Author: Shel Silverstein
My Review:
What is so profoundly moving, heartbreaking or tear-jerking about this silly book, I could never decipher. Seriously, people? There was NOTHING new in this book, nothing more than what we already know about, which is, how bitchy and selfish and ungrateful little souls all we human beings are, AND how trees are the kindest, most generous, selfless creations ever - too good for this world.

Bullshit.

Just imagine. If trees could move and kick our asses, the human race might have been extinct right when it even began. I’m not manifesting deforestation, all I want to say is that I don’t get the hype with this book. Tell me, didn’t you know what would happen in the end when you were, say, at the very first page? Hmm?

WE NEED TREES. TREES DON’T NEED US. END OF STORY.

Tbh It never once crossed my mind that the tree may signify a parent, because seriously it doesn't. That is a total misrepresentation of a parent-child relationship. Another failure I guess, duh.

This has to be the first time I have openly sworn. Shit.

Title: Shatter Me
Author: Tahereh Mafi
Bookshelves: books-in-series, dystopia, could-have-been-better, horror-paranormal, romance-lovey-dovey, writing-to-die-for
Bookshelves with positions: books-in-series (#71), dystopia (#13), could-have-been-better (#11), horror-paranormal (#60), romance-lovey-dovey (#84), writing-to-die-for (#7)
My Review:
What can you possibly say about a book such as this one? Because, other than overwhelming me with it’s vivid descriptions, this book had no impact on me. The only considerable quality of this book is the WRITING STYLE. Your overall opinion on this book might solely depend on that factor – you either love it or hate it.

✴THE PLOT

Juliet has been enclosed in prison for 264 days. Abandoned by family, secluded by the society for her lethal touch, Juliet has nothing in her life to keep her going other than hope. Hope that one of these days she’ll become less of a monster, hope that her parents would love her, hope that she would see the white bird with a crown flying high in the sky – hope that she can somehow fly with the white bird.

But Warner, the leader of their sector, is suddenly interested in her and her powers. She gets released only to the condition that she’d help Warner. Being branded as a monster and becoming one are completely different scenarios and Juliet has to face that option. In the midst of this dystopia it is only Adam and her hope that keeps Juliet from losing her mind. Discovering that there are other people like her was the first step. Now she realizes that her touch has the power to save the world too, instead of destroying it.

• There really wasn’t much focus on the plot. The world-building was delusional at best.

• The dystopian world Tahereh Mafi has created lacks all the quality of a proper dystopian world. There was nothing really motivating the story, nothing to look forward to, which made the read all the more forced.

• The concept had so much potential but the execution has me irked. What a terrible waste of a brilliant idea due to sheer focus on romance! There were all sorts of possibilities to be explored, but Mafi either considered us fools to fall for the romance, or was a fool herself to focus on that, rather than create some original substance for her book.

✴The Writing

So much has been said about the writing style in this book, all sorts of good and bad things, both of which are entirely justifiable. For me, the writing style was unlike anything I’ve read before. That was the sole reason I was motivated to read this book. And yeah, it was brilliant. Creative, original, imaginative, just the kind where words weaved up to make you either cringe or marvel in delight.

Though, sometimes the writings were overdone. The descriptions were overly descriptive and sometimes just plain absurd.

• Seems like Mafi hasn’t heard of the world blush. She uses so many other metaphors to describe the single word.

‘’red paints my face, bleeds through my skin’’



I’m dripping red paint on the carpet.



I catch the rose petals as they fall from my cheeks, as they float around the frame of my body, as they cover me in something that feels like the absence of courage.



• Umm, that’s too much, even for me?
• But there were some awesome descriptions too, and I loved some of them because they were the renditions of what I used to feel myself.

✴The Characters

Unlike in many other YA dystopias, the main character here is not a fake-badass-super heroine. In fact Juliet is portrayed to be a pitiful, self-pitying, powerless young girl. For most parts, she was likeable.

Enter Adam. The moment she lays her eyes on him, describing his deep-blue eyes, bulging muscles and her urge to touch him is the only thing Juliet can talk about. There was no development whatsoever in their relationship.
And then there is Warner. His character is intriguing in a way, but yet, there again comes a romance element. Come on, can’t a man and woman lay eyes on each other without having romantic thoughts? No wonder the whole world has come to be the way it is.


My favorite character however, is James. The 10-year old brother of Adam is the best thing in the whole book. Loved the way he was introduced, his sarcasm, wit, and innocence. He is too good for this world xD


When talking about characters, I must say, there didn’t seem to be any kind of development. Maybe because this is just the first book in the series, or maybe because development happens overtime; but the characters were flat, one dimensional. Which is why I can’t even say two more words about them ha-ha.

✴Overall

Well, with the exception of the writing style, this book provided nothing new. The plot is just the same old overly used dystopian trope – heroine saves the world from the deadly dangerous ruler and lives with the love of her life happily forever after. The love triangle can be sense miles ahead, and really, that is NOT something I want to get entangled in any sooner.

The ending, even if not conclusive, didn’t for a moment make me want to dive in to the next book and I am not sure I would do that in the near future.

Recommended for – fans of dystopia with a metaphorical writing style.
