Title: Milk and Honey
Author: Rupi Kaur
Bookshelves: contemporary, liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure, non-fiction, mature-stuff, poetry, indian-readers-2017
Bookshelves with positions: contemporary (#32), liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure (#25), non-fiction (#4), mature-stuff (#20), poetry (#1), indian-readers-2017 (#6)
My Review:
I never thought I would try poetry books. But this had so many great reviews, I just had to catch up before I turned my back on it. And boy! It was beautiful.

"my favorite thing about you
is your
smell
you smell like
earth
herbs
gardens
a little more
human than the rest of us"


Wait no, beautiful isn't the word. It was raw, unscathed and so brutally honest that I sometimes just had to take my eyes of the book because the intensity was such.

"people go
but how
they left
always stays"


milk and honey is a book of poetry. The poems lasts a line or two, but manages to shake you enough to make you read the rest. Illustrated with highly unconventional sketches, the poems are about loving yourself, others, longing, heartbreak, pain and abuse – in the reverse order.

"if I knew what
safety looked like
i would have spent
less time falling into
arms that were not"


Highly original, I've not read anything like it. This isn't a book full of poems written in unrecognizable verses. It is straight to the point, brimming with passion, pain, lust, heartbreak, longing and healing – it takes you along with the words. And the illustrations may not be that well executed, but it is a very accurate representation, raw and honest in its depiction, just like the lines it accompanies. Questioning social norms, and breaking every rule of oppression – the book doesn't hold back anything.

"emptying out of my
mother's belly
was my first act of disappearance
learning to shrink for a family
who likes their daughters invisible
was the second
the art of being empty
is simple
believe them when they say
you are nothing
repeat it to yourself
like a wish
i am nothing
i am nothing
i am nothing
so often
the only reason you know
you’re still alive is from the
heaving of your chest"



The language is lucid. There might have been a lot of grammar errors if not for the fact that it was poetry. (call me a grammar nerd, but yeah!) The poet writes in un-capitalized letters which somehow makes the read more effective, the message clearer. It was erotic at times, but striking all the same. Like these –

"the very thought of you
has my legs spread apart
like easel with a canvas
begging for art "


I mean, the lines are clearly imaginative, but I couldn’t bring myself to enjoy what it meant.
There were many such moments, were you are blown away by the creative use of words, but you simply couldn't bend your mind along with the lines.

If I had to quote out the best lines, it would probably include the whole book, so let's just say – READ THIS. Even if you don't think you could possibly love it - Because it carries an intensity that's going to break your insides and the words may either make you go gaga or make you cringe, but above all – the message it contains, definitely needs to be heard, even if not necessarily enjoyed.

"honey that man could feed
you sugar
and douse you in rose water
but that still could not make you sweet"

Title: When Dimple Met Rishi (Dimple and Rishi, #1)
Author: Sandhya Menon
Bookshelves: chick-lit, contemporary, indian-author-books, made-me-cry, made-me-lol, romance-lovey-dovey, young-adult, could-have-been-better, spiralling-downward, indian-readers-2017
Bookshelves with positions: chick-lit (#38), contemporary (#26), indian-author-books (#47), made-me-cry (#25), made-me-lol (#9), romance-lovey-dovey (#54), young-adult (#90), could-have-been-better (#4), spiralling-downward (#1), indian-readers-2017 (#5)
My Review:
I’m confused as to how much I actually liked this book. This was a well-executed, but cliché; happily-ever-after kinda Bollywood rom-com ride. But I cannot overlook all the feels and vibe and laughter moments this book presented to me, so I (or rather my heart) would rate it 4/5 *mind cringes*

Dimple Shah is an Indian girl, bought up in America by her very conservative parents. Contrary to her mother’s expectations of her marrying the ideal-Indian-husband, Dimple has her own future planned out. She’s going to Stanford and has her eyes set on a web development program – Insomnia Con - in San Francisco. The winners of the Insomnia Con would get to develop and market their app, with the help of none other than Jenny Lindt – her idol. While her parents resist at first, Dimple is excited when they finally allow her to go. But turns out, they had other plans in mind.
Rishi Patel, a very traditional boy, is excited to meet Dimple Shah, the girl his parents has picked up for him. He would be going to Insomnia Con where he hopes to meet her and possibly fall in love. But their first meeting goes horribly wrong. Rishi is at first slightly hurt that Dimple doesn’t want anything to do with him, but he feels okay after learning of her hopes and ambitions.
Without meaning to, they both fall in love, realizes their true desires with the help of each other. But, is it what Dimple wants? Would Rishi be able to let go? Would Dimple?

My Thoughts? - After all my past experiences with Indian contemporary, I knew better than to expect much of this book. But it didn’t disappoint. The writing was good, the humor actually made me laugh, and most of the time I had on this big smile plastered onto my face that it actually hurt.

I was pleasantly surprised that I loved the beginning of the book. Dimple seemed like an amazing MC. But I hated that her character seemed to lack the initial charisma later on in the novel. Rishi, on the other hand, maintained his Mr. Goody-two-shoes position throughout. And the main reason this book appealed to me was that the two of them loved what I loved the most – computers and art. But while the whole point of the Insomnia Con thing was coding, that topic faded off completely as the story progressed. And this whole meeting-love-romance happens in a span of six weeks, (of which we got to see only the first three weeks), which was ridiculous. The ending, was like any typical Bollywood romance sealed with a kiss.

Would I recommend this book? – Yup, for all those who don’t mind a clichéd romance with a desi (Indian) twist.

I don't really know what I just read. Reading about a family through their whole lives and I still have no idea what their lives are about.

The characterisation felt flat, the narrative monotonous and pointless. It took me forever to get into this book (like, at 80%) and then it ended before I could actually feel for the characters. Amina and Akhil's story wasn't my cup of tea. None of the characters were likable. The occasional attempts at humor saw no reaction from me, and that is something, coming from me - who couldn't stop laughing all over the place while reading [b:Catching Fire|6148028|Catching Fire (The Hunger Games, #2)|Suzanne Collins|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1358273780s/6148028.jpg|6171458]. I couldn't care less for the Pikuyu tribes (or something like that) or Bobby MgGrath or whats-his-name. The psychological issues addressed here weren't actually explained. It also didn't help that I had to look up every other word in the dictionary. Definitely not going to reread this one.

Title: A Gathering of Shadows (Shades of Magic, #2)
Author: V.E. Schwab
Bookshelves: adventure, all-time-favourites, fantasy, i-need-the-book, i-need-a-movie, loved-the-protagonist, made-me-cry, made-me-lol, really-liked-it, young-adult, writing-to-die-for, romance-lovey-dovey, characters-that-hold-my-heart, books-in-series
Bookshelves with positions: adventure (#30), all-time-favourites (#19), fantasy (#25), i-need-the-book (#5), i-need-a-movie (#9), loved-the-protagonist (#21), made-me-cry (#28), made-me-lol (#12), really-liked-it (#64), young-adult (#117), writing-to-die-for (#5), romance-lovey-dovey (#76), characters-that-hold-my-heart (#3), books-in-series (#4)
My Review:
Everyone who had to wait a year to get their hands on the third book, you people are the bravest of all. 😮

If anyone thinks ADSoM was not all that good, then they should pick this book up the very next instant. BECAUSE, LIKE WITH HARRY POTTER, THIS ONE ONLY GETS INFINITESIMALLY BETTER.

I’m officially declaring myself the newest member of the Schwab fandom. Oh yeah, I like that.

ADSom was about world-building, this one is about the characters. And magic. And everything in between. This book is magical, emotional, action-packed and in one word – brilliant. V.E Schwab, you are imaginative and daring – you’re one of a kind OR the kind is one of you. Simply, you’re my new favorite author.

LET’S SEE WHAT THIS BOOK WAS ABOUT…

After Holland was gone, and White London fell, Kell thought he would breathe easier. But he was wrong. King Maxim and Queen Emira of Red London are determined to keep Kell grounded, as long as it means their son, Prince Rhy would remain safe. With Lila gone and a new responsibility of holding Rhy’s life in his hands, Kell is as impatient as ever.

Also, Red London is hosting The Elemental Games this year, where magicians come forward to show their prowess and win the crown. Delilah Bard, reckless as always, decides to try her hand at the tournament. But little did she know that she wasn’t going to be the only disguise…

Meanwhile, in White London, a new king has emerged and the kingdom is flourishing. But the king is not so forgiving to the one Antari who led the downfall of his kingdom, Kell. Or, is he?

An aspiring and reckless pirate, a magician held prisoner in his own home, a charming Prince with a life debt, a king reborn to a flourishing kingdom while bound to destroy another…. What will it all lead to?

Few of the very best things about this book..,

1. DELILAH BARD
This woman is my most favorite person in literature right now. I’m pretty sure the book wouldn’t have been half as good if not for Lila. (Just kidding! But yeah?). Unlike most of the lead heroines in YA fantasies, the character of Lila hasn’t gone on a reclining spiral. Instead it has gone all the way up and established itself as one of the best badass female character ever written. Lila is reckless, ruthless, brave to the point of madness, quick, sharp-witted and as clever as she is all those things.

"I am one of a damned kind."

"Everyone thinks I have a death wish, you know? But I don’t want to die- dying is easy. No, I want to live, but getting closer to death is the only way to feel alive. And once you do, it makes you realize that everything you were doing before wasn’t actually living. It was just making do. Call me crazy, but I think we do the best living when the stakes are high."


Perhaps power had to be tended, like Tieren said, but not all things grew in gardens. Plenty of plants grew wild. And Lila had always thought of herself more as weed than a rose bush.


Probably not, but if anyone could make the strange seem ordinary, the impossible look easy, it was Delilah Bard.


In this book, we also get to see the other side of the façade – the slightly human side – of Delilah Bard. I’m gay when it comes to Lila. And generous. So here’s more –


"People could only hurt you if you cared enough to let them."

"Walking away had been easy. Not looking back was harder."


"I’m sorry" Alucard said.
"For growing on me?" She asked.
He shook his head. "For whatever happened to you. For whoever hurt you so deeply that you see things like friends and fondness as weapons instead of shields."


People survived by being cautious, but they got ahead by being bold.


I’m pretty sure that is as far as I can go before being arrested for violating copyrights. Anyway, you get the point? LILA BARD IS AMAZING AS HELL, AND ONE HUNDRED PERCENT MY FAVORITE CHARACTER FOREVER. (It’s funny, to fangirl so hard about a fictional character, while knowing full well that you wouldn’t like them if they existed in real life and you happened to meet. Guess that’s the difference between fiction and reality lol!)
So moving on..,

2. KELL
I am astonished at the amount of character building that has taken place in this book. Honestly, I wasn’t so fond of Kell in ADSoM, but this book has breathed an amazing persona into him. He’s become more charismatic, brave, upfront and more himself. More real.

Every moment when he fought for himself, every moment he missed Lila, every moment that displayed his loyalty to the Royals, every moment he thought of Rhy – they were just so complete and honest and right. This completeness, precision of thoughts and emotions, were missing from the first book, and I’m so glad to see it developed here. I cried every moment he cried, and laughed along with his joy. We’re soulmates!

Also, the fights – the duels. HE IS A FREAKING AMAZING, AND SKILLED. I LOVE HIS AUBURN HAIR, HIS GRACE, TALENT AND WELL, HIS COAT. AAaarghh!! The end though! Please someone save him. Lila!!! I’m looking at you. Hurry up. Where’s the next book??? I’m coming Kell,, you just hang on and please don’t let the seal break!!

3. RHY
The prince has matured so much and he has become so very adorable yet! The characterization is again, mindblowing. I loved that we got to see more of his perspectives. He makes up for his lack of magic with his charm, smile and his love for everything. I did suspect he would be gay, but that was a surprise! Alucard Emery?

Also, I was taken back by the way he cared for his brother. Till now, we only got to see Kell being worried for Rhy, and I wasn’t sure how much Rhy would do for Kell. My doubts be damned! Rhy is as loyal to Kell as I am. That SORRY broke my heart!

4. HOLLAND
Well, he barely made an appearance. But when he did, he summoned all my hatred and left it burning. Yeah sure, there is more to him than meets the eye, but please, CAN WE JUST GET TO SEE HOLLAND AS HIMSELF FOR ONCE??? Hoping to see that in the next book. And people, he deserves a chance!!

Overall, this book is imaginative and thoughtful in its plot, perfect in its characterization and brilliant in its execution. Could not have been any better.
5/5 stars and more

Title: Chasing the Alpha (Small Town #3)
Author: Jessica  Edwards
My Review:
There’s more? Yeah? I wasn’t prepared for that. But hell yes! I definitely need more. You can’t end a book like that Jessica! It’s unfair. How many more days till the next book is up? *Prays for it to be soon*

I actually thought this would be a 3-star read, because honestly, the first half of the book was kind of umm, scary? Intimidating? But then as always, Jessica made sure her readers are satisfied with the ending.


**TRIGGER WARNING** - Rape, Violent thoughts, Murder, Excessive swearing


Let me attempt a review here. I am going to make it slightly more critical because I think Jessica has really improved as an author. So here it goes –

THE PLOT

That night at her school in Mr. Edmund’s classroom changed everything for Alice. Her father was back to Small Town and she wasn’t very happy about it. After all, he left Alice and her Mum all those years ago for another woman.
Mr. Edmund is still on loose, and there is no telling when and whom he’ll attack next. She must be the one to put an end to his killing sprees.

Things aren’t going very well with Alice and Ryder either, but to take down Mr. Edmund, Alice needs allies. Who’d want to help her avenge her mother’s death? Would Alice forgive her father after everything that has happened?

My Thoughts

• The writing was simple yet raw. Could have used some editing.

• The book started right off where the last one ended. It was a bit difficult to understand what was going on. But yeah, we got a recap later when Alice recounts it to her best friend Sam. Still, I was a bit baffled in the beginning.


• Alice. I don’t think Alice is a likeable protagonist. At. All. Her actions and behavior were too much sometimes. She had no right to blame her father for a murder he had no role in. And btw she goes on blaming every other person for her mother’s murder, it’s insane! She hates Mr. Edmund for being the mastermind, and Silver for doing it. She then blames her Dad because he wasn’t there to protect her Mom because he left years ago? And then she blames Nora too, claiming she was the one to lure her Dad away in the first place. WTF?!

Let me get this clear; Blaming someone for a murder they had no hand in, is absolutely horrible. The guilt build-up is inevitable even if you had no role in it whatsoever. Especially if it’s the murder of someone close to you. No one deserves to live with such guilt for the rest of their lives.

Besides, Alice is also a hypocrite. She goes on and on about why no one should kill anyone for a murder beyond their control, all the while intending to kill someone herself. Her violent nature kind-of appalled me. At the same time, I was also glad she embraced the changes in her.


• THE CHARACTERS. I am surprised at the character growth that takes place in this novel. Sam, Ryder, and Max. Also Mark, and yeah Nora. Oh, and especially Bane. Besides Alice, I think I loved everyone else. Kellan’s character was a bit low for some reason. Jessica has done a great job with her characters, they’re memorable, each one of them unique.


• To me, the use of profanity was a bit too much. I don’t think kids swear like that. I mean, how can you even pronounce a sentence with so many f*cks in place? It was unrealistic, overdone and completely unnecessary.


• Use of rape as a plot device. Again, I didn’t see why this had to be the case. It was easily avoidable. The casual manner in which it was handled might be triggering for some people.


• There were some instances where characters were stereotyped for the way of dressing. I never thought I’d be siding up for short dresses and I’m the last person you’d see in a mini-skirt, but I think calling someone an “expensive dirty prostitute” for their dressing choices is unacceptable. Again, that is one more reason Alice didn’t work for me.


• The ending. I wasn’t actually looking forward to the ending because I thought there might be too much blood shedding. Thank God I was wrong. That ending was a pleasant surprise. The Epilogue though! From Max’s pov! I couldn’t have asked for more.


Overall this book didn’t amaze me like the other two books did, but it wasn’t disappointing either. Jessica Edwards has so much potential, I can’t wait to discover her future works! 3.5/5 stars

P.S Thanks to the author for sending me a copy of this book! All opinions are my own, though

Title: Last Sacrifice (Vampire Academy, #6)
Author: Richelle Mead
Bookshelves: books-in-series, chick-lit, could-have-been-better, horror-paranormal, i-didnt-get-the-point, liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure, over-hyped, romance-lovey-dovey, spiralling-downward, suspense-thriller-mystery, young-adult
Bookshelves with positions: books-in-series (#69), chick-lit (#53), could-have-been-better (#10), horror-paranormal (#58), i-didnt-get-the-point (#30), liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure (#29), over-hyped (#10), romance-lovey-dovey (#83), spiralling-downward (#5), suspense-thriller-mystery (#32), young-adult (#122)
My Review:
So many conflicting emotions! I don’t know if I should rate this 5 stars for keeping me on edge throughout the whole book or whether I should rate it 1 star because it all fell into…nothingness?

There are so many more questions, so much the author has left uncovered, I can’t help but be disappointed.

Don’t get me wrong, the book was well-crafted. Witty, reckless, action-packed, everything I’d hoped for. But I still can’t ignore the fact that what it delivered certainly wasn’t what I wanted. Yeah this definitely might be its-me-not-the-book thing. Seriously though? I have to admit I was totally engrossed, finishing this humongous book in two days. And now that I’ve gotten through the initial inability to write a coherent review, I can sum up some of it (it also means I have practically forgotten everything I’ve wanted to say, but let’s just ignore that, okay? Okay.)

**there might be mild spoilers ahead, but does it really matter at this point?**


THE PLOT

So Mead certainly did quite a good job of adding much more mystery, suspense and substance into this book(which is to be expected, since it’s the last one).

I’ll not say much about the plot since it would be too spoiler-y. But here are the basics:

Queen is dead--Rose imprisoned--Dimitri is too--Queen Tatiana’s letter--Another surviving Dragomir--On the run--Sydney plays a big role--Lissa nominated for Monarchy--Another Strigoi turns normal --Chaos at court

For once, I was actually intrigued by the plotline, believe me, it’s hard not to. The story takes off right away with lots of action and explosion. It was just a bang. I knew my heart was thumping aloud the whole time. But then, the book was over, the suspense wore off, I came to my senses and realized, it was all just a trance.

The plot, while it focused less on romance, (it was still there – ever so cheesy, but I have long since learned to overlook that fact.) the Author has tried to include so much in this book, and it kind of worked. It takes off our attention from the bigger PLOTHOLES which were always there.

Lord, I guess I’m still not capable of this review; my thoughts are so messed up, I should have learned to jot them down as soon as they formed. But heck, I’m not going to let this book get in the way of my clouded thinking.

RANDOM THOUGHTS

• Richelle Mead might be a feminist, or might not be one. From reading her books, I certainly did see some feminism and sometimes felt her writing was extremely anti-feministic.

• For example, take Rose. She is built up to be the strongest, most badass character ever,. And yet she and others are subjected to so much BODYSHAMING it sucks. It’s as if having a little more of curves and breasts make her more feminine. But describing other woman to be less attractive because they are tall and flat-chested doesn’t make her one. See this line from Spirit Bound for proof -

It certainly wasn’t meant to be sexy, but the way it hugged my stomach and hips did good things for my body


• There is also discrimination going on here. While there might be a Royal clan and non-royals, actively describing non-royals as ‘ordinary’ is not that smart. As if Royals are in anyway extraordinary than them. As if non-royals are worthless beings just because their lineage didn’t include kings. In fact, most of the royals in this book are just stupid spoilt fools imo.

• Speaking of feminism, why are mostly all the rulers Queens? I mean, yeah equality is fine and all, but hey, you don’t have to go overboard with that alright?

• And too, the discrimination between Moroi and Dhampirs is downright cruel. Why are Dhampirs treated lower than Moroi, I won’t understand. Why can’t they be kings, queens, royals? They’re an extincting specie for god’s sake!
And Rose can sleep with Strigoi but is extremely offended at the idea of Moroi sleeping with humans? How thoughtful, Rose.

• Another issue, Abe Mazur. He is Rose’s father and he knew she was his daughter all this while, but only thought of turning up when she became 18? What, do people need to be of age to know who their parents are? And what makes it even more unrealistic is the fact that Abe becomes an over-protective, loving and a proud father all of a sudden. Seems to me Rose should have known about her father a while ago atleast.

Richelle Mead has also so much more to improve in the way of giving depth to her story. In fact, I don’t think she improved at all throughout the six books. But I must appreciate; the dry humor cracked me up at the most unexpected places. Like, really cracked me up. But the certain issues with depth were really hard to ignore.

The Relationships

• Rose & Dimitri
I CAN’T BE THE ONLY PERSON IN THE WORLD WHO HATES THIS DUO TOGETHER, RIGHT? There has to be someone else, someone who can really see the relationship for what it truly is - lust

Rose is highly incapable of describing true love. All the philosophical insights she gave on love went right above my head. And most of the time, she is always thinking of sex. I was unfazed throughout their whole relationship.

Rose repeatedly says she and Dimitri understood each other perfectly, that they were meant to be. How touching! But in reality, there was no instance when we actually get to see that for ourselves. We never feel, ‘’Yes they are perfect!’’ ‘’They love each other so much!’’ even when all the while Mead continues to try convincing us. And, making Dimitri to be the God he isn’t, was downright pathetic. Rose isn’t even a believer. I really don’t get why these two are supposedly “made for each other”


• Rose & Lissa
This had no depth either. Without the bond I don’t even think these two would have been friends. Rose had a different personality and Lissa had a unique one too. All the time Rose says they’re best friends but never do we actually get to see them together.
It’s always either through the bond. When they are in the same place, we barely even see them hang out. But even if we don’t get to see their development, they share an intense relationship too. Proved by how much they care for each other. This too, is to be deduced by the reader, because, WE ALL KNOW BY NOW THAT MEAD IS AN UNCONVINCING WRITER.


• Rose & Adrian
Why these two even got together is beyond my comprehension. Adrian was fiercely loyal to Rose (who wasn’t? -.- ). Considering his personality, we might think it might be up to Adrian to cheat, but Rose got ahead again. She deludes herself into thinking she loves Adrian all the while pining for Dimitri and calling it ‘moving on’. She had no right to do all that she did to Adrian. And cheating on him with her ex-boyfriend, saying she is independent and can make decisions for herself. God, I can only bear so much.


• Christian and Lissa
Because, this was a relationship Mead didn’t actively pursue and bring into attention, I really liked it. When Mead brings her characters to the spotlight, she has a tendency to spoil it. Thankfully, that didn’t happen in this case. These two were perfect for each other, a lot more so than Rose and Dimitri, mostly because Mead didn’t try to convince us that they were perfect for each other.


Now that relationships are unpacked, I want to focus on the biggest thing I hated about this book –
ROSE AND HER HAPPILY-EVER-AFTER
I don’t know how to put my thoughts into words; I’ll try my best though. I just want to get it out of my system and say it all aloud.

Richelle Mead idealizes, idolizes Rose in every cringe-worthy way possible.

• She wins every fight. Four Strigoi? Rose and Dimitri are enough. Ten? Doesn’t matter. Like, when she catches a Strigoi by surprise, she wins. But when the Strigoi catches her by surprise, her years of training kicks in. She wins. Simple.

• Everyone is fiercely loyal to her, while according to Rose herself, she is independent and is not condemned to anyone.

• She uses every friend and foe loyal to her and just… leaves.

o Eddie – supported her all the while, helped her escape prison, and followed her around the world on a death mission. What does Rose do? Forget him as soon as she has what she wants.

o Adrian – she basically exhausted all of his funds by travelling around the world, gets his help every time she is in trouble, uses his money on the trip to bring back her ex-boyfriend and ditches him when the love of her life is back.

o Victor – he might be a passionate royal or whatever, but she had no right to use him to fulfill all her bloody plans and then kill him afterward.

o Robert –that guy saved a strigoi, but since Rose has better job to do, she leaves him insane on the streets, never giving an after-thought.

o Sydney –she is practically the reason why Rose survived that entire ordeal, but i-have-better-things-to-do Rose doesn’t ever give a damn on what happens to her.

o Christian –he had always been there for her and Lissa, but what did Rose do? Never even thinks of him even after calling out on his aunt for murdering the Queen. Seriously, Rose MUST have confronted Christian after what she did? Surely? Hmm? Oops, sorry, I forgot we were talking about Rose.

You see,? Rose is the most heartless person ever, she is too selfish and never gives another thought about those who were there for her in times of need. But according to Mead, Rose is right in doing everything she did, because her intentions were all good. Were they? No actually not. Everything she did has a selfish motivation behind them. I can’t believe she didn’t ever feel guilty for doing all that.


As for the ending, I saw that coming miles before. I don’t actually understand why Mead made it out to be such a big suspense when the answer was so obvious. I’m even wondering if she intentionally made the murderer obvious. Either way, she didn’t bother explaining how Rose cleared her name, how the evidences that were clearly pointing to her, suddenly start pointing to someone else. Instead, Rose nearly dies and comes back to life because of her resolve to live.

It is almost funny how simple Richelle Mead has made death to be. You die? Fine. You want to live? Boom! You’re alive again. Such ridiculous logic! (I actually leaped in joy when Rose died, but well, knowing Mead, I had to give up hopes of her actually dying)


On an afterthought, I can’t resist adding that this book was completely unoriginal, I felt like it had a mix of most of those YA series out there – Harry Potter, Hunger Games, Divergent… I haven’t read many others to add more. But yeah, the plotlines can certainly be traced to those books.


There had been so much more to say, but I’ve clearly started wearing off my memories of this book. It was entertaining, yes, but not enough to create a lasting impression on my mind. I’m glad this is over though! Would I read the spin-off series? Idk. I might, since it is not from Rose’s perspective. And I kind of am curious to know if Mead has really grown a brain and bothered to explain things that she promptly skipped over in this book.


2.5/5 stars

Title: Spirit Bound (Vampire Academy, #5)
Author: Richelle Mead
Bookshelves: characters-that-hold-my-heart, books-in-series, chick-lit, horror-paranormal, liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure, made-me-lol, romance-lovey-dovey, suspense-thriller-mystery, young-adult
Bookshelves with positions: characters-that-hold-my-heart (#14), books-in-series (#68), chick-lit (#52), horror-paranormal (#57), liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure (#28), made-me-lol (#16), romance-lovey-dovey (#82), suspense-thriller-mystery (#31), young-adult (#121)
My Review:
What is this book? I was planning on ditching it up until 80% of it, and in a bizarre turn of events, I lost a night to this book and jumped onto the sequel right after wtf I blame this book for making me a messy insomniac.? That’s extraordinary. Not that this book was any good. Richelle Mead is one manipulative author. Like really, really manipulative. How dare she light my heart with fury like that and become the fireman all of a sudden? Ugh, this one’s going to be hard to review, not to mention rate.

First half of the book? 1/5 stars
The 60%-80% potion of the book? 3/5 stars
That ending though? 4.5/5 stars

Overall, 2.5/5 stars

**As always, please be aware of spoilers in case you have not read the previous books**


THE PLOT

Let’s say um, where did that previous book end? I am not so sure. But this one started quite sometime after.
Rose and Adrian are dating. Yeah, finally. But she is not very sure of her feelings for him. She is confused. Because, duh, her ex-boyfriend is dead (undead-whatever) and might have a shot at being bought to life which would mean busting a notorious criminal out from his high-security prison. So what does invincible, reckless, i-am-in-control-of-everything Rose do? She emotionally manipulates, Lissa, her best friend, who thinks she owes her, in coming with her to bust that monster out and try to regain a Strigoi, which might not even be possible. In doing so, they are risking the entire Vampire world, Rose and Lissa’s future, the love and life of everyone they hold dear, to accomplish what? To bring a dead man out alive because Rose loved him. (Raise your hands if you didn’t cringe at that?)

Anyways, Miracles do happen and it happens here, but one problem leads to another, and in the end, Rose finds herself tackled in a web of conspiracies and an impossible quest; she isn’t even sure how she got herself there, or even worse, how she’d ever be able to get herself out.

MY THOUGHTS more like, my tangled chain of emotions

• Let’s be real and admit this: Rose is the most annoying, whiny, emotionally manipulative, utterly-selfish, reckless brat who does EVERYTHING with selfish notions and regrets every bit of her recklessness later. Like, for most part of this book, I ABSOLUTELY HATED HER. In fact, I can’t even remember an instant when she was bearable. She was awful to those who loved her, using them to get her way in and out of things, and not even giving a second thought on how much her actions might affect them.

• Btw, the way she described her love-life. Disgusting. It was as if the only good thing about being in love was the kisses, cuddles and sex.

• I DON’T SHIP ROSE AND DIMITRI. There – I say it again and I will say this all the time. I didn’t see any development in their relationship. I don’t even think they make a good pair. Because, honestly, Dimitri and Rose are the most annoying MCs I’ve read yet. Oh, Heck. They make the best pair. They are perfect for each other.

• But darn, Rose, why do you hurt my baby Adrian so much??? You know you aren’t going to stick around when Dimitri is back and yet you stay in hopes of comforting him. Are you crazy??? You don’t get to control everybody’s mind by just being there!!!

• Oh, sorry, I totally forgot. She IS crazy.

• Lissa has to be the best thing to happen in this book. Her character development was remarkable. I loved her better than Rose, but still, it’s not completely enough.

• Likewise, I LOVE CHRISTIAN’s character. Amazing. Bold. Ready-for-action. Cool. Just right for Lissa.

• And not to mention, Adrian. How could he be such a bundle of pitiful-cutie-pie? I hate that he is still bowled over by Rose, but nevertheless. HE IS AMAZING.

• The thing is, Mead doesn’t give much thought to her side-characters. The whole thing is just about Rose, Rose and Rose. Plus Dimitri (thankfully, not as much as in the last book though)

• If she had given Adrian, Lissa, Christian and some others, a fair chance, a bit more role, development, this book would have been so much better. Where is Jill btw?

• Another thing about Rose that I hate – the whole book might be about her – but it is impossible how she gets her way ALL THE DAMN TIME. Come on! She’s barely adult, she is stupid even. There is no explanation as to how those ‘ideas’ come to her. Everything seems way too convenient for her and it’s unrealistic how EVERYTHING happens in her favor.

• Be reasonable Mead, you don’t have to go out of the way to make us like Rose. It can’t be always her. She’s the heroine of the story, true. Doesn’t mean there’s no other person who’s a hero too. Doesn’t have to be Rose all the time.

• Like, people have turned Strigoi for centuries now and they’ve earned the title as evil-creatures-of-the-night. But when Rose’s so-called-soulmate turns into one, there suddenly appears to be a way to restore them back to human? Ofcourse, MIRACLE. Duh. So simple.

• And I’m now going to address another important but highly overlooked issue here - MONEY Yeah I know, it might be the least of your concerns, but really, the way money is made out to be the most commonly available thing ever? It’s offending. Rose is rich by no means, but she says she is funded by Adrian who is royal, but come one! Even Royals have their limit! Living in luxurious hotels and flying to some country every other minute? It’s not just costly, IT IS SUPER EXPENSIVE. How can anyone not see that? From the way Mead writes it, Rose might sctuslly be walking over a carpet of money. IT. IS. INSANE. THE AMOUNT OF MONEY – NOT HERS – SHE SPENDS.

• I’ve said this once, (twice? Idk), the plot is as repetitive as it can get. It is always the same thing over and over again. Someone gets kidnapped. Mostly Lissa. Rose leads a group of guardians to them. They emerge victorious. End of story. Happily Ever After. Cool.


Overall, this book was way too long for what good it did to the series. The plot is repetitive, but the ending came as a total surprise even when I was spoiled on the book’s happenings. I love the action part though, not too confusing, just enough to grip you on edge. But it’s still annoying – this technique of Mead to write horribly for most of the book and finally grab us with the endings. No one’s complaining tbh.

Title: I Wrote This For You (I Wrote This For You #4)
Author: pleasefindthis

Title: Lights, Camera, Cook! (Next Best Junior Chef, #1)
Author: Charise Mericle Harper

Title: The Third Horror (99 Fear Street: The House of Evil, #3)
Author: R.L. Stine
Bookshelves: books-for-children, drama-overloaded, horror-paranormal, i-didnt-get-the-point, shit-crap-and-all-things-bad, young-adult, books-in-series
Bookshelves with positions: books-for-children (#47), drama-overloaded (#12), horror-paranormal (#49), i-didnt-get-the-point (#18), shit-crap-and-all-things-bad (#3), young-adult (#92), books-in-series (#67)
My Review:
Ugh. Again, this was bad. I've never read anything as gross or ridiculous as this one. A suitable ending to a creepy trilogy.

As promised, Kody Frasier returns to the house at 99, Fear Street nearly two years after the tragic death of her sister Cally and brother James. But this time, there is a whole movie crew with her. Bo intends to boost his slumping film career by filming the story of the Frasier's at the very house it all happened. And for publicity (and also lack of availability of other actress) Kody is playing the role of Cally Frasier. Kody is sure she would find her sister's ghost in the house and she wants to. But Cally's ghost is not so generous anymore. She's evil. She wants to destroy her sister, who gets to live, when she is all alone in that evil house. What will Cally do? What happens to Kody? And the evil house?

I actually loved the idea of this book. Kody returning to the old house to fulfil a promise made to her dead sister. That was cool. But all that happened here, that I guess was meant to be scary, was just, gross. Really, 5 pages of swimming in vomit? AAARGH!! I almost vomited myself.
I haven't read of any characer as stupid as Kody Frasier. All the supporting characters weren't any better. But the ending was slightly better than the rest of the story. Actual rating - 1.5/5

Title: The Second Horror (99 Fear Street: The House of Evil, #2)
Author: R.L. Stine
My Review:
Nope, this was bad. Thank God it got over quickly. The prequel had been much better.

In The Second Horror of The House of Evil trilogy, a family of three moves to the house at 99 Fear Street. It's been about a year since the Frasiers moved out. Feeling abandoned by her family, Cally Frasier's ghost has been waiting to take revenge on anyone who comes to live at the house next. The McCloys are in for trouble.
Mr. McCloy is an anthropologist who collects rare antiques. His son Brandt has enrolled in Shadyside High and is all set to have a fun year at school. And girls seems to magnate toward him. But Cally wants Brandt all for herself. What would happen to Brandt? What is the strange condition which makes him weak? Would Cally finally have a friend?

The plot itself was ridiculous. Cally Frasier's character was just cruel. And all the fuss about Brandt's condition was getting to me when finally it was revealed and I was like WHAT???!! THAT IS JUST STUPID DUH 😑 Brandt had been dead for two years and had been living on another man's life force

R.L. Stine's characters have never appealed to me, but he has a way of making the readers curious enough. I guess I'll just read the third book and complete the trilogy, whatever happens.

Title: Blood Promise (Vampire Academy, #4)
Author: Richelle Mead
Bookshelves: chick-lit, could-have-been-better, horror-paranormal, i-didnt-get-the-point, never-read-again, romance-lovey-dovey, spiralling-downward, over-hyped, books-in-series
Bookshelves with positions: chick-lit (#51), could-have-been-better (#7), horror-paranormal (#56), i-didnt-get-the-point (#26), never-read-again (#8), romance-lovey-dovey (#79), spiralling-downward (#3), over-hyped (#8), books-in-series (#61)
My Review:
UPDATE 17/11/2017

I just happened to know that there was a spin-off to this series titled The Bloodlines. Because I'm human and because I'm a naturally curious person, I read the synopsis and aiehsjszvaowjpwpn; THAT DAMN THING WAS A HUGE SPOILER OF THIS SERIES WHY DID THIS HAVE TO HAPPEN TO ME PLEASE I NEED MY BRAIN REFRESHED. It changes everything!!!!

Why do book synopsis have to be so spoilery???? omg I AM SO FURIOUS MY SWEAT HAS EVAPORATED WITH THE STEAM -_-

------------------------


**This review might be a spoiler for those who haven’t read the previous books in the series**

Well, I waited. I really did. I didn’t know I was capable of such patience. You see, this book was slow. Like, had-to-drag-my-ass-through-it-while-it-felt-like-cement slow. I had to restrain myself so many times from just flicking over to the end and finding out what Mead had done with the ending this time. Admittedly, when it came, it wasn’t bad. It felt good actually. But those momentary pleasure of action was short-lived and I don’t think it was worth all the forcing-myself I had to do to get there. 2.5/5 stars.

So this is the plot (or so it claims to be) – Dimitri is dead. No, undead. He has turned strigoi. Rose had promised to free him from that soulless state. So she left the Academy, left Lissa and everyone, in pursuit of Dimitri. She sets off to Siberia, Dimitri’s homeland in hopes of finding him there. But it turns out to be a daunting task. With help from Sydney, an Alchemist, and Abe Zmey, a mysterious all-knower, Lissa soon finds Dimitri. Or rather, finds herself in Dimitri’s clutches. She is forced to make a decision- to turn Strogoi by choice or be turned by force. Impossible. Finding herself addicted to the lure of the man she used to love – now a monster - Rose has to regain her senses and be where she is needed – with Lissa.

Well, my first problem with this book was the plot itself. It was totally ridiculous, lacked substance and existed solely on our sympathy for the main character. I don’t really know what purpose this book serves to the whole series, because honestly, there is nothing much it adds to it. We begin and end the book, and the story is still at the same place it had been before we began. That’s bad. A sequel is supposed to continue a story, give it new dimensions, give us reasons, explanations. But no, that doesn’t happen. It feels to me like the whole book was about a love quest. Unnecessary. Vampire Academy could have used one less book.

The story is totally predictable, ludicrous, and while Mead does try to show the mental struggles of a drug addict, I didn’t think it worked in a positive way. The ending? I hated it. Pointless, stupid. I had thought that everything’s over for good. But no, feels like a circle – starts and ends at the same point – going nowhere else.

Here’s another - Character Analysis -

• Rose

I don’t even know why I thought I was similar to Rose. We are polar opposites. She is very different from the Rose she had been in the first book. And I don’t mean that in the sense of character development either. She had been all badass and carefree back then, but now she is just another lovesick teenager. Considering her stance on protecting Lissa a while back, her sudden change of mind is utterly unbelievable. She acts stupid for most parts of the book. Cummon, she fought a battle with Strigois and always had her emotions in check and suddenly drops to be a cry baby who passes out after handling two strigois? THAT HAS TO BE THE WORST CASE OF CHARACTER UNDER-DEVELOPMENT EVER.

And can we talk about that bedroom scene in the third book, which makes up like 85% of this book too? Honestly? I’m completely fed up of hearing Rose talk about Dimitri all the time. Come to think of it, This book was just Dimitri and Rose. They’re like the center of mass that holds the whole universe. But for me? I HATE THEM> AM I THE ONLY PERSON IN THE WORLD WHO DOESN’T SHIP ROSE AND DIMITRI?? BECAUSE, LIKE,THERE WAS NO DEVELOPMENT IN THERE.
According to Rose, Dimitri understands her perfectly but there is no indication of why and hows or in what weird way they became that close. I mean,yeah there’s the sex and all – but that was all there was to their relationship imo. A physical attraction.

I REALLY HOPE ROSE STOPS MENTIONING DIMITRI ALL THE TIME SHE OPENS HER DAMN MOUTH OR ELSE I AM READY TO RULE OFF THE NEXT BOOK

• Dimitri

He has to be the damnedest, blandest character to ever exist in a book and get involved with the protagonist. I can’t even realize why he was bearable in the first two books.
HE IS SUCH A FLAT CHARACTER, LIKE TELL ME SOMETHING OTHER THAN HE IS SEXY AND STRONG AND FIGHTS STRIGOIS. But Mead did try to give him some charm by introducing his family to us – honestly though? BAKING BREAD FOR HIMSELF? – that is the only thing we get to know. OMG How charming and appealing, he’s my dream boy. Bleh. Good Lord he is dead. Please stop making a fuss over his dead body Rose because he doesn’t even deserve to be back on earth with that blank character scale of his. Why does everyone love him? I don’t even.. eh never mind.

And the other thing – he’s Strigoi. He wants Rose. You see that? Every damn Strigoi we have encountered in the past three books never hesitated a moment to kill whatever came in front of them. They’re the most brutal beings ever to exist in the history of the Vampire World according to Rose, and suddenly, when Dimitri turns Strigoi, all rules get amended? Why the heck is he the only person who shows some compassion amongst all the strigois we know?. Please don’t tell me because he’s Dimitri. THAT IS THE WRONG ANSWER. THIS HAS TO BE THE BIGGEST CLICHÉ TO EVER HAPPEN IN THE HISTORY OF ROMANCE. OMG I DON’T WANT TO PUKE -.-

• Adrian

Can we all just take a moment and appreciate the fact that Adrian is, in fact, one of the best things to happen to this series.? He is super cool. He uses spirit. He is quiet emotional even if he tries to be the most annoying person in front of everybody he cares for and doesn’t. And ya’all have to know that such people are my favorite kind. (Yeah, remember Delilah Bard?)
And to whoever thinks he just wants to get Rose in bed, please open your eyes and start to count all the things he has done for her just because she wanted it, not because she asked him to, and not because he could. He’s just so cutesy and lovable and I wish Mead gave him more chance in the series. He needs a bigger role _/\_

• Christian

…. is my next favorite. Correction- my first favorite character. See how I skipped all the main characters and settled for these two here? Because Mead’s characters are all appealing until she decides to put them on the spotlight.

Anyone who could make a joke at Adrian’s expense ranked high on Christian’s list

Christian is a side character, but an important one. He is a badass, unafraid, insecure, is faulty for all the right reasons and I just love him because he can be so sweet at times. I especially had loved his connection with Rose in Frostbite, but then on Mead kind of decided to put him on rest. AND I AM NOT HAPPY. Why can’t there be more of Christian and Adrian even?. Why does it have to be always about Rose, Rose and Rose and (oh I almost forgot) an awful lot of Dimitri? Let’s all unite for Christian and please LET THERE BE MORE OF HIM IN THE UPCOMING BOOKS, because, let’s face it, he’s damn charming.

Also, I love this love-hate relationship between Adrian and Christian. Their banter is so so adorable and hilarious!

Adrian was more eager than she was to discuss it – probably in the hopes of impressing Avery-and provided a quick rundown of some of spirit’s abilities, like auras and compulsion.
“And,” he added, “I can visit people in their dreams.”
Christian held up a hand. “Stop. I can feel there’s a comment coming on about how women already dream about you. I just ate, you know.”
“I wasn’t going to go there,” said Adrian. But he kind of looked like he wished he’d thought of the joke first.


See? I told you! They’re adorable!

• Lissa

Blood Promise is the fourth book in the series. And Vasilissa Dragomir is one of the two protagonists. So I must know something about her, hmm? Aside from the fact that she is the last in the Dragomir line and that she specializes in spirit, I honestly don’t have much idea about her. Because that is how underdeveloped and inconsistent her character is. Concentrating on Rose and deeming her to be the badass heroine every famous YA book these days sells upon, Richelle Mead seems to truly have forgotten she had another main character. Lissa has so less roles in the events of the book. Like I said, the non-existent romance managed to override every compelling plotline this story had.

And I don’t even like Lissa tbh. I don’t even know what I don’t like about her. Or probably that is just the reason I don’t like her. She is just so flat and bland and pushed aside by the author herself, that I haven’t actually gave much thought to her character. Uh, yeah. Whatever. She can be ignored and no one’s gonna mind.

• Janine Hathaway

If anyone has grown a bone AND a great character over the books, it’s got to be Janine Hathaway aka Rose’s mom. She is genuinely a surprise because I never thought she would be around much anymore and yeah her presence is a comfort as much to us as it is to Rose :)

I think that would be enough. This already has become my lengthiest review (I don’t get why I have so much to say about why I HATED a book but nothing about the book I LOVED?) Okay, don’t bother answering that.

So issuing my verdict, if you have come this far in the series, you might as well want to pick this up, because it’s in the same league as Mead’s previous books (only, I didn’t like this one). But I can also say, it is safe to avoid this book and continue towards its sequel, imo. Also considering the load of rewinding Mead’s gonna pull off in the next book, you probably wouldn’t even miss a thing. Come on now, I’m being honest! Skip it, read something else or go for the synopsis if you wish. There is nothing more you’re going to get by reading this book except maybe a few wasted hours?

Title: Private (Private, #1)
Author: Kate Brian
Publisher: Simon  Schuster Books for Young Readers
Bookshelves: books-for-children, chick-lit, i-didnt-get-the-point, school-boarding-genres, romance-lovey-dovey, young-adult, books-in-series
Bookshelves with positions: books-for-children (#49), chick-lit (#41), i-didnt-get-the-point (#20), school-boarding-genres (#27), romance-lovey-dovey (#57), young-adult (#96), books-in-series (#58)
My Review:
I had expected to love this because I usually love boarding-school genres. I loved Enid Blyton’s [b:The Twins at St Clare's|735693|The Twins at St Clare's (St Clare's, #1)|Enid Blyton|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1351754656s/735693.jpg|1065014] and [b:First Term at Malory Towers|190344|First Term at Malory Towers (Malory Towers, #1)|Enid Blyton|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1300285044s/190344.jpg|1026679] series. I also managed to read up to 10 books of the Sweet Valley High series by Francine Pascal (stopping finally when it felt repetitive), marveling at how easy and relatable they were to read. But Private just didn’t make it. It was an easy read, but the story was just out of place, I’m not sure I’ll read the rest or give it another chance.

THE STORY

Private tells the story through the eyes of Reed Brennan, who is admitted to Easton Academy, one of the top-ranked institutions in the country. Reed had never had many friends at her old school, so she wants to fit in at Easton real bad. She meets Constance, her blabbering roommate, and with her, the Billboard Girls. They’re the ‘cool’ girls at Easton’s. They live in a separate dormitory, excel at basically everything, and have colleges lined up behind them.

Reed somehow gets invited to sit for lunch with them once, and she is determined to do all it takes to stay. But Thomas, the boy she has a crush on, thinks that the Billboard girls are not worth her time and the girls in turn, thinks he is a douchebag. But Reed wants to make it all work, make the two odd ends meet.

WHY IT WAS BAD

○▪ Reed. The main protagonist was the narrator of the story but she didn’t even make her presence noticeable. She had very few dialogues and her personality, I’d rather not say. She is a spineless, self-depreciating idiot. Her obsessive stalking of the Billboard Girls was annoying, and so was the way she practically threw herself at Thomas. I’m sorry, but I prefer charismatic, confident girls. For me, Reed’s voice was just bland and forced.

○▪ The plot was a bit overdone. Everything was just about the Billboard girls and how cool they were (for reasons beyond me) and in the whole fuss, Reed just muted into the background.

○▪ Character development was zero. I’d falsely hoped that as the story progressed, Reed would pull herself up, grow a bit of confidence. But no, she was just the same as was everyone else.

WHAT WAS GOOD ABOUT IT

○▪ Constance, Reed’s roommate. She was the only fairly lovable character I could cling to, but she barely made any appearance throughout the book.

○▪The genre. The first reason I felt compelled to read this book. But this book belongs to the lower caste of the genre.

○▪ The fact that it got over quickly.

Title: Enlightened (Immortal Chronicles, #1)
Author: Samantha Britt
Bookshelves: fantasy, horror-paranormal, not-really-my-thing, romance-lovey-dovey, young-adult, review-copies, books-in-series
Bookshelves with positions: fantasy (#22), horror-paranormal (#47), not-really-my-thing (#4), romance-lovey-dovey (#53), young-adult (#89), review-copies (#1), books-in-series (#57)
My Review:
I received a copy of this book from the author in exchange of an honest review. Thank you [a:Samantha Britt|14186098|Samantha Britt|https://images.gr-assets.com/authors/1487272008p2/14186098.jpg] and YA Buddy Reader's Corner 🖤 for this opportunity.

2.5/5 stars. This was a quick, easy read. Nothing exciting, nothing to keep me hooked. The concept was good, but the writing was just okay-ish.

Darcie lives with her father, who researches ancient history. With a job that required him to travel all over the world, Darcie was mostly homeschooled. When she returns to Maine, she is eager to meet her friends Marie and her brother Kevin, who has been her crush since high school. But her attempt at normal life ends when she runs into the Immortal brothers - Thane, Lome and Des. She is mistaken to be the soulmate of Des by Thane, Lome and all other Immortals, but Des denies that she is The One. Darcie is taken to their home in Greece, where she learns of the life and history of Immortals, their quest for power, and the rebellion which has been building up against the trio. Either, she has to trust her abductors and stay wih them, or question their intentions and risk her life by returning home.

Thoughts

(*) The writing wasn't great. Maybe it's the mistake of the ebook or something, but the writing was incredibly plain. It sounded too childish, but that improved as the book progressed. And there were also some grammar errors in the beginning. The repeated use of 'the teenager', 'the young girl', 'the petite blond', to refer to the characters made for an uncomfortable read. All the time, I was like, "Yeah, there comes the brunette" or "Uh-huh, she's still a teenager". Honestly, it was unappealing. The lack of mastery in the use of pronouns and nouns is depicted clearly. Here's an example -
"The young woman tilted her head and used her dark, round eyes to observe Darcie" Now imagine 'the young woman' in every other sentence, while she's still there. You get my point?

(*) The concept for the story was imaginative. Even if controversial, the idea of Immortals seemed interesting. But I think, it could have been a bit more developed, like making an entire universe, instead of just another species would've worked better or something. I don't know, it's just a thought.

(*)The plot lacked substance. There wasn't much happening in the story. I was oddly reminded of [b:The Twilight Saga|3090465|The Twilight Saga (Twilight, #1-4)|Stephenie Meyer|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1327930511s/3090465.jpg|6440505], and [b:Dark Promise|15765786|Dark Promise (Between Worlds, #1)|Julia Crane|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1343025776s/15765786.jpg|21469969] while reading the book (both were well-written compared to this one btw). The plot was eerily similar. Paranormal beings, an awkward teen, a (possible) love traingle, abduction, attempt at murder, saved at the last moment - all felt the same.

(*)The charcaters. The characters aren't all that well-developed, but I can see that might happen in the next book. Also, even if Darcie might not have been the best of heriones, I loved the way the author used her charcater to answer the reader's questions. Like, a moment we would be reading something and a doubt pops to mind, we'd find Darcie asking the same. It made her more relateable and interesting.

Overall this book wasn't anything extraordinary, a bit confusing at times and I might just pick up the next book, MIGHT.

Author: Steve Brezenoff

Title: The Queen (The Selection, #0.4)
Author: Kiera Cass
My Review:
Another one of The Selection series? A book on Queen Amberly? Yes please!

The Queen is the story of Queen Amberly, a glimpse of her life while she was competing in the selection for Prince Clarkson’s hand. We get to see her life, her family and the real Amberly beneath all the façade of grandiose we saw of her in The Selection.

It was plainly obvious that Amberly was going to be the queen but it still was delightful to read of how she came to the throne. Prince Clarkson doesn’t seem as bad as he was, as a king. But his thirst for power and his desire to have control is obvious here too, even though the impact is slightly lessened while seeing it through the rose-colored eyes of Amberly.

Eitherway, this was fun and delightful :)

Title: Vampire Academy (Vampire Academy, #1)
Author: Richelle Mead
Bookshelves: adapted-to-tv-movie, chick-lit, horror-paranormal, fantasy, romance-lovey-dovey, young-adult, books-in-series
Bookshelves with positions: adapted-to-tv-movie (#12), chick-lit (#48), horror-paranormal (#52), fantasy (#27), romance-lovey-dovey (#70), young-adult (#111), books-in-series (#56)
My Review:
This book was a weird blend of many other books, but in the end, it did manage to standout on its own.

Vampire Academy is set in a parallel universe, where there are four species of humans – Dhampirs, Morois, Strigois and normal human beings. Dhampirs are The Guardians, Morois are the royal and non-royal blood-drinkers, and Strigois are the immortals – the evil ones.

THE PLOT

Vasilissa is a princess of the Moroi world. She runs away with her guardian Rose to lead life among the humans, but they are found and brought back to St. Vladimir’s Academy. The Academy focuses on teaching morals and survival skills to the Dhampirs and Morois. The Morois are in constant threat from the Strigois, who are determined to overpower them and rule the world.

Rose and Lissa are connected by a telepathic bond. Lissa has secret powers which might make her a star, or a target. Rose has to learn everything she can from her personal instructor Dimitri – on whom she has a crush on – to keep Lissa safe. But from what? Why are they constantly threatened? Who is behind the threats?

MY THOUGHTS

- Rose. One of the most unlikeable protagonists I’ve read in a while. Her character was highly judgemental, hypocritic, and even with all these characteristics - one-dimensional.

She is a complete anti-feministic feminist. Her reckless attitude is very much forced, her obsession with boys borders on slutty, and her objectification of woman bodies is unforgiveable. I mean, look at this? –

Here, among the slim and small-chested Moroi girls, certain features—meaning my larger breasts and more defined hips—stood out. I knew I was pretty: but to Moroi boys, my body was more than just pretty: it was sexy in a risqué way. Dhampirs were an exotic conquest, a novelty all Moroi boys wanted to “try”.


- Lissa. An important character with no redeeming qualities, has very little ‘actual’ role in the book. She was given so little part in the story that I really don’t know anything to say about her character. But atleast, the times she did make an appearance, she was much more tolerable and likeable than Rose.

- The plot. Not much actually happened in the book, until the end. The ending was quite surprising and executed well compared to the rest of the story. But for most part, the book is just a high-school chick-flick drama, about boys and parties and sex, usual girl-girl banters and crush-on-teacher sorta things. There was lot less action than expected. The plot, to me, seemed like strands picked up from fantasies like Harry Potter, Twilight and Shades of Magic series.

- The narrative. Narrated from Rose’s pov, I felt that the whole plot lacked an esteem which otherwise could have been better. Like, there is very little focus on world-building and character development. Rose’s tone doesn’t match with the whole atmosphere which is paranorlmal-istic. But her narration was interesting too, straight-to-the-point and easy to follow. The writing was good, but it would have suited a contemporary book better, rather than a fantasy.

Overall, this book was an interesting read, suitable for fans of Twilight series. The characters were a bit flat, but plotwise, it was promising and just managed to convince me to pick up the next book.

Title: The First Horror (99 Fear Street: The House of Evil, #1)
Author: R.L. Stine
Bookshelves: books-for-children, drama-overloaded, horror-paranormal, liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure, young-adult, books-in-series
Bookshelves with positions: books-for-children (#46), drama-overloaded (#11), horror-paranormal (#48), liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure (#16), young-adult (#91), books-in-series (#54)
My Review:
I've only read R.L Stine's Goosebumps books, this was my first Fear Street novel.

The First Horror tells the story of the Frasier family, who are moving to the new house 99, Fear Street in Shadyside. To their disappointment, the house is creepy, dark and very old. Mr. Frasier puts them all to work on the house to make it liveable. Cally, Kody and James do their best to hide their contempt towads their new house. But scary things happen. Accident after accident, and one day Cubby, James's dog disappears. The creepy story Cally hears from Anthony, a boy in town, makes her believe Kody's concerns about ghosts. What is wrong? Why can they hear Cubby's barking, but not find him? And where did James disappear?

I found the characters very annoying, their dialogues abrupt. The story in itself was quite engaging. But it wasn't as scary as I hoped. Would definitely read the second book to find out what happens next.

Title: The Favourite (The Selection, #2.6)
Author: Kiera Cass
My Review:
I didn't expect a book from Marlee's pov. It was sweet and refreshing just as I hoped

Even if the romance seemed a bit too unrealistic. Or let's say the book tries too hard to be perfect. Everything is just spot on and right.
I must also say that whoever Kiera Cass writes as, she sounds just like America. Maybe I have got too used to her tone, but Marlee, Eadlyn, Amberlee - their voices just sounded same to me. Furthermore the characterization in this book felt a bit flat.

Well, for a novella, I must say it was enjoyable enough.

Title: The Prince (The Selection, #0.5)
Author: Kiera Cass
My Review:
Prince Maxon was one of my favorite characters in The Selection series, and that was one reason I was excited to read Maxon's view of it all. But well, I think reading this book changed my opinion of Maxon.



In The Prince, Prince Maxon is all set and prepared for one of the biggest decisions he'd have to make in life - the one of his wife. Seeking love and finding the right person is no small job. When Princess Daphne confesses her love and asks Maxon not to go on with the Selection, he is confused. Is it his true love? Has he found love and let go of it? Would he be able to find his one true soulmate among the 35 possible girls in the Selection?

I thought this book just wiped off the Mr.Perfect title I had associated to Maxon. Prince Maxon was a bit cowardly and lacked any personality I saw in The Selection. Princess Daphne was as shitty and arrogant as Eadlyn in The Heir. I couldn't connect with the characters. And also the royal family is made to be this perfect family, which aIf it was supposed to give us an insight into the perfect life of Maxon, it failed. The character of Maxon lacked the charisma, but America had it in abundance. I guess, reading about someone else in one's pov, makes them seem better than they actually are. Well that's how it was for me.

Would I recommend it? Yes, but keep in mind that there is a possibility of being disappointed.
2.5/5 stars

Title: The Heir (The Selection, #4)
Author: Kiera Cass
Bookshelves: chick-lit, liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure, read-always-one-author-challenge, romance-lovey-dovey, young-adult, books-in-series
Bookshelves with positions: chick-lit (#42), liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure (#19), read-always-one-author-challenge (#3), romance-lovey-dovey (#59), young-adult (#99), books-in-series (#53)
My Review:
I’m not sure anyone knows what they’re looking for until they find it


This book was an unexpected continuation to The Selection series. While I was sure there was nothing more left of America and Maxon’s story that could probably make the series better, I actually loved the idea of The Heir. It was a quick, delectable, comforting read. Nothing eventful or exciting - Just a bundle of warm memories.

PLOT

The Heir follows Eadlyn Schreave, the firstborn twin of Queen America and King Maxon of Illea. Her brother Ahren, was born seven minutes after her, which made her The Heir to the kingdom of Illea. Being brought up to believe she was the most powerful person in the world, Eadlyn is a bit arrogant and outspoken.
To lull the uprising in the country, Maxon and America advise her to organize a Selection, thinking it would distract the public and also hoping Eadlyn would find a good match. Eadlyn, as much as she is opposed to the idea, agrees, if only to please her father. In the process, Eadlyn discovers more of herself and others.

MY THOUGHTS

○•It was soo good to see Maxon and America again. Even if it isn’t the happily-ever-after I might have wanted for them, it was wonderful to see them happy and so in love after all these years.

○•The character development was planned very well. Eadlyn grows up from her arrogant self, to discover a side of her, which she never thought she had. I really hated her in the beginning, but as the story progressed, it was easier to see why she was the way she was.

○•I loved Eadlyn’s brothers. Ahren was a sweetheart and was happy for him when he eloped with Camille, and left the shadow of his sister. She WAS a bit controlling. Kaden was a genius - a cute geek and Osden was a lovable prankster. The relationship they had between them was adorable.

○•The life of the royalty was potrayed unrealistically. I think the author downplayed the role of a king and queen in a monarchy. It was made to feel as if their only duty was to dress up and look good for the public. (Yes, there was paperworks and stuff mentioned, but it still doesn’t make a clear point of how tough it actually is to rule a country.)

○•It simply lacked a good plot. The whole selection process was repeated, and while it wasn’t all that boring, it just wasn’t exciting or anything new. I would’ve expected more thought, something interesting to happen, but it didn’t. But where it lacks in creativity, it makes up with comfort. I guess that’s the whole point of this book, a nostalgic trip through The Selection lane.

I knew the water would get rid of the mess, and I knew it would take away the smell, but no amount of scrubbing would ever wash away this memory.


All things considered, The Heir is not my favorite book of the series, it just was a comfortable read. For anyone who enjoyed the first three books, this book might be appealing, but otherwise, I’d advice not to bother.2.5/5 stars

Title: Dark Promise (Between Worlds, #1)
Author: Julia Crane
My Review:
2.5/5 stars
Well, that was a quick and uneventful read. I had braced myself for possibilities of surprises and action, but there was none.

OVERVIEW
Dark Promise is a paranormal romance. Rylie McCallister is a soon-to-be sixteen year old. Her parents are loving and supportive, so is her best friend. Her boyfriend Adam is the most caring and handsome guy. Basically her life is just perfect, until it's not.

The day before her sixteenth birthday, a strange woman named Azura visits her family and reveals to her that she is actually her daughter. Not a human, but a 'light faery'. Her transformation would be complete on her sixteenth birthday, when she'll sprout wings, her ears will become pointed, and her skin flawless. Her name is actually Oleander. The star-shaped birthmark on her forehead wasn't a normal birthmark, but the sign of an Aurorian faery with special powers. Her real faery father had promised her to Varwik, the leader of the dark faery world hoping to gain access to the powers of the dark faeries. Not wanting her daughter to be given to the dark world, Azura had traded her daughter to the newborn dead daughter of the McCallisters to make Varwik believe that she died in birth. She has been watching Rylie grow ever since.

Azura warns Rylie that once she becomes a faery, other faeries could detect her and the dark faery would come after her. Soon enough, the day after her sixteenth birthday, Rylie is kidnapped by dark faeries and bought to Varwik's castle. Varwik offers her an impossible choice - either die and let her powers die with her, or marry his seventeen year old son Kallan.

Rylie is stuck between the two worlds. She badly wants to return home, and she misses Adam. But Kallan doesn't seem like a bad guy. What would she do? What were her powers that Varwik was so afraid of? How could she survive?

THOUGHTS
The starting was slow. The prologue practically tells the whole story, so there are no surprises.
All the first few chapters, Rylie talks about her perfect life, and it was damn boring. And next when she transforms into a faery, for about ten pages we're in front of the mirror.
The romance was cheesy. There was absolutely no chemistry between Adam and Rylie. They couldn't stand each other for five seconds without kissing. Everyone else was like,



So, it was after 70% of the book, that the story actually moved on. The story had so much potential, but the author focused solely on the sloppy romance. I wish the author hadn't brought on a love triangle and instead gave us some more insight to the faery world. The dark faery world didn't seem all that dark, and Oleander was actually roaming the gardens when she was suposed to a prisoner. (Don't worry these aren't even spoilers).

The characters lacked depth, except maybe Kallan. Rylie was the least lovable one. And her parents, the McCallisters, the way they took the news of their daughter being a faery surprisingly and unbelievably well, was unrealistic.

VERDICT
All said, the story lacked purpose halfway through the book and became yet another love triangle. But because I'm human and I am curious, I just might pick up the sequel.

Title: The Selection (The Selection, #1)
Author: Kiera Cass
Bookshelves: chick-lit, dystopia, loved-the-protagonist, romance-lovey-dovey, young-adult, liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure, read-always-one-author-challenge, books-in-series
Bookshelves with positions: chick-lit (#36), dystopia (#9), loved-the-protagonist (#16), romance-lovey-dovey (#52), young-adult (#83), liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure (#14), read-always-one-author-challenge (#9), books-in-series (#47)
My Review:
This wasn't anything new. I know, I know it is very popular and all, but really it just felt like another book to have come up just at the beginning of the era of dystopian books and managed to gather fans.

America Singer (really? What kinda name is that?) is a 'four' in the country of Illèa, where people are divided by castes, as numbers. When the letter arrives at her house, stating she would be one of the many woman competing to be the queen, her family is excited. Prince Maxon would chose from one of the thirty five young ladies who make it to the Selection to be his queen, and the family of the girl would directly be promoted as Ones. But America isn't excited at the prospect of leaving her loving and handsome boyfriend Aspen, a Six, to compete to be the queen of someone she doesn't even know.
She hesitantly signs the letter at her family and Aspen's insistance and is surprised when she is selected. America and the thirty five other selected girls would have to stay at the palace during the course of the Selection. When Aspen breaks up with her saying she deserves more than him, America is heartbroken. And Prince Maxon isn't as boring as she thought. But when Aspen turns up at the palace, she has to make the decision - either accept him and throwaway her chances, or be the queen and live a luxurious life.

My thoughts -
◇• The writing style was incredibly smooth, albeit plain. I loved that it never got boring to read even when the story dragged out a bit.

◇•The story was dull and lacking in substance. To me it was just a dystopia, weaved up from the fame of the likes like [b:The Hunger Games|2767052|The Hunger Games (The Hunger Games, #1)|Suzanne Collins|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1447303603s/2767052.jpg|2792775]. The similarities are striking. A dystopian country, people divided as numbers, a competition. There was nothing new, which was what I had hoped while diving into the story.

◇•There was little to no focus on relationships. There was really no relations present, with maybe one exception of America and her sister. Throughout the story, what we ever get to see is America and her problems. Thankfully, she didn't come across as whiny.

◇•The ending. I felt kind of cheated. Nothing really happened in the story. We MUST read the next book to make a sense of anything that has happened. I hate it when we are forced to read sequels. It is unfair! The ending was this big cliffhanger that you really HAVE to read the next book. The story ends when the group of selected girls are down to six.

Overall, this book was an easy, likable read. I liked the main character enough to make me curious as to what happens next. The Selection, would be for people who wants to read something along The Hunger Games, but with lot less action.
Recommended For: Fans of dystopia without action, fans of The Hunger Games
