Author: Judy Blume

Title: A Conjuring of Light (Shades of Magic, #3)
Author: V.E. Schwab
Bookshelves: adventure, drama-overloaded, fantasy, i-need-a-movie, liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure, loved-the-protagonist, made-me-cry, really-liked-it, romance-lovey-dovey, characters-that-hold-my-heart, hopefully-more-to-come, i-need-the-book, young-adult, writing-to-die-for, could-have-been-better, spiralling-downward, books-in-series
Bookshelves with positions: adventure (#31), drama-overloaded (#15), fantasy (#26), i-need-a-movie (#10), liked-it-but-i-am-not-sure (#23), loved-the-protagonist (#22), made-me-cry (#29), really-liked-it (#65), romance-lovey-dovey (#66), characters-that-hold-my-heart (#2), hopefully-more-to-come (#5), i-need-the-book (#8), young-adult (#116), writing-to-die-for (#4), could-have-been-better (#1), spiralling-downward (#2), books-in-series (#33)
My Review:
I have some very conflicting feelings towards this book. I know I liked it, but I also know that it wasn’t enough. This trilogy gave me characters I love so much, but I don’t want that attachment to pollute my actual opinion that this book WASN’T GOOD ENOUGH .

With the overwhelming feeling I had after reading AGoS, (you can check my review of it here), I had set my expectations higher for this, and if you can’t tell yet, I’m a bit disappointed.

THE PLOT

The story starts just the moment where the second book stops.

Red London is falling.

Magic and Power is a deadly combination. The Shadow King, in a grim determination to take over the kingdom, has brought darkness all over the place. His magic is dark and powerful, and it would take more than one Antari and a definite amount of planning to defeat him.

Kell, Lila, Holland and Alucard have discovered a way to defeat Osaron aka The Shadow King, and in their search for a magical artifact, their quest to bring back peace and order, they find power, trouble, witness more than one death AND learn their strengths and weaknesses.

MY THOUGHTS

The best thing about this book? Undoubtedly,

HOLLAND

If the first book was mostly about Kell, and the second book about Lila, in this book we get to see Holland quite often. And unlike Kell and Lila, there is a heartbreaking backstory which brings in all the mystery, grief, and adds an insurmountable depth to Holland’s character.

Holland said nothing, but made his way straight toward the hold. Lila watched him go.
I still don’t trust you, she thought.
As if he could feel the weight of her gaze, Holland glanced back over his shoulder.
You do not know me, his gaze seemed to say.
You do not know me at all.


I loved every moment of his presence, his slightly arrogant attitude, his demeanor, and the more everyone showed their distaste for him, the more I loved him.


“What?” demanded Holland.
“It’s nice,” said Kell, “to meet someone like me.”
Holland frowned. “I am not like you,” he said, and walked away.


But I’m so very disappointed at the way his story ended. We never got to see a moment where he actually lived his own life. Schwab used his character and carved out a tragic-hero kinda story for him and it is just so unfair! Holland, the Antari, the invincible one, deserved better. So much better. He definitely does not deserve to be the author’s puppet to be used against us, to be a tear-jerking plot device. NO. Just NO


The bodies piled. Athos watched. Astrid grinned.
Holland’s hand moved on its puppet string.
And his mind screamed until it finally lost its voice.


Almost half the time I cried through this book (that is still a lot!), it was for Holland. AND I JUST CAN’T GET ENOUGH OF HIM, I NEEEEED MOOOREE. PLEASE SCHWAB, REWRITE THE STORY BEFORE IT GETS ETCHED IN MY MEMORYYY

Another good thing about this book, the depth of the relationships. This is not just about the romantic interests, I’m talking about the general bond of the characters with each other. It was so so good, and so full of emotions. No it isn’t like they are meant to actually be this deep, but it kinda just happened. Over the course of the books, the bond between the characters HAVE GROWN INTO YOU, THAT YOU CAN JUST FEEL IT OOZING OFF THE PAGE. Like, the bond between Kell-Holland, Alucard-Kell, Rhy-Alucard, Lila-Holland and even most of the side characters like Hastra and Lenos. The characterization is brilliant, mesmerizing.

"You know, I still don’t like you" said Kell.
Alucard breathed in relief. "Don’t worry, the feeling is mutual"


Okay, now that we have got the Holland and the relationships part, let’s move forward shall we?

As always, Schwab’s writing was amazing. But the thing is, when the whole thing comes down to the STORY everything crashes down. Because, this book is almost 700 pages long and the story it tells could actually have been a 300 pages or less. That is how non-existent and downplayed it is.

We have this huge villain, The Shadow King, but I really can’t think of that many reasons why he is terrible. Osaron’s character, at one point simply seemed like a whining child, a kid claiming to be an adult. And since he was supposedly the main plot device, it just didn’t work out.

Sometimes the story seemed dragged-out, some parts were really unnecessary. And the suspense, the climax? It was the biggest disappointment. Every moment I felt the plot crumbling, I kept telling myself that the ending would be worth it, that the climax would blow me away. BUT THE THING IS, THE WHOLE BOOK BUILDS UP SO VERY SLOWLY UPTO THAT POINT, AND IT JUST KINDA BROKE DOWN WITH THE WEIGHT.

The plot devices here were really very few – a villain, an idea to kill him, a journey to work it out, death, death and more death (which were all unnecessary), and finally the unequivocal ‘Happily Ever-After’. I don’t know, but 700+ pages of a promising story which it failed to deliver has made me annoyed.

Some of the other things that went through my mind-
▪ The portrayal of religion is done in a real, subtle way. It gives the readers a chance to comprehend it whichever way they want. And I applaud Schwab for that.
▪ Did anyone notice that, Alucard is Dracula spelt backward?
▪ I couldn’t help thinking why Osaron, a piece of magic gone horribly wrong, was repeatedly mentioned as ‘he’, I mean it isn’t even human right?
▪ The three Antaris are so much similar in a way. I mean, they’re all the most powerful magicians in the world, but no one thirsts for power. All they need and ask for is FREEDOM. And that’s awesome.
▪ Even if Kell doesn’t want to, I still need to know his past. Schwab could have given it as a side story. What would people think if I say Kell is one of my favorite characters but I don’t have any idea about his past? -.-
▪ Also what about Lila? What’s the deal with her? How did she get the brown eye? There could have been some more details of her past too.
▪ Rhy’s character development is amazing!
▪ I couldn’t help comparing this trilogy to HP. All the similarities!

Overall, This book was an enjoyable read. Sure I wasn’t totally satisfied and there were parts that could have been better. But I did love the way it wrapped up. I love the characters.
Now that I’ve completed the trilogy, it is safe to say that it is nowhere as good as the Harry Potter series, but it does stand alone on its own. 3.5/5 stars.

Title: Chasing the Beta (Small Town, #2)
Author: Jessica  Edwards
Bookshelves: chick-lit, drama-overloaded, horror-paranormal, hopefully-more-to-come, mature-stuff, really-liked-it, review-copies, romance-lovey-dovey, young-adult, books-in-series
Bookshelves with positions: chick-lit (#49), drama-overloaded (#17), horror-paranormal (#53), hopefully-more-to-come (#4), mature-stuff (#19), really-liked-it (#67), review-copies (#5), romance-lovey-dovey (#72), young-adult (#113), books-in-series (#32)
My Review:
What?! SOMEONE PLEASE TELL ME THE THIRD BOOK IS OUT!! Why did you have to do this Jessica Edwards? I need to know what happens. NOW.

This book was better than the first one, though a bit predictable. I guessed most of the story right away, but that didn't stop me from enjoying it.

The plot starts right where the first book ends. After losing her mother to the mass murderer, Alice has no idea how to go on with her life. With her best friend Sam, brutally attacked, and in bed, Alice has no option other than to stay with Ryder and the wolves at his house. Adding to her misery, is the information that her father has been called to town. A father – whom she hasn't ever known, who left her and her mother even before she was born. Then there is Max, with all his lies, who is still begging her for forgiveness.

Alice cannot let the murders go on. Who is the killer? Who might be behind the attacks? And, WHY?


- I loved the quick pace of the book. It was such an easy read. One moment I was just started, and the next I know, it finished!

- I love Alice. She isn't made to be a badass she isn't.

- But she stands up for herself, and that's admirable!

- And SAM. Where was Sam for most part of the book?

- Gosh, I missed her.

- Ryder was annoying with his protective stance sometimes.

- But then he would act totally adorable, and I’d forgive him too soon.

- I wish Kellan gets what he deserves. And he deserves something good!

- Bane is one of my favorites too. He is totally the arrogant guy girls eye more than the hero. Can’t blame Sam!

- Max wasn’t creepy at all in this book. He was really good actually.

- But, Mr. EDMUND. That guy seriously beats Voldemort with his creepiness!

- And I hate every bit of him.

- I hope he rots in hell for being the mastermind in all the murders. And for what? To punish Alice for something which isn't even her fault!

- Now there is also Mark, I wish I could hate him,

- But for the very few moments he had in the book, I liked him.

- About that damn ENDING. I guessed right all along.

- I wish I was wrong though. It would have been better that way.

- But I still loved the book.

- And I need the third one rn!

- Please, Jessica, make my wait last shorter!

Update: The third book is out today and I CANT WAIT

Title: Frostbite (Vampire Academy, #2)
Author: Richelle Mead
Bookshelves: adventure, drama-overloaded, fantasy, horror-paranormal, made-me-cry, made-me-lol, really-liked-it, romance-lovey-dovey, young-adult, books-in-series
Bookshelves with positions: adventure (#32), drama-overloaded (#19), fantasy (#29), horror-paranormal (#54), made-me-cry (#32), made-me-lol (#14), really-liked-it (#69), romance-lovey-dovey (#75), young-adult (#115), books-in-series (#24)
My Review:
How delightful! 😍😍 After Vampire Academy, I knew better than to keep high expectations for this. But then Mead just took a leap and wrote a wonderful sequel. THIS BOOK. I’m not saying this was absolutely riveting. But comparing to the first book, I can safely say, this series is definitely getting better. 4/5 stars

The book takes off with a new attack on the Moroi world, by the evil Strigois –immortal vampires –who are trying to gain power by aiming the Royals one by one. To keep everyone safe, and to have a moment of fun, the students and staff at St. Vladimir’s, along with the royal families go on a skiing trip. They stay at a well-guarded luxurious resort.

Rose, being tutored by Dimitri, is working on honing her self-control and defense skills. Lissa, the last of the Dragomirs, is still on pills to keep her magic down, her spirit in control. Meanwhile, Mason, who has a huge crush on Rose decides to act on an impulse to take off some Strigois. He leaves off to town, with two others. Rose, along with Christian, Lissa’s boyfriend hunts them down and finds them. On their way back though, they are kidnapped by Strigois. How will they escape? What do the Strigois want?

Be prepared for some cool action and adventure. The beginning as usual, is a dragged on, dramatic high-school stuff. But throughout this drama, Mead builds up a really good foundation for the action in the end. I am starting to love this style of hers. The ending had me at edge.

Rose’s character development is amazing. But sometimes, she just switches personalities, in the span of a moment. It was a bit unrealistic and difficult to follow. The writing style has improved vastly, and I can see the book has developed a sense of purpose which it completely lacked in the first book. Even if the plot is highly predictable, the characters act totally oblivious to the twists. It was a bit annoying at times.

What I loved the most? – The understanding and chemistry between Rose and Christian. THAT WAS SO FREAKING GOOD. I was literally screaming my head off during those scenes. The ending was mindblowing. Predictable, yes. But it was very thrilling, a definite mind-effer. And MASON. My God! I didn’t realize he was my favorite person until the end. Mead unabashedly crushed my heart.
Why didn’t I get more of Christian?? He was absent for most part of the book. I loved every moment of his presence! Also, I might not be the biggest fan of Dimitri and Rose together. Duh.

Overall, a brilliant sequel to the first book in what I hope would be a really good series. I have to read the rest of the books soon. Also, I forgot to mention, EVEN IF YOU DIDN’T READ THE FIRST BOOK, YOU CAN SAFELY START WITH THIS ONE. The prologue is pretty much all you need to know about the series. Good Luck!

P.S Sorry, this review is more of a rambling. If you are still reading this, Thank You for putting up with my lack of organizing skills! ;)

Title: Shadow Kiss (Vampire Academy, #3)
Author: Richelle Mead
Bookshelves: characters-that-hold-my-heart, chick-lit, drama-overloaded, dystopia, horror-paranormal, i-need-a-movie, really-liked-it, romance-lovey-dovey, young-adult, books-in-series
Bookshelves with positions: characters-that-hold-my-heart (#4), chick-lit (#50), drama-overloaded (#20), dystopia (#12), horror-paranormal (#55), i-need-a-movie (#13), really-liked-it (#70), romance-lovey-dovey (#78), young-adult (#119), books-in-series (#23)
My Review:
Woah. This series is definitely improving. It still has so much bottled potential, so many unexplored territories that I can’t wait to read and discover more. Seriously, I never thought I was going to love this series. But Mead has a really consistent pattern of writing, of story-building, that I have gotten used to – it’s rhythmic, comfortable, adrenaline-jerking and enjoyable.

Shadow Kiss takes on after the events in Frostbite. The Strigoi attacks on the ski-trip had been unnerving. But this time, Rose and the elder Dhampirs have to go through the field experience – their final test before they can be officially declared as guardians. In the Field experience, Dhampirs are assigned to Moroi royals and have to follow them around like a real guardian. The test is when real Guardians dressed as Strigois pop up unexpectedly and test their reflexes and strength.

Rose is furious when she gets assigned to Christian instead of Lissa. But it doesn’t matter however, since those two are inseparable. Meanwhile, Rose’s love life is turning out more and more confusing. Adrian and Lissa start practicing their spirit-induced powers together and this gets Christian jealous. On the other hand, some of the Moroi royals have ganged up and started practicing magic for defense.
Rose has a tough life, with field experience, her perpetual visions of Mason’s ghost and Strigoi attacks that come at all the wrong time and wreak havoc like it has never before.

My Thoughts:

- I am starting to like Rose for real. Her character development knows no bounds.
- Like, she is such a badass and at the same time she feels so realistic.
- Ah, and how about all other characters?
- Like, Christian.
- I SO LOVE HIM
- But no, Mead forgot him for most part of the story.
- Why is there so less of so many characters?
- For instance, take Adrian.
- He may be spoilt all he wants, but HE IS MY FAVOURITE.
- Like, why is he even sticking up for Rose?
- And who knew, he had such a kind li’l heart in there?
- And that thing with Dimitri?
- I suspected it, since like, the FIRST BOOK?
- But that ending though? Ah, never in my dreams, ever.
- But still, why is this whole thing turned into just Romance and it’s after-effects in the end?
- I mean, there are bigger problems in the world, and all Rose wants to do is hunt a near-dead Dimitri?
- Sorry though, I will never get this thing about Love.
- Did I mention the whole book was like, COMPLETELY PREDICTABLE?
- Also, I’m quite sure I forgot to mention how much I want to read the next book.
- So yeah, you get the picture ;)
- Thanks for going through this with me, you can move on haha

Author: Stephanie Perkins
Bookshelves: chick-lit, loved-the-protagonist, made-me-lol, romance-lovey-dovey, contemporary, young-adult, school-boarding-genres, books-in-series
Bookshelves with positions: chick-lit (#24), loved-the-protagonist (#6), made-me-lol (#2), romance-lovey-dovey (#39), contemporary (#16), young-adult (#63), school-boarding-genres (#17), books-in-series (#18)
My Review:
*Warning - I'm not a professional reviewer. I'm just venting out my thoughts which wont even sound like a review, so, well, read the rest only if you are interested*

This book is good. Not Oh-my-god-I-cant-get-enough-of-it good, but Oh-okay-this-book-gave-me-the-feels good. It was witty, had a lovable protagonist, the side characters were adorable, and the romance was not melodramatic or exaggerated.

This book gave a virtual tour through Paris that I feel I wont even lose my way, once I'm actually there. Okay, not exactly, but you get it, right? Paris is described beautifully and it has become a dream destination for me (I even learnt some french!)

And Meredith, I loved that girl from the very beginning (Am I the only one? ). She's friendly, sporty, dream-like. She somehow reminded me of Eleanor of
[b: Eleanor & Park|15745753|Eleanor & Park|Rainbow Rowell|https://d.gr-assets.com/books/1341952742s/15745753.jpg|17225055] . I don't know how my mind related them, but they had some similarities. And I luuuurve Eleanor. (Do I sound weird? or gay? But I'm not)

I can see from most of the reviews, that people loved St. Clair. Why-Oh-Why? May I ask? Yeah, he's cute, beautiful (Is that even a fit description for a boy?) and has this really-good-hair according to Anna and all other people at SOAP. But he isn't a good boyfriend material. The best thing about him is his name : Etienne St. Clair. Isn't that lovely?

Stephanie could have done a better job, if she had given a better perspective of the side-characters, or described Anna's relations with her family. No, it isn't bad now, but it could have been better. Realistic, relate-able.

Overall, this book was a funny, feel-good romance. The writing was good, but somewhere it was also a bit disorganized. Or else, I would have come back for a re-read. Or maybe I still would. Duh! I'm so hypocritical. *Beg your pardon* *I know, I know, I'm a bad reviewer - I warned you, didn't I?*

So, what are you waiting for? Go read the book, you may love it, hate it, but it does value your time anyhow.

Okay darn, I'll just stop.

Title: My Sister's Bones
Author: Nuala Ellwood
Bookshelves: drama-overloaded, life-changing, made-me-cry, really-liked-it, suspense-thriller-mystery, i-need-a-movie, why-no-hype
Bookshelves with positions: drama-overloaded (#5), life-changing (#8), made-me-cry (#20), really-liked-it (#53), suspense-thriller-mystery (#21), i-need-a-movie (#6), why-no-hype (#6)
My Review:
Reading the title and subtitle, I had no idea what kind of book I was venturing into or what to expect. But what the book unfurled before me was something I could've never imagined.

Kate is a war reporter who has returned home to Herne Bay to set some affairs straight after the death of her mother. Her dad was a drunkard who beat her mom and her. After his death, her younger sister Sally becomes an alcoholic, resulting in her daughter Hannah running away from home. Sally's husband Paul has a hard time controlling her.

But Kate is haunted by her days in Syria. She has nightmares of the little boy Nidal, who she had become close to, and unfortunately died infront of her. As if the nightmares weren't enough, Kate sees a little boy in the house next door inhabited by an Iraqi refugee who denies she has children and insists her husband is away. She has a hard time separating dreams and realities and Paul helps her cope with it. Kate and Sally must reconcile their differences and learn the truth about their brother's death.
But after Kate leaves to Syria, she is reported dead. Sally must now do all that Kate has left undone in Herne Bay.

The novel started with a slow pace. Maybe it's my inexperience with psychological thrillers, but I felt kinda weird reading this; the beginning was slow and dragging, and then it suddenly becomes emotionally gripping to the point that I was forced to question my own sanity. The second half was a suspense thriller that kept me on edge and I gladly traded my precious night's sleep to find out what was going on.

The concept was really interesting. The author, without even trying hard, manages to convince us of the brutality of war. Kate's story seems impossible yet couldn't be more real. The novel gives us an insight into the life of a war reporter and the stress that goes with it. From all the war novels I've read, none of them had me convinced as well as this one of the affect of war on people. And it is not even a war novel!

Nuala Ellwood has done a brilliant job with the characters. Each of them has a realistic touch. It feels like we're living their life, especially of Kate and Sally. It's almost scary.

It is not so often that you come across a book, that grips you tight, twists your mind and churns your stomach, and yet makes you see the world for what it truly is. My Sister's Bones was one such book for me. If I wasn't put off by the writing style at the beginning of the book (it's not bad. It was just me, really!) I would've given it five stars.

Title: The Good Girls (The Perfectionists, #2)
Author: Sara Shepard
Bookshelves: contemporary, drama-overloaded, loved-the-protagonist, really-liked-it, suspense-thriller-mystery, young-adult, books-in-series
Bookshelves with positions: contemporary (#25), drama-overloaded (#8), loved-the-protagonist (#17), really-liked-it (#59), suspense-thriller-mystery (#25), young-adult (#85), books-in-series (#15)
My Review:
Oh. My. God. That was totally out of the blue. Even if my guess turned out to be right, I am still shaken by the way it turned out. For all the feels it gave me 4.5/5.

Ava, Caitlyn, Julie, Mackenzie and Parker are still the suspects on the Nolan Hotchkiss-Granger murder case. Their casual conversation not long ago, in the film studies class about whom each of them wanted dead, is being carried out one by one. First it was Nolan, then Parker's dad, then Ashley Ferguson. Everyone of them is killed just the way they had stupidly planned in that class. Who would it be if not one of them? Till now, all they did was be for each other and try to pick up evidences against the killer. But every evidence points to one of them. They must figure out who it is, before the remaining people on the list are attacked.

I had my doubts about the killer, in the beginning of the first book itself. And this book made it clear from the start that I was right. Yet, till the last page, it churned my mind to pulp. I was literally gasping all the way. Sara Shepard sure knows how to play with the minds of her readers.

The plot twist came out of nowhere, and I will have to reread the whole series now to make complete sense of it Turns out, Julie and Parker are the same people. Parker died a year ago and Julie suffered from an identity disorder, where she thought she was Parker and Julie at the same time.. Though, it does seem to have clichés, and the ending seemed a bit confusing, this book was an intense read all the same.

For all the mystery, thriller or even YA fans, this series is certainly not one to be missed.

Title: This Is Where the World Ends
Author: Amy    Zhang

Bookshelves with positions: chick-lit (#33), contemporary (#22), loved-the-protagonist (#13), made-me-cry (#22), really-liked-it (#55), why-no-hype (#3), young-adult (#76), characters-that-hold-my-heart (#13)

Title: Chasing the Omega (Small Town, #1)
Author: Jessica  Edwards
Bookshelves: fantasy, really-liked-it, romance-lovey-dovey, young-adult, suspense-thriller-mystery, freebies, review-copies, books-in-series
Bookshelves with positions: fantasy (#28), really-liked-it (#66), romance-lovey-dovey (#71), young-adult (#112), suspense-thriller-mystery (#29), freebies (#1), review-copies (#4), books-in-series (#12)
My Review:
Wow. I am pleasantly surprised that I loved this. Considering that I am not a big fan of shape shifters, that is. For a debut novel, Jessica Edwards has done a great job.


In Chasing The Omega we see Alice, who is bitten by a werewolf - turn into, and trying to cope with - her new life as a werewolf. She gets to know of the mysterious gang of four at school, who have a reputation for being weirdoes. Ryder, Bane, Kellan and Silver take sudden interest in her, and Alice finds herself intrigued by them. On the other hand, there is a murderous wolf in town who has already claimed lives. When Alice sees that her dearest ones are attacked, she sets out to find the killer herself.


- The book started off right along the path of action, and it was enough to keep me hooked.

- In the beginning, as we are introduced to the characters, there is a lot of descriptions about each of them which was very difficult to follow, and which – shamelessly – I forgot everything about.

- Like, why bother explaining a page on what each of them is wearing every single time?!

- But the writing improved gradually as the story progressed, and I found myself enjoying every bit.

- The romance seemed a bit rushed and I didn’t see much development there. It was confusing but interesting too.

- I’m also glad that it wasn’t the main focus of the story.

- The narration was done really well, but I didn’t actually connect with the characters emotionally.

- Some of the parts were a bit disconnected. And the characters went from being mature to being childish in the split of a second.

- But overall feel of the story was absolutely, POSITIVE.

- And btw, I’ve started reading the next book.

- Because, hell, the ending was compelling enough!

Title: The Guard (The Selection, #2.5)
Author: Kiera Cass
My Review:
"We know you are strong, but accepting help is its own kind of strength.”


This book was soo good! I have no idea why or how Kiera Cass manages to utterly disappoint me with a book, and then wow me with the other. She really is a kind of her own making.

The Guard is an insight into the tough life of Aspen as the palace guard. His take on the whole Selection process and hearing his side of the story was very refreshingly beautiful. His endless passion for all things is obvious. I loved the way he analyzed things in his own way, even if he wasn’t always right. Like, what he thought of King Clarkson -
"Of course the man with everything he could ever need or want didn’t understand why any average person might want the same chance”


Or about America’s dad –
'Out of the millions of words in the world, Mr. Singer always seemed to know how to pick the handful that made you feel like you mattered.’


That’s so very true! (As was seen in Mr. Singer’s letters to America)

I was stunned to see how perfectly Kiera Cass has worded each feeling and thoughts, and made them unbelievably real. This book was so beautifully written, I am slapping myself for ever doubting Cass’s mastery of words. She has this simple, lyrical prose, and yet she manages to hold so much depth and emotions in the very handful of the words she uses.

There was one thing I noticed though, like this –
I swear, I wanted to give my girl a medal.’ I mean, what is there to swear about? Such sentences were a bit repetitive. Not that I mind them :)

Through this book, I’ve also learned much more of the setting of The Selection. The rebel attacks as seen through the eyes of Aspen differ so much from America’s pov. Hearing about them from America sitting in a safe room wasn’t all that informative it seems!

I also was wondering how Aspen and Lucy became close, or how they could ever be a good match for each other – but this book has vanquished such doubts too. I can see for myself now, that they were meant to be.

Only problem with this book? Well, I really wished it was a bit longer. There were so many things I would have loved to see through Aspen’s eyes. Like, the end of the selection, America and Aspen’s marriage, or his reaction when he finds Marlee and Carter were still in the palace. Nevertheless, I can’t complain. It was just really good. 4.5/5 stars

Title: The Perfectionists (The Perfectionists, #1)
Author: Sara Shepard
Bookshelves: chick-lit, drama-overloaded, really-liked-it, school-boarding-genres, suspense-thriller-mystery, young-adult, books-in-series
Bookshelves with positions: chick-lit (#37), drama-overloaded (#7), really-liked-it (#58), school-boarding-genres (#25), suspense-thriller-mystery (#24), young-adult (#84), books-in-series (#10)
My Review:
I started this book without any expectations, and well, I wasn't disappointed at all. The suspense kept me up all night and I might have to sleep all day of exhaustion now *yawn*

Ava, Caitlyn, Julie, Mackenzie and Parker - the five of them goes to Beacon Heights High, a competitive school in Washington state. They aren't the best of friends, but when they're grouped up for a discussion in film studies class, they realise that they all have one thing in common - they hate Nolan Hotchkiss. Nolan has managed to wrong them all one way or other, and the girls plan to take revenge by pulling on a prank at his party. But things go horribly wrong when Nolan turns up dead after the party night, exactly the way they had planned.The girls start picking evidence against Mr. Granger, their film studies teacher, whom Nolan had been threatening. When they are sure of him and meet the police, it turns out Mr.Granger was killed the same night, moments after they left his house. Who is behind the murder? Why are they being framed?

The prologue was enough to pull me right into the story. The beginning got a bit confusing, with all the characters and their friends and boyfriends introduced to us out of nowhere. But the multiple povs of all the five protagonists made up for it. Sara Shepard has weaved a complicated suspense thriller with such ease, that it keeps your eyes glued to the page.
The characters and their emotions felt very real to me. The sheer reality of a competitive school-life was portrayed brilliantly. The suspense was also endearing even if my guesses were all totally wrong. (Let's just say, I'm not the best detective lol)

Even though, the actual culprit is not pointed out in the end, I wouldn't hesitate to read the next book to find out.

Title: A Darker Shade of Magic (Shades of Magic, #1)
Author: V.E. Schwab
Bookshelves: fantasy, i-need-the-book, made-me-cry, made-me-lol, really-liked-it, books-in-series
Bookshelves with positions: fantasy (#23), i-need-the-book (#4), made-me-cry (#26), made-me-lol (#10), really-liked-it (#61), books-in-series (#9)
My Review:
I hate to read hyped books. I truly do. It is VERY annoying when you are the last person on earth to read a book that’s been talked about for ages. It just plays with your mind, making you try and force yourself to like the book and be in everyone’s good books while constantly praying you don’t hate it, so as not to be the target of the immense fandom.



But I loved this book. It had its issues, yes, but in the end, I felt deprived and needy. I’m glad that ADSoM did that to me. I love it when books invoke such feelings.

EVERYONE knows what this book is about, but for ‘some’ of the everyone who don’t, I’ll summarize it for you :

There are four Londons in a parallel universe,
recognized by color – Grey (where magic is rare and people are ‘normal’), Red (where magic thrives along with its people), White (where magic is used to conquer and kill; ruled by the evil twins – Astrid and Athos Dane) and Black (once was full of magic and power; now extinct). These Londons have gateways from one to other, but only Antari’s can pass through them. They are a rare breed – only two are known, Kell and Holland.

Kell is of Red London and Holland is enslaved to the evil twin rulers of White London. They travel through the Londons carrying messages to and from the royals. But Kell has a habit of smuggling things, which his so-called brother Prince Rhy (of Red London) disapproves of. Kell is positive he won’t be caught, but then he is tricked, and ends up with the Vitari - a Black Stone – a powerful magical object from Black London.

Kell sets off to take the stone back to its native place, assisted by Delilah Bard, a gifted thief who is out to seek adventure. But he’s followed and attacked. Until the stone is discarded where no one can reach it, Kell and Lila would have to face the consequences.

THOUGHTS AT RANDOM

◇▪ The concept was very imaginative. The whole four-london-thing was really creative. And there were many other instances in the book which further proves Schwab’s creativity.

But the concept of MAGIC , with a LIFE OF ITS OWN was kinda scary. Like technology, maybe? We can be pretty much sure that it is consuming us, but if it had a life of its own, then humans are doomed. I felt the same here.

◇▪ The writing was engrossing. Even if the story started really slow, it picked up pace in the second half and was really entertaining to read.

◇▪ It lacked depth and complexity. I really wanted more of the world, the characters, of the world. But so less was offered. There isn’t much depth to the story. While the world-building is done carefully, it lacks in details. I need DEPTH, COMPLEXITY. I want to be able to describe all the Londons and it’s people in vivid detail, like I can about Hogwarts and the wizarding world.

◇▪ That COAT. No, I’m not talking about Kell’s coat here. It was wonderful, yes. But it isn’t possible to find one. What I want is Lila’s pirate coat. The one she bought from Calla. I. NEED. IT. *says the girl with zero bank balance**sigh*

◇▪ I hated the fact that Antaris had to cut themselves to travel around Londons. It was gross and took time to get used to.

THE CHARACTERS

◇▪ Kell wasn’t likeable. I found it hard to relate to, or love the main character. HE WAS QUITE A BLAND CHARACTER. There isn’t much we know about him, but seeing that he has a mysterious past life, I hope it gets cleared in the next book.

◇▪ Lila. One of the best things about this book. I loved her badass-ery. She’s really adventurous (a bit too much), kinda stupid and clever at the same time. She was the only character, who I could see was quite well developed, besides Rhy.

Rhy laughed silently. “I apologize for anything I might have done. I was not myself.”
“I apologize for shooting you in the leg,” said Lila. “I was myself entirely.”


◇▪ Rhy. He was the one, positive, normal, lovable character. Flirtatious. Handsome. Loyal.
I ugly cried when he died. (Oops! Was that spoiler-y? I assure you not.)

◇▪ Holland. I can’t seem to pull together my thoughts about him. He was manipulated to do things, but he did it with such cruelty - it makes me hate him. And love him. And I-donno-what. He’s a confusing character, even if he made little appearance in the book.

All said, A Darker shade of Magic was a delightful read. A bit difficult to get into, but once you do, all you can think about is picking up the next book.

Title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (Harry Potter, #3)
Author: J.K. Rowling
Bookshelves: books-i-own, all-time-favourites, fantasy, young-adult, books-in-series, characters-that-hold-my-heart, watched-the-movie-too
Bookshelves with positions: books-i-own (#1), all-time-favourites (#4), fantasy (#8), young-adult (#14), books-in-series (#6), characters-that-hold-my-heart (#11), watched-the-movie-too (#2)
My Review:
I need hagrid’s tablecloth to wipe the enormous happy tears. I have read this book more times than I can count, and yet they come each and every time, reminding me to be grateful to J.K Rowling for pulling me out of the labyrinth I was in, in my pre-Harry Potter days. For Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban was the first book I read in the series. Followed by Deathly Hallows. Even with my disorganized way of reading, I love this series as much as anyone else. And this book rightfully holds the credit for making me the reader I am today.

This is less of a review, and more of a personalized account of how I discovered my love for books.

So about four years ago, one summer vacation, I was in an agony, deciding what to read. There were some 10 books I had kept reading and rereading again and again, coz I didn’t have anything else. Correction – I had this one book, which looked very disinteresting to me. But when boredom got the better of me, I picked it up, started reading, and finished it in a day.

This book was what prodded me into reading more. That interest, the way a book pulled me into its pages - It made me realize that there was a vast world within the pages of books, that I was yet to discover. J.K Rowling, you deserve every accolade you’ve received and more.

There’s no point in telling what this book is about, so I’ll just say what is so special about it.

--There’s seriously no one else who can write like Rowling. Her perfect prose, wit, and humor, is a trademark in its own right.

--J.K Rowling is nothing short of a genius. To plot such a story - intricate, full of details, so brilliantly planned out – I can’t even describe my fascination. Every time I read this, there’s a new detail, a point I earlier missed. THAT SORT OF THOUGHTFULNESS AND DETAILING IS NOT EVEN HUMANLY POSSIBLE.

Okay okay, I’ll stop about JKR (it isn’t intentional, really! I just seem to have a crush on her – girl to girl)

Random Thoughts -

¤~Aunt Marge was beefy enough as it is, I don’t think that blow up made much of a difference, other than making her float.

¤~Ron certainly needs a muggle studies lesson. I mean, a telephone call? What do wizards do instead?

¤~I actually quite liked Stan. His slang is cute. To think that he joined the Dark Lord! *sigh*

¤~The best part of quidditch matches is Lee Jordan’s commentary.

¤~I was quite disappointed with Hermione’s boggart.

¤~Harry should have got full marks in divination exam. His prediction was completely accurate!

¤~I wonder how dementors communicate. Like, Fudge said he's gonna talk to them?

¤~Dumbledore is a phenomenon.

¤~I love Sirius. The last letter to Harry filled me up. That guy is seriously cool. Let him off people :/

So that’s it folks! Excuse me while I’m off to Hogwarts demanding my acceptance letter.

My Review:
This is the best in the series so far. I have no idea why this book had such a hold on me, considering I was not that happy with its prequels. But there it is - I AM IN LOVE WITH THIS BOOK Kiera Cass is my new favorite author. I love everything about her. I even read every word of her acknowledgements. They’re delightful!

The Plot

Continuing where The Elite left off, America has decided to chase Maxon, to fight for him. She has become sure of her feelings for Aspen and Maxon. But now she has to gain the approval of the public and The King.
With the rebels as fierce as ever, America has to fight her way to the throne, and hope to change her country for good.

Reading this book, I was a WRECK. The outbursts came from nowhere and were overwhelming. I guess, I’ll just let the gifs do the talking.

PLEASE DON’T READ AHEAD IF YOU DON’T WANT SPOILERS. You are warned.

My reactions while reading this book -

*- When America tried to seduce Maxon, and he LAUGHED.


*-When America got back at the king by saving Adam.


*-Seeing the girls and the queen playing dress-up.


*- Seeing America’s reaction when her dad died.


*-Reading her father’s letter.


*-When Maxon found out about Aspen and America.


*-When Maxon changed his mind about The One.


*-Reading Maxon’s letter to America.


*-When I found out Maxon was dead.


*-When the fairy tale ended with a happily-ever-after wedding.


Hah! I don’t think there’s anything more (well, there might have been, but finding gifs is a tough job guys!) Phew!

Title: Welcome to Dead House (Goosebumps, #1)
Author: R.L. Stine
Bookshelves: old-school-library-reads, goosebumps-frenzy, horror-paranormal, i-didnt-get-the-point, over-hyped, shit-crap-and-all-things-bad
Bookshelves with positions: old-school-library-reads (#64), goosebumps-frenzy (#34), horror-paranormal (#43), i-didnt-get-the-point (#27), over-hyped (#9), shit-crap-and-all-things-bad (#4)
My Review:
“We killed someone who was already dead.”

There, that one sentence just about sums up how ridiculous the concept of this book is.

I remember the time when I first started reading, which was some four years ago. Our school library was so poorly stocked. The only books it held were the many different editions of classic books and THESE. Goosebumps books. I used to read them and love them then, but now, I don’t even want to think I used to love them once.

The Plot

Amanda and Josh are not at all happy with their new house at Dark Falls. The town looks deserted, completely shady and eerie. But their parents insist the house is huge and cool.
Creepy things happen to them, and the kids in the neighborhood act strange. One extraordinarily creepy night, they find that all those friends they made, are already dead. And they want Josh and Amanda dead too..

Thoughts

- At one point, Amanda, the mc, thinks she’s more sensible and patient than her brother, BECAUSE SHE IS A GIRL

- Sounds reasonable right? Duh. I don’t see why boys aren’t considered sensible enough?

-The book was fairly readable, except, the writing was really uncool. Like, look at this –

“Your basketball is packed in one of these cartons,” Dad was saying. Then Josh said something. Then Dad said, “How should I know which one?” Then Josh said something. Then Dad said, “No, I don’t have time to look now. Believe it or not, your basketball isn’t at the top of my list.”


-Yeah that’s a real paragraph from the book. I CAN’T EVEN..

-Seems like R.L Stine has memorized every bit of how-to-write-a-horror-story manual. He has badly used every supposedly-scary trope there is.

* Dog barking at dead people? ✔
* Gross description of peeling skin and popping eyeballs? ✔
* Melting bodies? ✔
* Dead people afraid of light? What’s a halogen light, even? ✔
* Venturing to the cemetery at night and considering it ‘adventure’? ✔
* Century-old, nearly-dead trees? ✔

-But what I don’t really understand is the concept. It is ridiculous to say the least. Who on earth would agree moving to a house they supposedly inherited from a non-existent great-uncle? And, dead people living in a town? They aren’t even considered as ghosts. Why are they ‘dead’ then? What does dead mean? How come, they’re not anywhere else? If they’re already dead, what happens when they ‘melt away’? Ugh, questioning the plot devices of this book is sickening.


In short, if you decide to overlook the questionable plot and poor writing, this book might be enjoyable. Probably.

Title: Because You Love to Hate Me: 13 Tales of Villainy
Author: Amerie
My Review:
How do you rate an anthology? You rate it five stars because there was this absolutely stunning piece of writing that should be bill boarded elsewhere? Or you rate it one star, because one of the stories managed to piss you off in the most uncool fashion possible? Or do you just close your eyes and go by whichever rating the mouse is pointing at when you open your eyes?
Ugh, goodreads rating system is so very overrated people!


Now let’s steer back to this book. Here’s the deal. A booktuber challenges an author to write a villainy tale, and the author comes up with a matching story. The booktuber then comments on the story and the villain.

It is a collection of 13 short stories written by 13 famous (and not-so-famous) authors, who has awed us with their amazing books and had no business tending to short stories like the ones in here. Like, really, this book just about extinguished all my curiosity for short stories. It was a literal placard showcasing how unsatisfying short stories can be.

Or probably, it was a matter of expectations – I started this book, because it promised us a tales from the villain’s pov. So I was like, OMG this is my kinda book, I love Villians! I mean who doesn’t love to get a glimpse of the actual person behind all those façade of a villain? Like, who has watched The Dark Knight without rooting for The Joker instead of Batman? There is just something mysteriously intriguing about villians which is why this book piqued up my interest.

``We love to hate them and they hate to be loved, if only because being hated frees them from being good.’’


In a way, this book provides exactly what I expected it to. But what I forgot to consider was the fact that every villain is the hero of their own story.

Even if the whole concept was interesting, the execution failed to reach the readers. The booktubers comments felt totally unnecessary most of the times. The stories were made up like it was written just for completing the challenges. It lacked the originality I had expected with such an intriguing idea. Though some of the tales were really good, I’ve come to believe that whatever they say, short stories just don’t come up to full-length-novels. The characters are forgotten way too soon, the message goes awry and unrecognizable in a matter of moments. I may be wrong, but considering this book, I am completely right.

My favorite stories? –
• Sera by Nicola Yoon,
• Gwen and Art and Lance by Soman Chainani,
• Death Knell by Victoria Schwab (because the writing was amazing),
• You, You, it’s all about You by Adam Silvera.

And yeah, as I said, the comments got repetitive and boring after a while, but the final one, The Bad Girls Guide to Villainy by Steph Sinclair and Kat Kennedy was really cool! So there’s that. The villains are the heroes, some of the stories do nothing other than promote ‘villain-ism’ and the whole purpose of the story was kind of misinterpreted in one way or other.


Now, say, how do I rate this book? Since it wasn’t COMPLETELY bad, and since I loved some of the stories, I’ll go with goodreads standards and rate it 2/5 stars (it was okay). Read this if you have nothing better to read.

Title: What Light
Author: Jay Asher
My Review:
A light-hearted romance. Just what I needed after a month of hectic reading. 3.5 stars.

Sierra always loved christmas holidays. She and her parents would pack their bags to California, where they had a christmas tree farm from which they sold, both for business and a tradition. Her friends at Oregon would have loved to have her stay, but Sierra isn't sure they would get another vacation at Oregon, so she wants to make the most of it.
Her best friend there is Heather, who wants her to have a christmas fling so that they could go on a double date. With her father around, Sierra wouldn't even think of dating a boy working at their farm. But when Caleb comes there to buy trees, she thinks of giving it a shot. Only, there are rumours about him, dangerous ones. And if she gets too attached she would have her heart broken when they finally leave, and never come back. Would she risk it? Was Caleb worth it all?

Thoughts
○~I loved the premise. I've never heard of christmas tree farms before. It felt like a refreshing change from the usual high school YA romances.

○~The writing. Jay Asher's words are somehow a reflection of my thoughts. That's what I loved about [b:Thirteen Reasons Why|29844228|Thirteen Reasons Why|Jay Asher|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1496655158s/29844228.jpg|2588213] and that's why I knew I would like this one.

○~I loved the relationships portrayed. Sierra's friendships were really nice to read about. Heather, Rachel and Elizabeth were all really good side characters. I wish I had seen more of them.

○~The characters might have been good, but the characterisation lacked depth. I've read the whole book, and I realise I don't really know my characters. That's a big put-off.

○~The ending wasn't any remarkable. If anything, it felt a bit abrupt. It was as if the author did not have anything much to say, so he decided it was upto the readers. Nit that it wasn't good. But just that it didn't give me the satisfying sigh you get after finishing a contemporary romance.

So yeah, this isn't the best of Jay Asher and I hoped a better, indepth book from him. But I did love the book. It was the a book that came at the right time.

Title: Matilda
Author: Roald Dahl
Bookshelves: classics, books-for-children, i-need-the-book, loved-the-protagonist, magical-realism, all-time-favourites, young-adult
Bookshelves with positions: classics (#35), books-for-children (#48), i-need-the-book (#2), loved-the-protagonist (#18), magical-realism (#4), all-time-favourites (#18), young-adult (#118)
My Review:
I LOVED IT. It was freaking Amazing. Magnificient. Magical. Oh God, Where are all the adjectives when I need them?



I wish I had read Matilda years ago. Oh I SO wish I could've read it as a child, I would've read it again and again and again, I would have had it memorised. ( I would most possibly do that now btw)
Roald Dahl is one hell of a writer and his words are so so beautiful, I gulped them like a thirsty cat. Uh-huh, never did I think I would have such a reaction to a children's book, but no, I HAVEN'T DEVOURED A BOOK LIKE THIS IN WHAT SEEMS LIKE A HUNDRED LONG YEARS.!! I need all of the Dahl books. Right. Now.

And the story? I hadn't a least bit idea of what it was, until I started,.. and never stopped, till I finished it.

Matilda is a brilliant child, like, genius-brilliant, Dumbledore-like-brilliant, child-prodigy-brilliant, just freaking BRILLIANT. She's learned to read books all by herself, she can do calculations like a mathematician and she has read quite a lot of books from the public library and she is a FIVE YEAR OLD (I haven't read half of what she has. Need to expand my tbr). Her parents, Mr & Mrs.Wormwood does not even remotely think she is clever. They despise her, taunt her. And she works out plans to trick them too. (Those are hilarious!) When she joins the local school, Miss Honey, her teacher, immediately notices her intelligence. But the school Headmistress Miss Trunchball is a hot-headed, cruel woman who hates the sight of children and wouldn't spare to hear the babble of a child prodigy. Matilda isn't one to sit back and watch. She make plans. To take on Trunchball, her father, to save Miss Honey from her misery.

I DON"T KNOW WHAT IT WAS WITH THIS BOOK, it was really well-written, the characters were well-developed, the story was fun and easy-going. The scrawny illustrations were just the right amount of scrawny.It wasn't just Matilda, there is something in Roald Dahl's writing that would hook children and adults alike.
If given a gun, I would gladly shoot the living tits out of Trunchball. And tipping off a glass of water by sheer willpower? I'm gonna try that. My brain's been used for nothing other than to scan books for the past four months, so it just might work *wink-wink*
Also, I didn't see that twist coming!! Trunchball is Miss Honey's aunt!

I loved the way things were handled, how it all wrapped up beautifully. At the end, I was this wide-eyed 18 year old, wondering why the hell I didn't pick this up sooner. I'll make up for it though. I am getting Charlie and The Chocolate Factory, James and the Giant Peach and whatever it is that Dahl has written. I am not waiting anymore, I've wasted enough of my childhood (maidenhood?) already.

GOD BLESS ME, AND MATILDA, AND DAHL, AND ALL THE POOR BEINGS OUT THERE (to think I was one among them a few hours ago!), WHO HASN'T THE FAINTEST CLUE WHAT MATILDA IS OR WHAT THEY ARE MISSING BY NOT GRABBING THIS BOOK THIS VERY MOMENT. HAA! I guess that's enough blessings for the day.

And did I hear a movie? On MATILDA? I'm on my way.!

Title: Yesterday
Author: Samyann
Bookshelves: chick-lit, contemporary, i-need-the-book, magical-realism, really-liked-it, romance-lovey-dovey, why-no-hype, young-adult, sci-fi, verging-on-five-stars
Bookshelves with positions: chick-lit (#40), contemporary (#27), i-need-the-book (#3), magical-realism (#5), really-liked-it (#60), romance-lovey-dovey (#56), why-no-hype (#4), young-adult (#95), sci-fi (#13), verging-on-five-stars (#2)
My Review:
I received an ebook copy of this book from the publisher in exchange of an honest review. All opinions expressed are my own.

As Sherlock Holmes once said, ‘When you have eliminated the impossible, whatever remains, however improbable, must be the truth.’



ACTUAL RATING – 4.5/5

I LOVED THIS BOOK. Why isn’t anyone else reading and raving about it? Just 85 ratings on goodreads?! THAT’S THE WORST KIND OF DISRESPECT A BOOK THIS WELL-WRITTEN DOESN’T EVEN DESERVE.
PLEASE, PEOPLE – GRAB THIS BOOK AND READ IT. YOU’LL BE GLAD YOU DID.

Yesterday, as the title says, is a story of reincarnation. I’d thought it would be some cheesy, filmy romance, but no, it was amazing (romantic yes, but amazing all the same).

Amanda Parker saves the life of Mark Callahan from a train accident, in front of an antique shop. Mark is instantly attracted to Amanda, but Amanda is less so. She is still mourning for the death of Joe, her boyfriend. Everyone she has ever loved has succumbed to death. She now lives with Mary, her godmother, who is a psychiatrist. Amanda has vowed to herself that she would never let herself close to anyone ever again. But Mark is not the one to give up.

Both of them have this daunting feeling that they know each other but also know that they have never met before. Through regression sessions with Mary, Amanda learns of a past life, where she was Bonnie, living in Chicago in the late 1800s. Bonnie’s life is similar to Amanda. Her loved ones had deceased. This makes her all the more reluctant to accept Mark. But fate has a way of revealing its most brilliant plan at times like these. Amanda and Mark’s life are intertwined by fate. Will Amanda let it loose?

THOUGHTS

I was instantly hooked up by this book in the beginning itself. It had a very Gone With The Wind feel to it which made it even more appealing.

The plot, even though quite simple, is executed perfectly. The way the narratives alternate between the past and present lives, makes you more and more curious. And the little details in this book, like the St. Michaels church, the angel bells, and many such important artifacts too, later revealed to be real, blew my mind.

The writing was pure bliss. It isn’t the easy-to-read, comfortable style you are familiar with, but the engrossing style we associate with classics. Amanda and Mark’s slight bickering was refreshing.
Mark might come across as a dominant character, but he was a gentleman in true sense. Amanda’s reserved nature added mystery and depth to her character. I couldn’t find a fault with the character development, as hard as I did try.

There were some little issues though, which is the reason this was not a five-star read.

I wasn’t a fan of the constant romantic moments of the book, but because it was Mark and Amanda, it felt a bit more bearable. Amanda is very hesitant towards Mark at first, but she has no problem involving with him sexually. The kisses and cuddles, as hot as they were, seem pointless and overdone.

And also, It seems silly that Amanda didn’t recognize Daniel to be Mark right away. It was way too obvious.

Also, there’s a cat named Electra, which seems to live a bit too longer than its natural lifespan. Maybe cats lived for 20 years in the 19th century? Ah I don’t know.

Trees grow tall for the sake of the view. Falling is a small price to pay if you see something interesting on the way up.


I AM SAYING THIS AGAIN FOLKS, I LOVED THIS BOOK, AND I WANT YOU ALL TO READ IT. DOESN’T MATTER IF YOU LOVE IT OR NOT, IT IS ONE PIECE OF LITERATURE THAT SURE AS HELL DESERVES MORE ATTENTION THAN IT HAS.

Title: Monarchy (The Monarchy Trilogy Book 1)
Author: Laura Pritchard
My Review:
I received a copy of this book from the author, in exchange of an honest review.

This book was so similar to Divergent, unexpectedly so. The concept was same, the execution is where it differs. Anyways it was a quick, easy read.

Constance and Prior are siblings, living in sector six, of the six sectors under the rule of The Monarchy. No one knows who the monarchy is comprised of, or what it actually is. Only that they are the reason people have food on their plates and are taken care of.

Constance, being the elder daughter, is forced to join the brigade through a Removal Ceremony. She undergoes training with others, where the trainees are forced to bow to the monarchy and comply with their every will. There are rebels in the sectors, and Constance has to fight people of her own sector, or else risk the hatred of the Monarchy.

My thoughts -
-The writing was good and easy to read. But it felt kind of detached at times. I found myself thinking of things while reading, which was a first for me. I need books to distract me, not be the source of my distraction.

-The plot was poorly thought out - unoriginal. There were many instances where events were just skipped past and are explained later. It was confusing, not to mention annoying.

-The character development was scarce. Constance was bold and determined at first, and then she turns all cowardly. It didn’t make sense.

-The romance felt forced. It clearly was established to make the story interesting. I don’t think it worked.

-I loved the relationship between Theo and Constance. Their kinship was really good.

-Daisy and Lex might be my favorite characters.

-The cliffhanger at the end was expected, yet surprising.

All things considered, I would like to read the next book to know what happens further. Because no one deserves such an ending -_-

Title: That Night
Author: Cecily Wolfe
My Review:
I seriously have nothing to write about this book, because, while it was pleasant to read, it was uneventful all the same. 3/5 stars.

That Night is a story of love and death and how it affects people.

THE PLOT

Kayla is a popular girl. Being the football captain at their school; she was equally loved and respected. But one night, Kayla is found dead of heroin overuse at a party. Cass and Sarah, her best friends, and Paul, her boyfriend, is distraught and so is her family. This is the story of how they come to terms with her death, dealing with the negativity that came with it, and supporting each other throughout its aftermath.

THOUGHTS

This book did have its good points, it is well written, is more emotional than structural, the characters feel realistic and relatable. It had a good message, but I think it failed in its efforts to convey it meaningfully. The story is simply full of grief and sadness, and is far too stretched out for the reader to identify and sympathize for the characters.

Cass and Sarah, while we get to see their pain and love for their friend, I wish we had more of their lives, about themselves, of what actually happened, of their role in everything.

The book is just all about Kayla and by the end of it, we don’t even know her that well. The author justifies the lack of happenings in the book as being ‘emotional’ and more about the mentality of the characters, which in my personal opinion, wasn’t quite enough. Maybe my inability to sympathize for Sarah, Cass and Paul might be because I’ve never been in their position. I did try to understand, and on one level I’m sure I did, but then it got boring soon.

Overall, a simple story with a lot of emotional appeal. Original in its plot, but with a slightly overdone cause. Quick, easy read – failed to stir up my emotions, but otherwise did a good job at conveying its message. P.S I loved the last chapter- it was oddly satisfying.

Title: Under a Painted Sky
Author: Stacey  Lee
Bookshelves: contemporary, historical-fiction, i-need-a-movie, i-need-the-book, loved-the-protagonist, made-me-lol, made-me-cry, romance-lovey-dovey, really-liked-it, why-no-hype, writing-to-die-for, young-adult, verging-on-five-stars
Bookshelves with positions: contemporary (#33), historical-fiction (#16), i-need-a-movie (#12), i-need-the-book (#7), loved-the-protagonist (#24), made-me-lol (#13), made-me-cry (#31), romance-lovey-dovey (#74), really-liked-it (#68), why-no-hype (#5), writing-to-die-for (#3), young-adult (#114), verging-on-five-stars (#1)
My Review:
Wow! Another book hops to my favorites this year. I am impressed by the number of books that have appealed to me despite my refined and new regime of ‘strict rating’. Anyway, 4.5/5 stars

After losing her father to a tragic explosion at their beloved shop, Samantha Young –a talented Chinese violinist- is lost. The only person she knows to ask for help is their landlord Ty Yorkshire, who turns out to be devil in disguise. Samantha runs away with Annamae, a slave of Ty’s. They both disguise themselves as boys and sets off to California –both in pursuits of things they hold dear.

Samantha –or Sammy -is in search of Mr. Theodore, a friend of her fathers who is in possession of her mother’s bracelet. Annamae –or Andy –is searching for her brother Isaac, who is her only living relative, lost to her five years ago when they were all sold off. While on the trail as wanted murderers, they stumble on a group of three men –Peety, Cay and West. In a rush to reach California, they join the trio.

The group of five men –including two disguised girls -faces all the adversities together, helping each other in need, finding solace in stories, music and hope. They take us through a memorable journey, one to behold.


-The writing is gorgeous. Stacey Lee has made me fall in love with her prose. The first sentence was all it took. <3

-I loved that the protagonist was Chinese. The little tidbits from the Chinese culture we get to glimpse are beautiful. I loved the Chinese calendar, their tendency to look for double meanings, their belief in fate.

-The characterization is superb. Loved all of them.

-Cay was a sweetheart. He may flirt all he wants, but the times when he actually spoke, his words were worth memorizing. My personal favorite.

-I loved Chinnito – Sammy, that is. She is lovely girl inside out. I am really glad she didn't go all gaga swooning over her crush.

-West, even though mysterious with a tragic past, did not completely hook me off. Peety was better.

-Annamae was amazing. Her determination and stubbornness are the best of its kind.

-Sammy's dad, was a wonderful side character. I wish we could have had more instances with him alive. One of the best father figures in literature. He is totally along the lines of Atticus Finch and Jean Val Jean.

-Those wise words of wisdom form half the charm of the book. Literally!

-Even if the plot wasn't all that happening, and predictable, I loved every moment of it. The ending might have been a dead end, but to me, I was content reading it. Satisfied. Couldn't ask for more.

Overall, this book is beautiful. A story set with a backdrop of cultural diversity and history, it doesn't spit out facts at us. Would recommend to fans of To Kill a Mockingbird, The Book Thief, historical fiction, or just about any book lover. This book is delightfully painful and thought-provoking. You ain't gonna waste a cent reading this.
Recommended For: Fans of To Kill a Mockingbird, The Book Thief and Everyone else

Title: Someone Like You
Author: Nikita Singh
Bookshelves: indian-author-books, made-me-cry, romance-lovey-dovey, contemporary, all-time-favourites, chick-lit, i-need-the-book, i-need-a-movie, loved-the-protagonist, young-adult, characters-that-hold-my-heart, indian-readers-2017
Bookshelves with positions: indian-author-books (#2), made-me-cry (#6), romance-lovey-dovey (#6), contemporary (#7), all-time-favourites (#20), chick-lit (#47), i-need-the-book (#6), i-need-a-movie (#11), loved-the-protagonist (#23), young-adult (#109), characters-that-hold-my-heart (#1), indian-readers-2017 (#1)
My Review:
Mirrors remind me of things I am not, things I see other people are and things I would like to be. And also-sadly-things that I can never be.



Someone Like You – It seems I have a thing for that phrase. It is one of my favorite songs, and it is also, undoubtedly one of my favorite books. Look, I am not saying that this book is a great piece of literature – it isn’t. But sometimes, you just need to sit back, relax, and read a book, just to seek pleasure. Because if you read this book with a critic’s mind, you’ll do just that – criticize. And you’ll find many points to back you up. But for once, if you decide to read just for the sheer pleasure of it, to enjoy yourself, to marvel at life, to take yourself on a nostalgic trip, to make you want to cuddle in bed, then – Read this book. It was absolutely adorable yet heartbreaking, and I enjoyed every moment.

A week before starting college as a freshman, Niharika Singh visits her sister in Delhi. She has never been much beauty-conscious, but now that she is going to college, her sister Simran insists on a makeover. With newfound confidence in herself and her looks, Niharika also attracts Akshat Verma, a filthy rich guy, who is ever the gentleman. His perfect looks and demeanor instantly gets her and they go on a few dates. But this relationship is short-lived as she soon discovers Akshat had dated Simran.

Once in college, Niharika meets Tanmay, a cute, nerdy guy and they hit it off instantly. Her roommate Pia also enters the team, and they become an inseparable trio. There is also this mysterious guy Karthik, who is the college’s heartthrob. Niharika finds herself intrigued by him, but she knows better than to go by looks, thanks to Akshat.

A stalker who insists he’s changed for good, a guy who seems to be more than his looks, a roommate struggling to maintain a long-distance relationship, a guy friend who’s changing by the day – Niharika does have a story to tell.


The book is written in a simple, lucid prose, which suits the story surprisingly well. Durjoy and Nikita have a great coordination, and you simply cannot NOT notice the way they have blended both their voices as one. There wasn’t a moment to be bored. The plot is fast-paced, but it did take some time to gear up in the beginning.

There is love of all kinds – sibling-love, family-love, friendship, insta-love and a splash of romance. There is joy and elation. There is heartbreak and grief. And the best part is that the authors make sure you feel them all along with the characters.


Also – the characters. I really loved Niharika, the protagonist. She is innocent, sweet and naïve. I could relate to her on many levels. Some might find her to be flat and blunt, but for me her character was perfectly well-defined. Akshat, Tanmay, Karthik, Simran, Pia – each and every one of them were developed in such a realistic way that I wondered if it was a true story. But no, it is all fiction – all the more reason to compliment the authors for the great job they did.


The climax, even if I was forewarned, even if this was a reread, made me cry – again. It isn’t suspenseful or anything, but the whole book is like a feel-good Bollywood movie – of the best kind. The romance is there – but it isn’t cheesy. The guy is villainy – but not tough. The girl is innocent – but not stupid. Everything is just in the exact place.


Overall, if you are looking for a good contemporary read, pick this one next time. I’m sure it wouldn’t disappoint. The characters were remarkable and will stay with me for life. The plot wasn’t all that extraordinary, but good enough to be cherished. For smiles, cuddles, tears and all things warm 5/5 stars for sure.

Title: Home Fire
Author: Kamila Shamsie
Bookshelves: booker-books, books-i-own, drama-overloaded, i-didnt-get-the-point, romance-lovey-dovey, writing-to-die-for, freebies
Bookshelves with positions: booker-books (#4), books-i-own (#15), drama-overloaded (#18), i-didnt-get-the-point (#24), romance-lovey-dovey (#73), writing-to-die-for (#2), freebies (#2)
My Review:
I am not the least bit ashamed to admit that it took me over a month to read all of the 264 pages in this book. This book is one of those which you cannot read in one sitting, which grows on you with time, and demands very little attention. In this way, this book is going to blow your mind. But, NO, Shamsie has also done a fine job of OFFENDIG ALL THE MUSLIMS OUT THERE


Home Fire is the story of three siblings, the politics and nations they involve with, the choices they make, and the ones they regret.

Isma meets Eamonn one fine day as normally as how two strangers collide. But thereon begins a complicated relationship which ends when Eamonn learns of Isma’s distorted family background.

Eamonn, the son of the powerful Home Secretary Karamat Lone, then happens to meet Aneeka –Isma’s sister –a charming young lady, who is initially hostile with him. They both develop a mutual infatuation for each other. This relationship doesn’t go well with Karamat Lone, as Isma and Aneeka are practicing muslims, while the Lones are not. Also, the family has had a history of brewing terrorists. But when Parvaiz –Aneeka’s twin –goes in search of answers about their father, Aneeka is forced to seek Eamonn’s help.

Written in brilliant prose and a careful narrative through four people, this book depicts the complicated subject of religion, politics, history and relationships.


- The writing? Absolutely brilliant. Clever. Practiced. The attention to details is amazing.

- I am also blown by how accurately Shamsie trusts her readers to feel just the way she wants them to.

- Throughout the book, I never did feel any emotions; neither did I care for any of the characters.

- But I am still wondering why I feel positive about this book.

- This book is certainly a mind-effer.

- Okay, now for the REAL PART

- What stigmatic version of Islam was portrayed here?

- One I STRONGLY DISAGREE with.

- Seriously, the depiction of Muslims in this book was a social humiliation to all rest of us out here.

-
Friends don’t let friends be hipsters


- Why Shamsie, why? Why do you have to degrade Muslims this way?

- Because, I am telling you people, the one depicted in this book is not even close to the REAL thing.

- Like, which Muslim woman would have sex with a total stranger one day and put on a hijab to pray the next morning?

- THAT IS TOTALLY UNACCEPTABLE.

- Bloody girl, either you take off your hijab and go be a whore OR you stop declaring you are a Muslim.

- Because, no, you cannot do it all at once. It is humiliating to the rest of us.

- Throughout the book, I felt the religion being mocked at, the author’s sarcasm makes itself clear.

- THAT, I CANNOT TOLERATE. Sorry, you lost some stars there.

Overall this book is a fine one, with a story to tell, but not a message as a whole. It conveys meanings through its many lines, but I couldn’t tell what it is actually meant to do as a whole.
My initial reaction was 3.5, but here it is, 2.5/5 stars

Favorite line –

Well, you obviously don’t love anyone very much if your love is contingent on them always staying the same
